SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 976 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
At More Companies, Benefits Without the Wait

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
WORKERS at the 15 retail stores of the Tile Shop do not receive many of the perks that many a new-economy employer may dish up to attract talent. They get no stock options, no nap rooms and certainly no on-site pet care.
But the company does offer a big lure for new hires: Instead of waiting months or years to be eligible to join the 401(k) retirement savings plan, workers at Tile Shop can join as soon as they walk in the door. 
 As job-hopping has become common in many industries, employers say that the traditional waiting periods for benefits have become an obstacle to recruiting. Qualified workers who already have benefits are loath to do without them, even temporarily, to take a new job.
So more employers are reducing or eliminating the probationary periods for savings plans, vacation time, profit sharing and sometimes even medical insurance coverage, benefits experts say. And companies that have not formally changed their waiting periods are increasingly willing to waive them if a potentially valuable new employee asks.
"In the current job market, this is a highly desirable thing to offer," said Dallas L. Salisbury, president and chief executive of the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington.
Hard statistics are scant, but many companies say they see anecdotal evidence that when benefits are available quickly, vacancies are filled faster and turnover among new employees is lower.
The short-wait or no-wait approach seems to spreading fastest for retirement savings plans. According to surveys by the Profit-Sharing/401(k) Council of America, a nonprofit organization that includes both sponsors and providers of plans, 40 percent of companies let new employees join 401(k) plans within their first three months in 1999, up from 32 percent the previous year. And 18 percent made them eligible for profit-sharing plans that quickly, up from 12 percent.
Robert A. Liberto, a vice president at Segal Advisors, the investment consulting unit of the Segal Company, a benefits consulting firm based in New York, estimated that over the last year, at least one-third of his company's clients have shortened or eliminated waiting periods for 401(k)'s.
"We're seeing clients moving away from one-year eligibility to either immediate eligibility or eligibility the month following the beginning of employment," he said. "Companies see it as a competitive issue. Allowing people to come into a plan immediately doesn't penalize them for coming from another job."
More than a tight labor market is at work. Federal rules governing 401(k) plans oblige employers to enroll as many middle- and low-paid workers as possible, to ensure that the plan is not deemed to unfairly favor highly paid workers, though recent rulings have eased some of the restrictions. Companies can now enroll workers automatically, and the Internet has made benefits administration easier for employers.
But recruiting is the primary motive. Pearson Inc., the American arm of Pearson P.L.C., the media conglomerate based in London, eliminated its three-month wait for medical benefits in January 1999. A year later, it trimmed the wait for 401(k) plan eligibility from as long as six months to no more than 30 days, depending on the date of hiring.
"We've gotten positive feedback that this has been an effective recruiting tool," said Randall Keller, senior vice president for human resources.
At the Tile Shop chain, based in Plymouth, Minn., executives were also concerned about retention; Minnesota, after all, has an unemployment rate of just 2.5 percent. Historically, turnover in the company's sales and manufacturing divisions ran to 80 percent a year, and personnel officers found themselves having to fill the same jobs every few months. Scrapping the 90-day wait to join the 401(k) has given new workers a greater stake in staying, said Dianna Kincade, the human resources director at the company.
Immediate eligibility for medical plans, however, is not yet as common, but it, too, is spreading. Kenneth R. Jacobsen, who leads the national health practice at Segal, said many more companies were shortening the wait for medical coverage from 90 days to 30. "We're seeing this trend in mid- to large-sized companies, and we're seeing it at a pace that is three to four times higher than a year or two ago," Mr. Jacobsen said.
Not all waiting periods appear headed for the out box. Employee stock ownership plans, for example, still tend to have one-year eligibility requirements, because they are explicitly intended to reward longevity, said Corey Rosen, director of the National Center for Employee Ownership in Oakland, Calif.
Experts caution that "immediate eligibility" can mean different things at different companies. Prospective employees should check the fine print to make sure that they understand a company's rules. "It might be the first day of earnings, or it might be the first day of the first month after you start work, or even the first day of the second month," said David Wray, president of the Profit Sharing/401(k) Council. The variations sometimes reflect differences in how quickly companies process a new employee's paperwork, he said. Knowing when coverage will start, of course, helps job changers decide whether to extend their former employers' medical coverage under the federal Cobra law to cover any gap.
Still, whether they kick in immediately or almost immediately, accelerated benefits are making a difference. Carl Randazzo, a regional manager at the Tile Shop, said turnover had dropped sharply at the five stores he manages since his company eliminated the waiting period for its 401(k) plan. The change, Mr. Randazzo added, is also making a big difference in hiring.
"If people are looking at two job offers, this benefit can cinch it so that they go with us," he said.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK;
On the Rez, an Entrepreneur to Be Reckoned With

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
LONG one of the major summer attractions on Long Island, the Shinnecock Powwow is also the major revenue-producer for the Shinnecock tribe. This year's powwow, the 54th, is co-chaired by a young entrepreneur whose respect for tradition and flair for retailing has made him the tribe's largest employer and a new-generation leader.
To increase revenues this year, the Shinnecock Powwow committee has approved some new marketing methods, including a small television advertising campaign, a ticket package with a multiple-visit option, and a Friday start that expands the event to three days. The tweaking reflects the entrepreneurial savvy of Lance A. Gumbs, the tribe's leading entrepreneur. 
 If the weather is good, attendance will exceed 30,000, according to state police estimates, though several local business leaders outside the reservation estimate attendance typically exceeds that level several times over. Even using conservative estimates, the powwow reigns as one of the East End's major tourist draws, rivaling the 45,000 figure for attendance at the Hampton Classic equestrian event.
Mr. Gumbs, who has his own retail business, continues to spur the tribe's economic growth, combining modern merchandising and business strategies with traditional Native American values. Active in powwow planning for a number of years, Mr. Gumbs, who is in his mid-30's but won't give an exact age, is officially a powwow co-chairman this year for the first time.
"The success of powwow shows us that tourism is the direction we as a people can take," Mr. Gumbs said last week. "We're sitting here smack in the middle of one the top tourism areas of the United States. But for all the money and the visitors, there's a lack of things like major hotels, conference centers, and various tourism services. We're pursuing opportunities to do what other tribes across the country have done."
Does that mean casino gambling, embraced by numerous Native American tribes as a revenue generator? Mr. Gumbs was noncommittal. "We are in discussion with several prospective partners about development opportunities," he said. "No option, is ruled out."
A passionate advocate of Native American economic self-sufficiency, Mr. Gumbs recalled growing up on the 750-acre Shinnecock reservation, just west of Southampton village, painfully aware of economic inequities. One of his early role models was his first employer, Gus Johnson, an entrepreneurial Shinnecock whose carting business served residences and businesses in the surrounding community. Hauling trash in Southampton was a constant reminder of the greater wealth outside the reservation, Mr. Gumbs recalled, and a spur toward achieving prosperity himself.
Helping Mr. Johnson was hard work, Mr. Gumbs said, but preferable to the main alternative: caddying at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. He said he didn't want to chase golf balls for white men.
A few years later the teenager was hired by Dan Rattiner, the publisher of Dan's Papers, as a general assistant. With Mr. Rattiner's encouragement, he enrolled at Adelphi University in Garden City. After completing his sophomore year, young Mr. Gumbs spent his summer vacation turning a roadside shack he had inherited from his father into a rudimentary storefront, stacked with cigarettes and sundries. A reservation-based store, he had learned, could sell tobacco products without charging sales tax.
Even with the exemption, the first few years were difficult, Mr. Gumbs recalled. Clearing $700 the first summer and $2,000 the second made him reconsider a retailing future. The third year, he installed insulation so the store could run year round and began advertising in local newspapers. Business grew, and brought competition: a fellow Shinnecock set up a similar tax-free tobacco store in a nearby building.
Mr. Gumbs created a new ad that helped distinguish his store from the new competition, and also spruced up the store's image. Putting his undergraduate training in commercial art to good use, he designed a logo, a slogan -- "People of the Shore" -- and staff uniforms.
Mr. Gumbs has expanded far beyond tobacco. The Indian Outpost also stocks a wide array of merchandise ranging from compact discs of Native American music to packaged food products such as chili stew and fry bread mixes. Adjoining the original store, Mr. Gumbs has built a delicatessen and a wholesale bakery.
In the mid-1990's, he opened the Trading Post in Green Acres Shopping Center in Valley Stream, selling a similar inventory of Native American crafts, books, CD's and jewelry. That was followed by the Shinnecock Gallery, which offers more upmarket inventory, with much original artwork, on tony Jobs Lane in the Village of Southampton. He said he has 31 Shinnecocks on his payroll.
John Strong, a Southampton College professor emeritus who is an expert on Native American traditions, met Mr. Gumbs while researching his book on the Shinnecocks, "We're Still Here." He described Mr. Gumbs as "a very bright guy with sound business judgment" who has brought a new level of business sophistication to the powwow. His role as co-chairman of the powwow, with Fred Bess, reflects the tribe's increasing respect for his leadership skills, according to Professor Strong. (Members of the Shinnecock Tribal Council did not return calls seeking comment.)
Mr. Gumbs's brand of private enterprise represents a variation on traditional Native American economic activity that has some internal dissenters. "There are other schools of thought that say Native American businesses should be run by the tribe, rather than by individuals," said Professor Strong. "I think in the past Lance has been frustrated by that thinking."
Mr. Gumbs defended his brand of capitalism. "Individual stores provide employment for many tribal members and demonstrate to people on the reservation that building a business is a viable prospect," he said. "Starting a business isn't for everybody, but if it's your dream you should go forth with it."
Earlier this year, Mr. Gumbs brought Jacques Ditte and Jan Hanna onto the reservation to film footage for the first television commercials promoting the powwow.
"To succeed as a fundraiser, powwow has to bring in thousands of people onto the reservation, which means you've got to promote it in newspapers, radio and television," said Mr. Ditte, who co-owns Black Sheep Television, a multimedia production agency, in Westhampton Beach with Ms. Hanna. "The tribal elders realize that, but were concerned about us coming in with lighting and TV cameras. Lance opened the door for us, but had to do a lot of negotiating for the commercials to happen."
In recent years Mr. Gumbs has become known as one of the country's leading Native American entrepreneurs.
"I think Lance is to be congratulated for his success and the expansion of his business, involving members of his tribe and other Native Americans," said Deborah Champlain, a Narragansett who operates a Web site about Native American activities, newigwam.com. "You don't hear many success stories like his."

HEADLINE: 32-Story Hotel Is Rising on Baltimore's Harborfront

BYLINE: By CHARLES BELFOURE

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
A 32-STORY hotel that will be the city's largest is nearing completion as part of a $500 million redevelopment of a gritty industrial area that links the original Inner Harbor project with two gentrified historic neighborhoods.
 Inner Harbor East, with three million square feet of space on 18 acres, is considered the linchpin in the redevelopment of the 32-block industrial area that connects the Inner Harbor with the residential neighborhoods of Fells Point and Canton. With several other pending projects, it will help create a continuous path of development along two miles of the harbor. 
 Developed by H&S Properties Development Corporation of Baltimore, Inner Harbor East will eventually be nine contiguous blocks of residential, retail, office and entertainment space. The current construction is actually the second phase of the development. It began in 1995 with the construction of the 130,000-square-foot headquarters for Sylvan Learning Systems and the Promenade, a 113-unit rental building, at a total cost of $33 million.
 When finished next February, the 750-room Baltimore Marriott Waterfront will be the first hotel to be built here in 15 years. Aside from providing guest rooms for business travelers and tourists, the $135 million concrete tower will provide critically needed space for convention visitors.
 The hotel has a separate entry and lobby for busloads of conventioneers. Two levels are specifically for convention activities, including column-free ballrooms of 20,000 and 17,000 square feet that can be divided into smaller meeting spaces. Rooms with hospitality suites for seminars surround the ballrooms, and there is a space designed as a command post for meeting planners. A large freight elevator can bring displays and equipment, including automobiles, directly from the street to the ballrooms for meetings.
 The new hotel has already had an effect on convention business, according to Michael S. Beatty, a vice president of H&S. "The Shriners convention is booked for 2005," he said. "That's 30,000 visitors."
 Regular guests will arrive under a porte-cochere about 20 yards from the edge of the harbor and enter a vaulted lobby. The penthouse level contains rooms of usual size as well as luxury suites with views for five miles in all directions.
 Next to the hotel tower is a 50,000-square-foot office-retail complex, with 600 parking spaces, being built for $20 million. A 210,000-square-foot office building, already fully leased, that shares a two-story retail base with an adjacent hotel is under construction on the block bounded by Fleet Street, Central Avenue, Exeter Street and Aliceanna Street four blocks away. The 207-room hotel will fly the Marriott Courtyard flag, and be intended for business travelers. The $22 million complex, to be completed in November, will have a Fresh Fields supermarket on the first floor and a 370-space parking garage above it.
BEGINNING in early 2001 and across from the Marriot Courtyard on Exeter Street, construction will start on a 90,000-square-foot entertainment complex that will include an 18-screen movie theater and 40,000 square feet of retail stores on the street level.
 A 450,000-square-foot office and retail building with 1,200 spaces of underground parking is due to begin early next year in the adjacent block. The residential part of the project along Lancaster Street will begin as well, with the construction of a 225-unit long-term-stay hotel and two luxury apartment buildings with 225 and 90 units. A 300,000-square-foot office building by the edge of the water is also being considered.
 H&S was not the original developer of the project. The first developer assembled the parcels in the 1980's, but got into financial difficulties and came close to foreclosure. When the bank was about to call its loan, city officials asked John Paterakis Sr., who owns H&S Bakeries, a major supplier to regional food stores, a few blocks to the east, to buy the loan. He did, expecting the city to acquire the property from him at the same price he paid for it.
 When it did not, Mr. Paterakis, with no development experience to speak of, reluctantly started the project himself. He brought in a co-developer to obtain approvals and create a master plan. In 1995, frustrated by delays, Mr. Paterakis became an active one, Mr. Beatty said, constructing the Sylvan building and the Promenade.
 For all its early reticence about development, H&S is now diving headlong into two more large projects directly south of Inner Harbor East. It has formed a joint venture with a major Baltimore developer, Streuver Brothers Eccles & Rouse, and is completing the acquisition of the vacant Allied Signal site from Honeywell Corporation. About $300 million is expected to be spent to turn the 27-acre parcel into a mixed-use development to be called Harbor Point, with 1.8 million square feet.
 Near the southeastern edge of the Allied Signal site is a six-acre parcel along Thames Street, on which Streuver Brothers Eccles & Rouse and H&S will build 141 residential units and 330,000 square feet of office space. That project will cost $90 million and be completed in 2003.
 Other pending projects, a few blocks away, include an 80,000-square-foot four-story building for Whitman Requardt & Associates, one of the oldest engineering firms in the city. The Living Classroom Foundation will build the nation's first museum dedicated to black seamen and shipbuilders a few blocks east of the Allied site.
 H&S Bakeries, which started in a row house in East Baltimore 60 years ago, owns several blocks and buildings east of the project, but has no plans to relocate or to redevelop that property.
 Inner Harbor East's tower was criticized as out of scale with the adjacent neighborhood of Little Italy, criticism that was rejected by its developers, who cited zoning that would have allowed them to build a taller structure. "We could have built a 430-foot hotel, but we kept it at 330 feet and reduced the bulk of the other buildings so they wouldn't overwhelm the streets," Mr. Beatty said.
 Critics still complain about the scale of the Inner Harbor East project, but accept its economic value for Baltimore's waterfront. "Our project will be a huge driver for people who want to live down here," Mr. Beatty said. "We've tried to create a 24-hour environment with a mix of residences, offices, retail and entertainment."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Online Links Help Find Contractors

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS will tell you that one hallmark of a hot economy is an increase in the amount of money homeowners are willing to spend on upgrading, repairing and maintaining their homes.
What they won't tell you is how to find a good contractor. 
 "Right now, we're booked almost a year in advance," said Jesse Taylor, president of Just Decks, a contractor in Toms River, N.J. "I get a lot of people asking me about putting in fences and swimming pools and things like that, but I tell them that's why we're named Just Decks. I couldn't handle the extra work anyway."
Indeed, any homeowner who has scoured the telephone book looking for a contractor has discovered that it is often now the contractor who gets to pick and choose customers rather than the other way around.
A number of Internet-based services, however, have been set up to help consumers find qualified and reliable contractors.
"We provide a free service to homeowners by matching them with prescreened contractors, architects and designers in their geographic area," said Sharon Land, a manager with ImproveNet, an online contractor referral service based in Redwood City, Calif.
Ms. Land said that the company has about 40,000 registered contractors who have passed a stringent prequalification procedure.
"We screen under four criteria," she said, explaining that before contractors will be accepted by ImproveNet they must have been in business under the same name for at least three years, must have a clean legal history (which means that the company cannot have been on the losing end of any lawsuits brought by clients or creditors) and a clean credit history, and must provide proof of insurance.
"About half the contractors who apply fail the screening process," Ms. Land said.
Nora DePalma, a spokeswoman for ImproveNet, said the company had registered contractors in every state who were experts in just about every home improvement specialty. But unlike most referral services -- which provide homeowners with lists of contractors based on geographical factors or the type of project contemplated -- ImproveNet provides the contractors with the names of homeowners.
"The way we work is the homeowner describes the project by filling out an online form," Ms. DePalma said, adding that a description of the work to be performed, along with a hoped-for start date and a range of what the customer can afford, is then passed along to contractors in the homeowner's general vicinity.
"The first four contractors who respond are given the name and telephone number of the customer," she said. "We tell customers that it will take about a week for contractors to respond, but in practice it usually takes just two or three days."
The service is free to homeowners, Ms. DePalma said, because the contractors pay ImproveNet a commission for every job they get through the company. "They pay us between 2 and 10 percent of the job, depending on the type of work they do," she said, adding that the maximum amount a contractor is required to pay ImproveNet for any individual job is $995.
In addition to simply matching up homeowners with contractors, ImproveNet also monitors the process to provide additional assistance and follow-up. "We assign a personal project adviser to monitor the relationship between the homeowner and the contractor," Ms. Land said, explaining that the adviser is available to answer questions the homeowner may have and to assess the results of the matchup when the work is done. The Internet address of ImproveNet is www.ImproveNet.com.
Another nationwide online contractor referral service is Handyman Online, a company based in Beaverton, Ore. "We just recently referred out our 100,000th home improvement project," said Bruce Stahl, director of marketing for the company.
Mr. Stahl said that Handyman Online (www.handymanonline.com) was formed in 1997 by two former contractors.
"We realized that there was a real consumer need for this type of service," Mr. Stahl said. "And the service works well for the contractors, too, because it's a more efficient way for them to find customers."
Mr. Stahl explained that the 8,000 or so contractors currently registered with Handyman Online had all been prescreened by the company.
"Before we send anyone out to a customer we check to make sure that the contractor has insurance and that he is licensed if licensing is required in the state where he's doing business," Mr. Stahl said. "We also require every contractor to provide three references and to sit down with us for a personal interview."
Like ImproveNet, Handyman Online is free to customers because contractors pay the company when they land jobs. "Our contractors pay us a fee of anywhere from $10 to several hundred dollars, depending on the size and type of the job," Mr. Stahl said, adding that his company also assigns a customer service representative to each homeowner who requests a contractor.
"We contact the customer to make sure that a contractor has called," he said. "And then we follow up on the job until the project is completed."
Other Internet sites that provide on-line contractor referrals include www.nari.org, the Web site of the National Association of the Remodeling Industry; www.ServiceMagic.com, a company that provides consumers who submit project descriptions with up to three qualified professionals, and www.NationalContractors.com, a company that specializes in providing preconstruction project planning experts for remodeling projects costing $25,000 or more.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Looking at Change From Both Sides Now

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS

 BODY:
CREATIVE ideas for new businesses should emerge from every level of a company, says Gary Hamel, author of "Leading the Revolution."
Professor Hamel works with companies on instilling a capacity for what he calls "radical innovation." He is also the co-author, with C. K. Prahalad, of a business classic, "Competing for the Future." 
 Following are excerpts from a recent interview.
 FRED ANDREWS
 
Q. Your earlier book was directed at the company. This one is directed at the individual. What happened?
 
A. The first book was really aimed for a rather senior audience, strategic planners and so on. This book is aimed at any individual anywhere who has a passion for creating something new.
Probably what has changed in my thinking is really two things. First, a realization that despite all the aphorisms to the contrary, change does not start at the top. As I began to look at how some really large companies had dramatically changed their identity and their sense of direction, more often than not it was not something that started at the top. It was started by people low down who lacked any kind of formal power.
And, second, there was a sense that many people in organizations had become cynical, frustrated, even angry, at the sense of not being in control. We've gotten an ever greater gap between rhetoric and reality inside large companies. We no longer call employees "employees." We call them "associates" and "members" and so on, and yet they're more expendable than ever.
So the goal was to see if we couldn't begin to turn back the estrangement and cynicism so aptly symbolized by Dilbert.
 
Q. Your book talks about Silicon Valley, but not about start-ups. Aren't they revolutionary?
 
A. I think we've drawn a false dichotomy between old economy and new economy, which is not very helpful. Every new-economy company is busily working to adopt the virtues of old-economy companies. They're all trying to learn how to build a global infrastructure, how to build a world-class brand, how to achieve operational excellence, how to build up scale and size. Those are all things companies have been doing for the last hundred years.
On the other hand, all those old-economy companies are being forced to learn to continually reinvent themselves, to exploit the imagination of every employee, to substitute markets for hierarchies, and so on. Where we're headed is a synthesis between the virtues of new-economy companies and old-economy companies.
 
Q. You say innovation is everyone's challenge. How so?
 
A. If you went back to the 1950's and asked somebody where does quality come from, they would have said either from the artisan or from the inspector. It either came from somebody with magical hands making luxury goods or from somebody at the end of a production line weeding out the bad products.
Dr. Deming W. Edwards Deming, an industrial consultant who theorized about quality control and emphasized teamwork and communication over competition and a few others in the mid-50's said it doesn't have to be this way. We can make quality everyone's job and improve quality enormously. It is hard to understand how radical that thought was.
I remember a meeting with Dr. Deming when he was presenting his ideas to the top management of one of America's big car companies. And the audience there literally thought he was nuts. They said: "Now tell us again, we're going to take people with eight years of formal education and teach them statistical process control? We're going to let employees stop a billion-dollar production line?" And of course now we take that for granted, but that would be radical at the time.
And today the challenge is not quality; the challenge is innovation. So we need to do for innovation what we did for quality.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Bennett Stepping Out With Studio And Dropping in for a Performance

BYLINE: By ROBBIE WOLIVER

 BODY:
TONY BENNETT certainly lives the good life. And he is about to share some of his sweet fortune with his former hometown of Englewood.
The dapper crooner and his youngest son, Daegal, known as Dae, are in the process of building a state-of-the-art production center on the site of Englewood's downtown railroad station. Bennett Studios will incorporate music recording, television and cable production, as well as provide Internet production and Webcasting. 
 "This will be a great cultural and economic asset to the community," said Mr. Bennett, in a phone conversation from Chicago, where he was performing. Currently enjoying his first sold-out world tour, he will appear at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, with the jazz singer Diana Krall, on Wednesday.
Mr. Bennett, who recently turned 74, is the last of the great traditional pop singers. With the deaths of peers like Mel Torme and Frank Sinatra (whom Mr. Bennett called "my best friend"), the singer may be the only link left to America's most popular musical tradition. And he holds that iconography with grace.
Mr. Bennett lived in Englewood from 1957 to 1971, and Dae Bennett operates a successful recording studio there. His Hillside Studio is a small, one-room operation, but many top artists have recorded there, including Queen Latifah, George Benson and Dizzy Gillespie, another Englewood favorite son.
The younger Mr. Bennett , 44, lives in Tenafly with his wife, Anita, and two teenage sons, Austin and Jared, but his artistic home is Englewood.
He is pleased that his father encouraged him to proceed with the project.
"It is a lot more ambitious than something I'd usually take on, but everything fell into place here," Dae Bennett said. "We've had our eye on this great location for a while."
The Englewood depot has a long history. After serving for decades as the local train station, the building was leased out by the city through the Englewood Economic Development Corporation. The site has been the home to several restaurants, though none were profitable enough to remain. The Bennetts hope to retain the historic look of the slate-roofed Victorian brick building (with grand windows in the former waiting room).
"This was a beautiful building in the perfect location," said Dae Bennett, though recording sessions must pause when the occasional train passes. "We'll get 15 minutes notice."
The 6,500-square-foot studio, located at 1 Depot Square, off Van Brunt Street, otherwise known as Dizzy Gillespie Place, will also form a partnership with the nearby nonprofit John Harms Center, an old vaudeville theater that currently presents concerts ranging from rock to classical.
The city is expected to build a trench between the two buildings so that a fiber-optic cable would connect them, enabling live recordings and other high-tech productions. Sixty-four channels of audio and video data will be broadcast between the two locations. Danny Bennett, Dae Bennett's older brother and Tony Bennett's manager, runs the A&E cable series "Live by Request," in which viewers call in requests for songs. He will bring his experience in televising shows to the studio operation.
"The idea of recording classical performances and theater from there is making many people excited," Tony Bennett said. "A theater like that is the perfect acoustic setup for symphonies and orchestras."
A Bennett Studios offshoot is the Tony Bennett Center for Media Arts, a school offering internships and educational opportunities to local students from Dwight Morrow High School. Dae Bennett will teach students who will create hands-on projects at the studio.
Tony Bennett, who is also spearheading the Frank Sinatra School of Performing Arts in Astoria, Queens, said: "What makes this project so exciting to me is bringing kids into the studio and giving them an opportunity to learn about recording, to teach them about the music business. It opens up the world to them."
Bennett Studios will feature two large rooms, one specializing in mixing, the other, a 50-by-30 space, will specialize in recording. There will also be a computer editing room and an area for Internet and Web-based media. There will be receptacles for cameras to offer clients streaming potential.
Dae Bennett said an important design aspect was that the studios look homey. "For many artists this will be their home away from home," he said. "It has to be comfortable, and not look like a dentist's office." The Bennetts expect the center to open in February.
"Our interest is to bring the industry into Englewood," Tony Bennett said. "There are a lot of technical and musical people already there.
"It's perfect. It's close enough to the Apple, but there are no police sirens or ambulances. Celebrities will be utilizing the businesses downtown, going to restaurants, shopping. It will be like our own Rodeo Drive."
The studio will also pay homage to Tony Bennett's career. "It's equivalent to a presidential library, a reflection of his life's work," his youngest son said. "It will include his artwork, memorabilia and music.
"We're talking about a man who is incredibly gracious and classy. I want this to be a living legacy to him."
Tony Bennett, who has been singing professionally for 50 years, is humbled by the idea of the studio, but even more so about working with his sons. "When I think of my father who came to the United States with $35 in his pocket, I know how blessed I am.
"I get to sing and paint, my two favorite things. And I get to share all this joy with my family who I love. I never dreamed it could get this magnificent."
Mr. Bennett also has two daughters -- Joanna, an actress, and Antonia, who is currently attracting attention as a jazz singer.
The studio will also be a place for lectures, and eventually outside concerts. "Just give me a drum roll, and I'll come out and sing," warned Mr. Bennett, "and I look forward to bringing in many of my artist friends to record here."
Mayor Paul Fader of Englewood is optimistic about the project. "This is one of the greatest things to happen to the city," he said. "This will make Englewood the entertainment capital of Northern New Jersey.
"Tony Bennett has the pizazz, prestige, name recognition, talent, and ability to pull this thing off with class."
Mr. Bennett has always been regarded as a class act.
"I did get shaken when the Beatles came out," he recalled. "I didn't know what to do, if I should change my style or not. But I never changed, and I think that's what people like. I never try for fads. I just try to sound good and keep singing good songs that never sound dated. I won't compromise my music. My saying is, 'When you're hot, keep going.' "
And it is not just former bobby-soxers who go mad for Mr. Bennett; the MTV generation does as well.
"I am so pleased I've been embraced by the rock crowd," he said. "Some of those musicians have become great fast friends, like Sting and Elton John."
Mr. Bennett, who paints every day, is also an artist of some renown. "It is such a surprise when my paintings fly off the walls. What a feeling of confidence and encouragement." He was recently commissioned to design the official poster for the Kentucky Derby.
"A painting makes you fall in love with life," he said, as he prepared to take a four-hour preconcert break to paint at Lake Michigan. "When you paint nature, you say, 'What a miraculous world we live in.' It's the search for truth and beauty.
"Singing is more extroverted. You help people forget serious problems and make people feel good."
Backed by the Ralph Sharon Quartet in concert, Mr. Bennett sails through a repertory that covers several decades. His songbook is vast, from George Gershwin to Duke Ellington to "Steppin' Out," the MTV-driven song that made him a pop-culture icon. He also shares two duets with Ms. Krall.
An impeccable musician and remarkable showman, the high-styled Mr. Bennett has left his mark in music and art worlds.
 "He might have left his heart in San Francisco," said Mayor Fader, "but he will be leaving his legacy in Englewood."
 
TONY BENNETT AND DIANA KRALL

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS: for BOB TASCA Sr.;
On the Front Lines of the Tire Recall

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY

 BODY:
BOB TASCA Sr. has kicked plenty of tires in his 73 years. He estimates that he, his sons and his grandson, who own a Lincoln-Mercury dealership in Massachusetts and a Ford dealership in Rhode Island, have sold 330,000 cars and trucks.
Mr. Tasca once told Henry Ford 2nd that he made "lousy cars." Since then, Mr. Tasca has made more than 600 assembly-line inspections, telling Ford Motor executives how to fix flaws. He chronicled his exploits in accountability in a book, "You Will Be Satisfied" (Harper Business, 1996). 
 Since Aug. 9, when Bridgestone/Firestone announced the recall of 6.5 million tires, two-thirds of which were sold new on Ford sport utility vehicles and trucks, customers have flooded Mr. Tasca's service bays, demanding replacements. This week, before leaving to inspect a Ford plant in Detroit, he talked about the recall. Here are excerpts from the conversation. JULIE FLAHERTY
 
Q. How well has Ford handled the recall?
 
A. There was too much hesitation. They kept it hush-hush and didn't bring it out in the open. At the time that they were aware that a problem could have existed, that's when it should have happened. Now we've got all this hullabaloo. When we changed tires in Saudi Arabia, we should have changed tires in Texas. They should have announced it that day. I would have preferred to see anybody with a Firestone tire have the option of changing, but I don't think it's going to happen. They aren't going to be able to produce enough tires.
 
Q. What do customers say?
 
A. They are fearful of putting their children in the car. When you saw the accidents on the TV and in the newspaper, it didn't look like the chance of surviving was going to be too good. People are saying, "I don't want to buy a Firestone tire; I don't want to drive a car with a Firestone tire." There are people just scared stiff of the name Firestone, which is unfortunate. I've always had good experience with Firestone. I'm driving an Explorer Sport Trac with Firestones.
Of the 200 vehicles we checked, we changed about 36 sets, or 144 tires. I had to change ones that didn't have the defective code, too. I had one elderly lady whose Firestone tires were not that code who said: "I am not going to drive the car. I'm going to park the car right here." So I took the Goodyear tires off another car and put them on hers.
 
Q. Is this the biggest crisis you have seen with Ford?
 
A. I've had callbacks my whole life. It is probably a scarier callback than most of them, but we've had callbacks where the car can catch fire because the fuel line was not routed properly, callbacks where a bolt was not tempered properly and the front end can fall off. But this will go down in the top 10 percent.
 
Q. How long do you expect the clamoring to last?
 
A. Today was one-fifth of yesterday. It's tapering off. It could take three or four weeks. It might take some time to convince people that if you've got a Firestone and it's not one of the bad ones, you're O.K. If you can get people to believe that, you're over the last hurdle.
It's costing me money, between $5,000 and $20,000, but I never worry about what it costs me to satisfy a customer. Obviously I don't want to go bankrupt. But I've been with Ford for 57 1/2 years. It's too late to get divorced now.
 
Q. Will the recall frighten people away from Explorers and sport utility vehicles?
 
A. I sold nine Explorers the day before yesterday -- that's the biggest Explorer day I've had all year. I changed the tires for Goodyears on two of them. But the people like S.U.V.'s. Sure, they're worried about safety, but we know how to make them safer, we know how to make them more economical, and if that's what the market wants, we'll do it. We're going to see a lot more S.U.V.'s, but they'll be a different type S.U.V.'s. We've got an Explorer, an Expedition and an Excursion -- I don't think we need them all. You'll see the biggest ones trimmed down in size.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
Is It Back to School, Or to the Loan Officer?

BYLINE: By Julie Dunn

 BODY:
How much you think you will spend on back-to-school shopping may be far different from the reality, a new study suggests.
Consumers who set aside a few hundred dollars for each child may find themselves woefully short. The average family will spend $5,423 to prepare for the new school year, for students in all levels of school, from elementary to college, according to the national study, which asked 1,002 people about their back-to-school purchases. 
 "There are a lot of peripheral costs that don't get added in initially," said Steve Rhode, the president and co-founder of Myvesta.org, formerly Debt Counselors of America, a nonprofit financial organization in Rockville, Md., that was co-sponsor of the study with Capital One Financial in Falls Church, Va.
Some parents buy another car, or maybe airline tickets, to send a college student to school, while some buy jerseys and other equipment for their elementary-school children who are involved in sports activities. And some schools require tuition be paid up front, Mr. Rhode said.
The study estimated that on average, a family would spend $2,457 on tuition and fees, for example, $1,610 on transportation and $591 on electronics.
"Back-to-school spending comes at the worst possible time, after that summer vacation, but right before the holidays," Mr. Rhode said.
He suggested involving children in money discussions, to teach them about financial responsibility. "Let them understand that there are limits to money and hard decisions to be made," he said.
Myvesta also advises parents to keep track of this year's spending to help set next year's budget. And it urges consumers to pay more than the minimum amounts due on credit cards. If a shopper pays only the minimum on a bill of $5,423 with an interest rate of 17.99 percent, Myvesta.org calculates, it will take 48 years to pay off the debt, which ends up totaling $20,843.
"We live in a minimum-payment mentality," Mr. Rhode said. "We mortgage our future for instant gratification."
 Julie Dunn

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Reclimbing the Real Estate Charts

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
HIS hair is thinner, though still tinted red, and his posture is slightly bent, but certainly not bowed. Harold Farb, the flamboyant Houston apartment developer who gained national attention for his excesses before he fell hard in the 1980's, is back.
Mr. Farb, 77, has spent the last 15 years selling office buildings and trimming his apartment portfolio by 90 percent, in order to pay off $455 million in debts from real estate deals that went bad when the price of oil hit the skids and took the Texas economy with it. He has also put behind him such costly indulgences as a supper club, where he headlined as a lounge singer, and a glossy magazine catering to Texas's rich and self-absorbed. 
 Now, Mr. Farb is putting the finishing touches on a $25 million, 372-unit apartment complex in the suburban Kingwood section of Houston -- his first project in a decade and a half. This time around, Mr. Farb said, he will keep his business on a firmer foundation.
Like many developers who lost their French-cuffed shirts when the Texas real estate market crashed in 1983, Mr. Farb has become more cautious. Gone are the days when he built 1,000-unit apartment buildings and office towers as if he were playing with Legos.
"I've learned I'm not invincible," said Mr. Farb, who before the real estate collapse made the Forbes 400 list of the wealthiest people in America, with an estimated net worth of more than $200 million. Yet, he added, "I'm not running scared, either."
A cinema buff who has financed five albums of himself singing show tunes, Mr. Farb has named his latest venture the Paramount, in honor of the studio that made many of the films he enjoyed watching as a boy in his father's two Houston movie theaters.
THE new apartment complex was built using the same builders, landscapers, finance officers, accountants and lawyers whom Mr. Farb used in his heyday. But now, he said, they are contract workers, not employees. Mr. Farb was also more selective about the location.
"Kingwood is zoned," he said, "so I know there isn't going to be a lot of junk going up around the property, like pawn shops and liquor stores," which would diminish its value.
Mike Inselmann, president of the American Metro/Study Corporation, a Houston company that compiles and analyzes housing data, said Mr. Farb is emblematic of most developers in the state.
"It took the Texas market getting sucked down the drain before we started seeing a more studied and restrained approach to building," Mr. Inselmann said.
Two years ago, at the slightest hint that the Houston market was going soft, new building permits started to tumble. They are projected to fall to 4,000 this year from 20,000 in 1998, Mr. Inselmann said. And the decline has come despite surging oil prices that have buoyed the local economy, and forecasts that 60,000 jobs, mostly unrelated to energy, would be created this year.
"Everyone would prefer to be safe than sorry," he said, adding that Mr. Farb's new development could cash in on local builders' overreaction.
Mr. Farb said he couldn't be happier about his timing or about his return to the apartment business. He is looking to develop more residential properties in Houston as well as in Atlanta. "Apartments are what I know," he said.
He is staying away from office buildings and ventures like the supper club and magazine that Mr. Farb said got him into "trouble with a capital T." (He is not as shy about marriage, despite his highly publicized divorce in 1983 from his second wife, the socialite Carolyn Farb, which cost him a reported $20 million, though he disputes that figure. He has married four times since then, including three separate ceremonies with his current wife, Diane Lokey.)
Outsiders agree that in focusing on apartments, he is playing to his strength. After all, Harold Farb apartments were once the hip places to live in Houston.
"If you were young and single and upwardly mobile in the 1970's, you lived in a Farb," said Liz Dantone, a project manager for the Friendswood Development Company, a former Exxon subsidiary that has built several residential communities around Houston. "He's still a master at branding."
Unlike apartments owned by anonymous real estate investment trusts, Mr. Farb's have always been identified with their owner, with his name and logo (showing him holding a rolled-up blueprint) plastered all over the place. Comment cards addressed "Dear Mr. Farb" are in every manager's office.
"Landlords have such a negative image," Mr. Farb said. "I've always let my tenants know who I am and how they can get in touch with me."
Often, Mr. Farb personally answers complaints written on those cards. He also visits his four remaining properties daily, making inspections, talking with maintenance men and striking up conversations with tenants.
"I've gone back to my roots of providing people with a nice place to live at an affordable price," Mr. Farb said. Even while charging cut rates -- his credo is "rent $10 below market" -- he pays extra for amenities like resort-quality pool furniture and high-end exercise equipment. "I want it to be a poor man's country club," he said.
THE pool at the Paramount will be graced with a 7-foot-high statue of Minerva, the Roman goddess of wisdom, that he salvaged from his defunct marble-and-mirrored supper club, the Carlyle.
"I paid $50,000 for that statue and now I have a place to put it," he said, pleased with his thrift. "My daddy told me to always eat hot dogs, even if you can afford steak," Mr. Farb said. That way, a reversal of fortune will not seem as severe.
"I still eat hot dogs," he said.

HEADLINE: Hypocritical Arms Sales

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While the United States tries to demonize Russia and China for arming questionable countries, it rarely thinks twice about its role as the world's top gunrunner (news article, Aug. 21). Are we more responsible in deciding who can buy weapons? Given that we arm or train more than 150 countries, the answer must be no.
Our arms export policy is that arms and services shall be provided for internal security, legitimate self-defense and United Nations operations. But this runs counter to our foreign policy, which condemns the oppressive practices of totalitarianism and violations of human rights. 
 If America wants the moral high ground, it must end this contradictory policy and put human rights and democracy before profits and narrowly defined economic and strategic interests.
 
MICHELLE CIARROCCA
New York, Aug. 21, 2000
 
The writer is a research associate at the World Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Somalis Take Close Look At Election In the U.S.

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia

 BODY:
Somalis who speak little English will still giggle and say: "Read my lips." Despite mixed feelings about Americans here, there is strong affection for the father -- as a man who tried to make peace in Somalia -- that has rubbed off on the son this American election year.
"We are following it," said Shuayb Abdi Karim, 30. "And we support Bush." Or "Bush Junior," as George W. Bush is sometimes called here. 
 Mr. Karim was standing in a spot that caused much pain for Somalis and Americans alike. An American Black Hawk helicopter was shot down there in October 1993, igniting an all-night battle in which 18 Americans and perhaps 500 Somalis died. Mr. Karim said his brother, who was 18, was killed by a stray bullet.
That battle marked the beginning of the end for America's military involvement in Somalia, and in all of Africa for that matter, under the Clinton administration. So the logic behind the fervor for George W. Bush here is that he might have a personal stake in reversing that, since his father sent American troops here in the first place.
"If the Republicans win, I think the Somali problem is over," said Abdi Sheikdon Negeye, 40, once one of Somalia's most popular radio personalities. "All Somalis believe that. We lost Somalia when the Democrats came in power."
Americans do not have good memories of Somalia (just as there are many Somalis who feel American soldiers went too far in trying to create peace here). And Mr. Bush has given no sign of any plan for re-engaging in one of the most troubled corners of the world if he wins the White House.
But that has not tamped down hope here. That hope is fueled partly by the memories of the money that flowed into Somalia during the United Nations operations here and softened the economic blow after the government of the dictator Muhammad Siad Barre -- and all central authority -- fell in 1991.
A vein of optimism is also rising to the surface in Somalia that there finally may be a return of government, from peace talks going on now in the neighboring country of Djibouti. Many Somalis say it would not take much money -- donated perhaps by the United States -- to give any new government an early dose of legitimacy.
Perhaps for those reasons, some Somalis are following American politics and this election very closely. Mr. Negeye, at a wedding in a well-guarded hotel in Mogadishu, was talking about how he views Republicans as far better on foreign policy than the Democrats. One Somali said he liked Mr. Bush because Gen. Colin Powell is also a Republican.
At one of Mogadishu's beautiful beaches, Abdulahi Ahmed Koronto, 42, said he sees Mr. Bush as having stolen Bill Clinton's old game plan, positioning the Republicans to the center.
"George Bush is a man who has taken policy from the Democrats," said Mr. Koronto, a programs officer for a foreign aid agency in better days who is now unemployed. "He looks very compassionate. His father was not compassionate like him. He's very flexible, no?"
And in a society where family counts above all, many Somalis say they feel they know the candidate from his father, starting from the familiar voice and face.
"He looks very much like his father," said Muhammad Hassan Guled, 56, a former port manager who was holding the wedding for his son. "And his father left him a big reputation. Now the world is expecting much from him."
Mr. Bush also has support from Somalia's most famous son, Hussein Aidid. His father, Gen. Muhammad Farah Aidid, was one of Mogadishu's most notorious warlords until his death in a street battle in 1996. The elder Mr. Aidid was, in fact, the man whom the American soldiers were trying to capture in October 1993, when the Black Hawk was downed.
The younger Mr. Aidid, 38, who lived for 17 years in the United States and fought as a United States Marine in the Persian Gulf war, returned to Somalia to take over his father's faction. He was a registered Republican in California -- who voted both for Bush and for Clinton in various races, he said -- and he had some advice for the younger Mr. Bush: "You can't be in his shoes. You have to have your own ideas."
The advice seemed heartfelt: Mr. Aidid has had much trouble of his own stepping out of the shadow of his father.

PUB-DATE: August 27, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2688 words

HEADLINE: Clearing the Decks for a Trade Pact's Riches

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD

DATELINE: VUNG TAU, Vietnam

 BODY:
TO explain why he is so excited about the new trade agreement with the United States, Pham Van Tuat clambered aboard the Xin Thu, his new 89-foot wooden fishing trawler, and gestured into its spacious holds. Lower American tariffs for Vietnamese seafood products in the United States, he explained, will mean more demand for tuna and squid. And that is where this $125,000 trawler comes in.
The Xin Thu, the largest of his nine boats, can travel 400 miles out to sea and bring back 200 tons of fish, Mr. Tuat said. To demonstrate how, he bundled his visitors down into the engine room. There, still bearing its maker's signature yellow paint, was something that makes many American executives here as excited as Mr. Tuat: a brand-new, $32,000, 480-horsepower Caterpillar engine.
"We'll be exporting to America soon," Mr. Tuat said triumphantly, hurrying his guests onto a skiff to beat the ebb tide back to shore. "I'm planning to build another boat like this one. But even bigger."
To a large extent, Mr. Tuat's plans are the fruits of seven years of toil by Anthony D. Salzman, an entrepreneur from New York. Mr. Salzman came to Hanoi from Japan in 1993, hoping to capitalize on that country's swelling investment in Vietnam. He wound up opening a dealership for Caterpillar, which was among the most vocal companies in urging the Clinton administration to lift the United States embargo that blocked trade for 19 years.
Mr. Salzman, 49, is now one of Vietnam's most prominent American residents, well known for his outspoken, unrelenting style. And he is just one of many American executives here who say a trade pact will unleash a tide of exports -- and lift his fortunes with it. After five years of talks, the United States and Vietnam signed the agreement on July 13, and it is expected to be ratified by Congress, though probably not this year.
Since President Clinton ended the embargo in 1994, the American commercial adventure in Vietnam has resembled its earlier military one, with optimism quickly bogged down in a quagmire of red tape, corruption and Communist recalcitrance. To skeptics, the new agreement is yet another capitulation: tariffs on Vietnamese goods would drop immediately, while Vietnamese tariffs and quotas on American products would fall only gradually, in some cases enduring as long as seven years.
But supporters here say the agreement represents a new, irrevocable commitment by Vietnam to open the country to global markets and to play by internationally accepted trade rules.
MOREOVER, as Vietnamese exports rise and foreign investment returns, executives like Mr. Salzman say, demand will also rise for American products, whether toothpaste or trucks and bulldozers.
"The impact is indirect," Mr. Salzman said. With rising export revenue, he predicted, "my electric business is going to grow, my marine-engine business is going to grow."
"And as everything else grows," he added, "the infrastructure business should grow, too."
Mr. Salzman foresees $1 billion in sales for his venture, V-Trac -- for Vietnam Tractor -- over the next 10 years if Vietnam carries through on its commitments. But he and other veterans of business here warn that change should not be expected overnight. With or without the trade accord, Vietnam is still a poor, Communist country, with an absence of legal, social and physical infrastructure that sent foreign investment inflows plummeting to about $1.5 billion a year in 1999 from roughly $3.3 billion in 1997.
At the same time, Vietnam is no longer a hostile, war-ravaged country. More than half the population is too young to have ever seen an American G.I. And Vietnam's other former adversaries, meanwhile, have moved back in. France was the top investor in the country last year, and Japan the top trading partner. The United States is still only Vietnam's seventh-largest foreign investor and trading partner.
"It can be a challenging market, but I think the potential is definitely here," said Michael R. Frisby, counselor for commercial affairs at the American Embassy in Hanoi and a Vietnam war veteran. "Companies should come and investigate this market, because with ratification of the treaty the potential in Vietnam will increase exponentially."
Vietnam is already rich in resources. It is the largest producer of black pepper and robusta coffee, which is used for instant blends. And it is the second-largest exporter of rice, after Thailand, and a key source of seafood, cashews and bauxite. Its workers earn high marks from foreign employers -- and not just for the low pay.
The country also has much potential as a consumer market. More than one-third of its 78 million people live in poverty, but some of its roughly 18 million urbanites are sitting on what bankers and economists estimate are billions of dollars in gold and other hidden savings, with perhaps $1 billion to $2 billion more coming in from relatives overseas every year. Many Vietnamese hoard their money to avoid income taxes, and because they do not trust banks.
Although American companies lack much market share here, their brands are easily recognized. When Coca-Cola returned in 1994, it found people still familiar with its logo. Offices in Vietnam at that time were still using old I.B.M. computers and keeping cool with rusting Carrier air-conditioners, all left behind when the United States pulled out nearly 20 years earlier.
THE first Caterpillar equipment arrived here before World War II, when Vietnam was still a French colony. More Cats, of course, came during the American military involvement.
Old Caterpillar tractors and bulldozers were still rumbling across the landscape in 1990, when Bruce St. John, then Caterpillar's representative in Bangkok, traveled to Vietnam to assess the prospects.
He learned that Vietnamese mechanics still knew how to service Caterpillar equipment. Given Vietnam's infrastructure needs, Mr. St. John, who served in the Army in Vietnam in 1970 and 1971, predicted a lucrative market for Caterpillar.
"It looked like a very attractive opportunity," said Mr. St. John, who now works at the same factory, in Mossville, Ill., where Mr. Tuat's engine was built.
In 1991, Mr. St. John testified before Congress about the embargo. Caterpillar's stance set off protests from groups that had been urging the United States to pressure Hanoi to find missing American soldiers.
Caterpillar executives argued that Vietnamese markets were falling to Japanese and European competitors and that more influence on the M.I.A. issue could be gained by trading with Vietnam. In 1993, Caterpillar opened its office in Hanoi.
Mr. Salzman took an unlikely road to Vietnam -- and to bulldozers. His father, Herbert, secured the family fortune in 1967 when he sold the company his own father founded, Standard Bag, to Boise Cascade. Herbert Salzman went on to serve four presidents in various positions at the State Department and started the agency that would become the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which guarantees American investments in third-world countries.
The younger Mr. Salzman studied at Yale University and the Duke University law school. After stints at American Express and Lehman Brothers, he chose to explore his entrepreneurial roots, a decision that took him to Portugal and Spain. Then he tried Asia, starting in 1992 with Japan, where his wife was born.
When his effort to crack Japan's closed markets did not succeed, Mr. Salzman and his wife moved to Vietnam. "Yen were pouring in," he recalled. "It meant that Vietnam was going to be an important Asian economy."
Hanoi was a long way from the Salzmans' apartment on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. When he and his wife called an exterminator to rid their new home of rats, Mr. Salzman said, a man showed up with a snake in a bag.
Efforts by the Communist government to keep tabs on the new capitalist arrivals were equally rustic. Mr. Salzman learned that his phones were tapped when he heard officials breathing over the line. Fax machines were illegal -- they were too hard to decipher.
Still, Mr. Salzman said he never felt any animosity as a citizen of Vietnam's former enemy. He set up the first American Chamber of Commerce in Hanoi and began prospecting for business ideas that would capitalize on Vietnam's obvious need for new infrastructure.
Mr. Salzman had just abandoned hopes of investing in a cellular telephone operator when he met Caterpillar's Hanoi representative, James Ferrara. Caterpillar was already fielding offers from its big distributors in Hong Kong, Indonesia, France and Canada to expand to Vietnam, Mr. Salzman said.
Mr. Salzman prevailed over the other bidders, he said, by appealing to the company's traditional preference for family-owned dealerships. In mid-1994, he set up V-Trac. A Caterpillar spokesman, Jeffrey S. Hawkinson, said Mr. Ferrara was not available to confirm Mr. Salzman's account.
While many Vietnamese knew the Caterpillar name, Mr. Salzman needed to spread the word that Cat was back. In 1995, he advertised a contest offering a $1,000 prize for the oldest working Caterpillar equipment in the country. The winning entry was a 1939 generator serving on a tugboat. The overwhelmed winner carried off his prize in two shopping bags filled with Vietnamese currency.
SELLING new equipment, however, was still difficult. The same year, V-Trac lost a $7 million contract to supply bulldozers and other heavy equipment to one of Vietnam's cement companies. Mr. Salzman blamed the Jackson-Vanik law, a cold-war statute aimed at Communist countries not allowing free emigration. The law prohibited trade financing to such countries by the Export-Import Bank or by OPIC, the agency started by Mr. Salzman's father. The Vietnamese cement contract went instead to Komatsu of Japan.
In 1998, President Clinton waived the Jackson-Vanik restrictions against Vietnam, and last year V-Trac won $2.3 million in financing from OPIC, the first deal the agency had made in Vietnam since the war. V-Trac now employs 140 people in seven offices around the country.
But financing is still difficult to obtain from risk-averse government agencies, Mr. Salzman complained. The Ex-Im Bank, for one, started operations in Vietnam in December, but has yet to finance a deal.
 In fact, the trade accord may be a bigger boon to other companies from other countries as they invest in Vietnam. Textile companies from Taiwan, for example, poured millions of dollars into Vietnam on the prospect of exporting to the United States with reduced tariffs. Now, a Taiwan trade official said, they are counting the minutes until the agreement is ratified by Congress.
BUT what is good for Taiwan textile companies in Vietnam may also be good for Caterpillar. Just north of Vung Tau, the Hualon Corporation of Taiwan has a factory that makes cloth and polyester yarn. When the plant opened in 1997, there was no electricity, so Hualon paid $15 million for three Caterpillar generators. Now it is planning to build a second plant next door, more than doubling its power needs.
Power is now available from the local utility, but Hualon's generators remain cheaper -- and more reliable. Back in Vung Tau at the Technical Raw Material Trading & Supplying Company, Phan Doan Hung showed off a new, $400 million shoe factory left dormant for a day by a power failure; its 2,200 employees had to stay at home.
Mr. Hung and the companies in Europe, Korea and Taiwan that buy his shoes said the trade agreement would mean more business for his factory. "We'd like to export our product directly to America," he added. "That way we can earn a bigger profit."
To ensure that he has the power he needs to meet his contract deadlines, Mr. Hung is buying a $61,000 Caterpillar generator. "Please come soon," he said to a visiting V-Trac executive. "You see what it's like today. I worry, worry, worry."
Ford Vietnam, a joint venture between Ford Motor and a Vietnamese partner, also uses Caterpillar generators to power its $102 million factory near Hanoi. Business is slow: Ford makes only 100 of the 14,000 cars that the factory could produce each month. Company executives are optimistic that the trade agreement will change that.
"The agreement makes me feel even more confident because of the way it makes other businesses grow," said Deborah Aronson, general director of Ford Vietnam. "There's a significant retail population that is looking to demonstrate its success."
Chronic power failures, however, underscore Vietnam's limitations as a market and investment. Though the economy is regaining speed, unprofitable state-owned businesses drain government coffers, while banks, like so many elsewhere in Asia, are paralyzed by bad loans. Income tax rates are so high that it is sometimes cheaper for foreign companies to hire expatriates than to pay Vietnamese a competitive after-tax wage.
The agreement also leaves unresolved a litany of structural problems, executives say. Vietnam is only beginning to experiment with capital markets; it recently opened a stock market, but regulations still hobble businesses' ability to raise money. Vietnam is trying to overhaul these rules, but its bureaucracy is still Byzantine, its licensing rules unclear, and its foreclosure and bankruptcy laws inadequate. Courts are not independent; they answer to the Communist Party.
And some executives here do not share Mr. Salzman's faith that the trade pact will permeate the economy. Ronald R. Kiel, 3M's managing director in Vietnam, agrees that the accord is essential for Vietnam's future but says the country's goods are too poor and its infrastructure too decrepit. "I don't think you're going to see an explosion of industrial output because the country isn't geared up for it," Mr. Kiel said.
Others have more faith. "I think that Vietnam does have the potential for explosive economic growth, more so than most countries in Asia," said Wesley Grove, the chief representative of Chase Manhattan Bank in Ho Chi Minh City.
Gerard Letellier is another believer. Mr. Letellier is chief executive of Morning Star Cement, a $400 million joint venture of the Swiss cement giant Holderbank Financiere Glarus and Vietnam National Cement.
Booming demand for cement to build homes has sent Morning Star's production soaring from 400,000 tons in 1998 to one million tons last year. The trade agreement, Mr. Letellier predicted, "will open the Vietnamese market to U.S. investors, and this means new infrastucture."
"And this is good," he added, "for the cement business." (There is no need to guess whose equipment Morning Star uses to excavate the limestone to make that cement.)
CATERPILLAR'S dividend doesn't end at the quarry. Increased shipping traffic is also helping the Bien Dong Shipyard south of Ho Chi Minh City. Bien Dong's workers are putting finishing touches on a new $70,000 ferry; inside it is a $30,000 Caterpillar engine. "After this one's done, we're building another for the same purpose but with a 400-horsepower Caterpillar engine," said Phan Ngoc Chuc, Bien Dong's director.
Mr. Chuc is investing $200,000 and hiring 20 new workers to double the shipyard's production and to take advantage of what he thinks will be a boom in demand for another kind of vessel. Dwindling catches and environmental concerns have prompted Vietnam to push its fishing fleet farther out to sea, requiring larger, more powerful boats. Such big boats are more economical when they remain at sea, so Mr. Chuc foresees building other boats to transport their catch to shore.
Back in Vung Tau, Mr. Tuat remembers that when he was a boy in the 1950's, he had to go only about a mile out to catch all the fish he needed. Bigger boats won't be enough to compete in the American market now, he realizes. He and other fishermen will need to improve the quality of their product, he says, investing in more ice and freezers that will burn more fuel.
That may help Caterpillar sell bigger engines in Vienam. But it could help Mr. Tuat, too. One of his sons, it so happens, sells ice. The other sells fuel.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1159 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Tune In, Turn Out, Turn Off;
The Mystery of Nonvoters and Whether They Matter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
WHAT if they gave an election and everyone came?
There would be profound surprise, for one thing. Turnout in the last three American presidential elections has hovered at around half of the nation's voting-age population, which has prompted a good deal of hand-wringing. 
 It's obvious that if everyone eligible voted this November, the number of ballots cast would roughly double. But would those 100 million or so additional votes change the outcome for the main contenders, George W. Bush and Al Gore?
The answer is: maybe yes, maybe no.
First, the maybe yes. If the race is close, then any usual nonvoters who turn out have the potential to decide the outcome. And races that go down to the wire typically generate higher turnout, because of the uncertainty, and heightened competition. After Labor Day, as each party's post-convention bounce in the polls levels off, voter surveys will give the first good indication of how close the 2000 election is likely to be.
Now, the maybe no. It may be that this year's likely nonvoters differ so much in how they are lining up behind the candidates that if they voted, a different candidate would be elected. But that would be in contrast to every election since 1988. A statistical analysis of those three elections by The New York Times suggests that if nonvoters had voted, only the margin of victory would have changed, not the victor.
The statistics say that if the "votes" of nonvoters had been counted, George Bush would have increased his margin of success over Michael Dukakis in 1988; there would have been no change in the margin of Bill Clinton's win in 1992, and his margin would have increased to a landslide in 1996.
The similarities of the preferences of voters and nonvoters suggest that in modern campaigns, with saturating news coverage and endless commercials driving home candidates' positions, voters and nonvoters may reach similar conclusions and take sides in roughly similar proportions.
Of course, assessing opinions is an inexact science. And there's much more data to go on for voters than for nonvoters.
The reactions and tentative conclusions being formed by likely voters are measured by many polls and also widely broadcast and published. The only way to know nonvoters' preferences is through the infrequent public opinion polls -- with their inherent degrees of error in sampling and measurement -- that bother to address them. And there are other gray areas. Nonvoters who become voters may be motivated by something that also changed their minds.
The New York Times/CBS News polls, conducted just before Election Day in each of the last three presidential races, were designed to determine whether usual voters and usual nonvoters agreed, disagreed slightly or disagreed strongly in their candidate preferences.
In 1988, voters preferred Mr. Bush by 8 percentage points. Nonvoters that year also preferred Mr. Bush over Mr. Dukakis, but by 16 percentage points. If everyone had turned out to vote, Mr. Bush's margin over Mr. Dukakis would have been somewhat larger than it was. Same winner, but bigger.
Voters and nonvoters each favored Bill Clinton over President Bush in 1992, and by the same margin, 6 percentage points. Had everyone voted that year, there would have been the same winner and the same victory margin. But Ross Perot would have gained an additional 2 percentage points over the 19 percent he actually received.
In 1996, by contrast, voters and nonvoters held preferences that differed strongly. Bill Clinton beat Bob Dole by 8 percentage points, but among nonvoters, Mr. Clinton was the overwhelming choice. If everyone had voted, it would have been a 24-point Clinton blowout. (In 1976, Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter ran a close race, but nonvoters were not polled.)
The seeming pattern in these three elections -- that with everyone voting the winner would have remained the same in each case, with an enlarged victory margin in two of the three cases -- provides ammunition for several arguments.
It shows that nonvoters are not invariably more pro-Democratic than voters, as stereotypes suggest. Nonvoters were more pro-Bush than voters in 1988, more pro-Clinton in 1996 and indistinguishable in their preferences in 1992.
Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania and author of "Everything You Think You Know About Politics . . . And Why You're Wrong" (Basic Books), said that the finding of few big differences in candidate preferences of voters and nonvoters conforms to "the standard finding of political scientists." But she said she was still surprised because "nonvoters, tending to have lower socio-economic status, might be expected to be more Democratic."
But does the voter/nonvoter pattern also suggest that it doesn't matter that nonvoters stay home?
Only if the sole purpose of voting is to elect someone. But citizens are urged to participate in politics not only to elect people, but also, perhaps even primarily, for their own good. Dennis F. Thompson, Alfred North Whitehead professor of political philosophy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, has argued in his book "The Democratic Citizen" (Cambridge University Press) that participation can help develop citizens' awareness, knowledge and self-realization.
Moreover, the three polls measured only how voters and nonvoters reacted to the candidates, issues, and appeals in the campaigns that were actually waged in those election years. They cannot show what public reactions might have been if the candidates, issues and messages had been different. And if everyone voted, those might become quite different.
Nonvoters tend to be younger, less well off in income and education, less partisan, less politically involved and more alienated from the system. If parties and candidates actually expected everyone to vote, they might find themselves having to revise their strategies, raising quite different issues.
Campaigns might revolve as much around health care for poor children, child care for working mothers, and job training and college tuition for working-class and lower-middle-class youths, as they do now around prescription drugs for the elderly and tax cuts for the affluent.
In 1996, turnout was 49 percent of the voting-age population, defined as United States residents 18 or older. In 1992 it was 55 percent. In 1988, despite earnest get-out-the-vote drives, it was 50 percent. But the category includes some people who are legally ineligible to vote, like noncitizens, felons and those who have not yet met local residency requirements, so actual turnout would have been a bit higher in each case.
One hundred percent turnout may always be a fantasy, practically speaking. But, if political participation brings civic awareness, then a higher voting rate may still be a desirable goal, even if it does not change the outcome of elections.
