HEADLINE: Feeling Powerless In a World Of Greater Choice;
Consumers Grow More Anxious As They Are Cut Loose In Electricity's New Free Market

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
Over the last 20 years, a dogma has taken root in America that says people would be happier and better off if they were all continually shopping for the best deals. Consumers, according to this theory, should be empowered and freed from the old business monopolies and the dictates of fussy bureaucrats.
So airlines were deregulated, and telephone service, and then the Internet arrived, giving people the ability to choose from 10 different sellers of the same merchandise. The bull market on Wall Street brought 5,000 mutual funds begging for attention. Having more choices became an end in itself. 
 But for millions of people, especially in New York and California, the doctrine of the sovereign consumer has come into question this summer around a commodity that most had taken completely for granted: electricity. A recently deregulated energy market, which was supposed to increase choices and reduce prices, has, for most residents, done nothing of the kind. Many community leaders and politicians, calling for investigations and caps on rising electricity bills -- up 30 percent to 40 percent from those of last August in many areas -- have denounced energy deregulation as either a failure or a fraud.
Some social scientists say that the anxiety over energy is exposing something even deeper in the human wiring. At a time when protesters have railed in Seattle and Washington against chain stores and global branding, and prominent social critics have denounced the intrusion of endless choice into every corner of life -- a phenomenon that Barry Schwartz, a psychologist at Swarthmore College, calls "the tyranny of freedom" -- the public's worries about electricity may say more about human nature than about kilowatts.
Perhaps, this alternative theory says, there is a point at which people no longer wish to be autonomous, rational consumers at all. Maybe they would just as soon delegate their decisions regarding some transactions, as they did when Consolidated Edison was the only game in town and government was assigned to make sure that the company played by the rules. Maybe when it comes to electricity, a mysterious and dangerous thing that is also the foundation of modern living, Americans are just a little afraid to be alone.
"In the past we trusted that state regulators who were appointed by our elected officials were watching out for us, which may or may not have been true," said Edward A. Smeloff, a former utility industry official who runs a research group on electricity at Pace University. "The new model is, 'Figure it out for yourself.' "
Some economists and energy industry experts say the sense of powerlessness and confusion that many people feel is perhaps as much a source of anxiety and anger as higher electricity bills. The players have all changed and no one seems to be in charge.
The old Brooklyn Union Gas Company, for example, still remembered by many New York residents for the fuzzy, feel-good images of its advertising, has become the cool and metallic-sounding KeySpan Energy. The old Con Ed, on the other hand, was like a crotchety grandfather who sometimes had to be prodded and yelled at, but who nonetheless presided over the system.
The company now throws up its hands and says it is not responsible for recent price increases; Con Ed's wires are simply a delivery mechanism for the unregulated corporations that own generating plants, Con Ed's chairman said at a recent hearing at City Hall.
Opinion poll takers say anxiety about deregulation may also have something to do with a contradiction in the American psyche that they say has opened up in recent years, a contradiction about what people really want. Surveys conducted by Yankelovich Partners, a research and consulting firm based in Norwalk, Conn., have said, for example, that a majority of people want more control over the details of their lives, but a majority also want to simplify their lives, a result that Barbara R. Caplan, a partner at the firm, has called "the paradox of our time."
Deregulated energy arrived right in the middle of those conflicting goals; because only a handful of energy competitors have been attracted to the New York market, most people still do not have much choice in their electricity, and yet it all seems more complicated than ever, as well as more expensive.
Another factor, some researchers say, may be a result of timing. People have had experience with deregulation, and they have seen that it did not always unfold to their benefit. The hub-and-spoke system developed by the airline industry, for example, has given airlines near-monopoly power at many airports around the country, resulting in less competition, not more. Consumers have also seen that although tools like the Internet have made buyers more powerful in getting good prices, corporations on the other side of the transaction have become more powerful, too, in gathering information about them.
"Years ago, you went into an auto dealership and had to negotiate to buy a car, but only the corporate side had knowledge of what the real costs were," said Mark L. Gillenson, a professor of management information systems at the University of Memphis. "Now you go into the Internet, and lots of places will give you that information for free." On the other hand, Professor Gillenson said, the data that corporations are collecting about people are creating what the old car dealer could never have imagined: knowledge about what people want before they even ask.
Lurking behind all those forces, some psychologists say, is the growing sense that people are simply being asked to decide too much. Economic deregulation has accompanied what may be called social deregulation, as issues that were not even considered decisions in the past have become issues of conscious choice: whether to get married and have children, or how to express oneself sexually, as gay, straight or somewhere in between.
And the more choices there are, the more it can seem possible to achieve an ideal result in every case, leading to a doomed, treadmill kind of behavior often seen in people who continually change their long-distance telephone service as they endlessly seek an incremental price advantage.
"Over what domains in life are you supposed to have control?" said Professor Schwartz, the Swarthmore College psychologist. "Nobody gets depressed when you can't control the weather, and years ago nobody got depressed because they couldn't control your telecommunications or electricity either, because those things couldn't be controlled," he said. "But now you can, or you're told that you can, and so you're going to be continually frustrated."
And electricity is also just different. Unlike a telephone call, or an airline ticket, nobody ever really wants to buy electricity itself -- rather, people buy its expression and result: a cold beer in the fridge, a light to read by. By the standards of American marketing, it is barely a product at all.
"People want to make choices about clothes and restaurants and what houses they live in, but a lot of us would rather not be bothered with having to make a choice about electricity," said Wendy Kaminer, a public policy fellow at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study in Cambridge, Mass. "It's not a desire to be disempowered," Ms. Kaminer added. "It's a desire not to be bothered."
Finally, some experts think that the long bull market for stocks, in which share prices mostly just go up, has made people forget a fundamental truth about how markets work: they are genuinely fair only over the long run, while at any given time, there are likely to be as many losers as winners.
"Deregulation and privatization were sold implicitly on the assumption that everybody can win from this, but I'm hard pressed to find an example in the real world where that has happened," said Willis Emmons, a professor in the strategy, public policy and ethics department at Georgetown University's business school. Right now, Professor Emmons added, "maybe somebody is winning, but it isn't the consumer."

HEADLINE: Sir Lynden Pindling, 70, Prime Minister Who Led Bahamas to Independence

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
Sir Lynden O. Pindling, the prime minister of the Bahamas for 25 years whose reputation and relationship with the United States were marred by unresolved accusations of protecting drug traffickers, died yesterday at his home in Nassau. He was 70.
The cause was prostate cancer, aides said in a statement. 
 Mr. Pindling was the prime minister from 1967 to 1992, leading the Bahamas through tremendous change, including the transition from a British colony to independence in 1973. He was defeated in the 1992 election by the current prime minister, Hubert Ingraham. At the time of his defeat, Mr. Pindling had been in office longer than any leader in the Western Hemisphere except Fidel Castro of Cuba.
Yesterday, as radio and television stations in the Bahamas broadcast tributes to Mr. Pindling, Mr. Ingraham called him "a giant of our times," according to The Associated Press.
Left unmentioned, however, were allegations involving Mr. Pindling in the 1980's that political observers in the Bahamas say contributed to his defeat. He was accused of covering up for drug traffickers and of taking bribes as the chairman of the nation's Hotel Commission. A Bahamian government commission was unable to substantiate any of the claims, but the allegations had pronounced political ramifications.
Mr. Pindling remained a member of the House of Assembly until 1997, when he resigned after 41 years in that legislative body. At the time, he said he was "less than perfect," but added that "when all I did for good is put in the balance against all I did for ill or failed to do at all, I hope that future generations will not find me sorely wanting."
In 1953, Mr. Pindling helped found the Progressive Liberal Party, a political organization dedicated to overthrowing the mostly white colonial-run United Bahamian Party. Some supporters called him the "black Moses."
When Mr. Pindling was first elected prime minister in 1967, he ended a tradition of white minority rule that had been in place for centuries. He devoted his first term in office to securing independence from Britain and used that prestige to win five more elections.
Mr. Pindling spent much of his time working to improve the reputation of his country, but became vulnerable to charges of corruption in 1984, when an official commission set up to investigate drug trafficking in the Bahamas found wide evidence of official corruption in his cabinet and the Bahamian police. The commission eventually cleared Mr. Pindling of any wrongdoing, but said that he and his wife had at least $3.5 million in bank deposits that could not be accounted for.
At the 1987 trial of Carlos Lehder, a founder of the Medellin cocaine cartel in Colombia, prosecutors charged that Mr. Lehder and other drug traffickers had paid at least $5 million to Mr. Pindling for permission to use the Bahamas as a shipment point for cocaine and marijuana bound for the United States.
Several drug smugglers testified that they had made such payments directly to Mr. Pindling. The prime minister denied the accusations. After Mr. Lehder's conviction, the United States sought to confiscate his holdings in the Bahamas, but was rebuffed by Mr. Pindling. He continued to quarrel with the United States until his 1992 defeat.
By that year, though, a decline in the economy in the late 1980's and early 1990's had become the decisive factor for many voters. Tourism was by far the largest source of employment and revenue in the nation of more than 700 islands, and the Bahamas was finding it difficult to compete with other vacation destinations.
To many young voters, Mr. Pindling was seen not as a father of their country, but as an international pariah and leader who could not get them jobs.
Mr. Pindling is survived by his wife, Lady Marguerite; two sons, Obafemi, 40, and Leslie, 39; two daughters, Michelle Sands, 38, and Monique Johnson, 34; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: After the Mall: Luring Shoppers Back Downtown

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
In downtown New Rochelle, in Westchester County, a decaying mall was replaced by an elaborate $194 million entertainment complex that is meant to evoke an idealized image of city life.
In downtown Hempstead village, on Long Island, a shopping center with a Home Depot is nearing completion on the former site of an Abraham & Straus department store. 
 And in downtown Englewood, N.J., officials have been working block by block to revive a section of a shopping strip that only recently was scarred by drug dealing and abandoned buildings.
All over the region -- and throughout the country -- suburban communities are struggling to reverse a decline that began decades ago as shoppers fled the central business districts for the outlying malls, leaving behind deserted commercial streets that cast a pall on the surrounding residential neighborhoods.
These days, the robust economy, a growing distaste for suburban sprawl and increasing demands on people's time are helping to fuel a renewed focus on suburban downtowns. Suburban malls are not exactly a thing of the past, but many people find them a nuisance to get in and out of, especially for smaller errands.
"Neighborhood shopping has taken a huge jump," said Philip H. Kowalcyzk, a managing partner at Kurt Salmon Associates, a retail consulting firm in New York. "It's all about the convenience factor."
At the same time, wealthier suburbs are becoming less receptive to so-called big-box stores, like Home Depot and Costco, forcing retailers to look for alternatives.
Often, they are finding them on the edge of cities, in the older suburbs, which long ago ceased being a refuge from urban problems and now tend to look much more like the cities themselves, racially and socioeconomically.
"The relentless sprawl of the 90's, and the resulting congestion, has made the outer areas more hostile to development," said James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "The developers are getting a warmer welcome in urban communities."
National retailers are also beginning to recognize the buying power of minority neighborhoods, and are less afraid to venture into them.
Seizing on these trends, several older suburban communities in the New York region have devised plans for increasing their tax base and resuscitating their downtowns. Some, like New Rochelle and Mount Vernon, also in Westchester County, hope that entertainment will be a magnet. Others, like Englewood, have adopted a more gradual, comprehensive approach. And still others, like Hempstead and Port Chester, in Westchester County, are counting on big-box development.
Some urban planners have voiced skepticism about the larger projects, saying that they are not likely to be the magic bullet that turns around a downtown, especially if the people who use them can avoid the downtown streets. "Generally, the big single project dropping out of the sky won't do it," said Bob Yaro, the executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit civic group serving New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Englewood offers a cautionary tale. In the early 1990's, the city approved plans for a shopping mall behind West Palisade Avenue, a stretch of its downtown that is literally on the other side of the tracks from the more prosperous east side. The mall created jobs, but it did not lead to more pedestrian traffic on West Palisade, apparently because it was self-contained, with parking right in front of the stores. "It was a peninsula," said Peter Beronio, the city's director of economic development.
Since then, Englewood has rethought its strategy for revitalizing West Palisade and is now considered a model for other small cities, said Jef R. Buehler, the acting state coordinator of Main Street New Jersey, an economic development program run by the State Department of Community Affairs.
It is too early to know whether New Roc City, New Rochelle's new entertainment complex, will escape the fate of other large projects that could not deliver on their promises.
Built in part with public money -- including $25 million from the city for the construction of a garage -- New Roc City straddles an immaculate cobblestone street and has a facade inspired by New York of the 1920's. The new complex, which replaced a shopping mall abandoned by Macy's in 1992, includes an 18-screen theater, two skating rinks, a video game room, an amusement ride called the Space Shot, two restaurants and a Super Stop and Shop market.
Although business has been light on weekdays, New Roc City draws crowds on weekends. Regal Cinemas, the nation's largest movie house chain, says its theater at New Roc City is one of the company's top 10 performers. Robert M. Greene, one of the developers, said about 70,000 people visited the center each week, exceeding his projections.
Angela North, a Pelham, N.Y., resident who works on Wall Street, goes to New Roc several times a week with her children. "I think it's great," she said. "And you can't complain about the security. The kids aren't going to cause any problems." The complex has a police substation and a highly visible security office.
But a number of storefronts near the complex are empty, and several downtown business owners said New Roc had yet to bring them more customers. "The effect that everybody is looking for is not there yet," said Addison Cornelius, the owner of Dominic's, a men's clothing store that has been in New Rochelle since 1966. "Everybody thought it would happen overnight. That's not realistic."
Not long ago, New Rochelle officials were reminded that urban redevelopment is more often than not a Sisyphean endeavor. R.E.I., which sells outdoor gear and clothing and is one of Main Street's few upscale retailers, said it would close its 11-year-old store next June because of disappointing sales.
And New Roc itself has had setbacks. The project includes 92 units of office space, but they have not been rented, and the developers have asked to be allowed to convert them into apartments. City officials would have preferred downtown to have both residents and hundreds of new office workers, who would make use of shops and restaurants during the day, said Michael D. Ritchie, the city's commissioner of development.
Family Golf Centers, the parent company of Sports Plus, the operator of the center's skating rinks and video arcades, filed for bankruptcy protection in May. But Mr. Greene, the developer, said Family Golf's problems were not hurting New Roc City.
Even before it opened, however, New Roc had spurred other development in downtown New Rochelle. Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust, is building 1,000 market-rate rental apartments near the train station -- the first housing of this type in downtown New Rochelle since World War II. Fred Harris, a vice president of Avalon Bay, said the project would not have gone forward without New Roc City.
City officials say the new apartments will have a bigger impact on downtown than New Roc City because they will attract young professionals who have been priced out of the New York City housing market.
Whether New Roc proves successful, planners like the fact that it is surrounded by city sidewalks, not cut off from downtown by a large parking lot. "New Roc City is a great start," said Elliott D. Sclar, the director of the urban planning program at Columbia University. "It's the antithesis of putting a Home Depot in the middle of town."
Other suburban cities are also looking at entertainment as a draw. In densely packed Mount Vernon, Mayor Ernest D. Davis, an architect by training, dreams of creating space for a sports arena and hotel by building a platform over the railroad tracks that run through the center of town. He said the plan was being studied.
Mayor Davis is opposed to putting superstores in the center of downtown. But other communities are hoping that the big boxes will jump-start downtown redevelopment.
A superstore does not necessarily spell the death of mom-and-pop businesses, said N. David Milder, the president of Danth Inc., a consulting company in Queens that helped Englewood formulate its downtown revitalization strategy. But whether the smaller stores can benefit from increased traffic may hinge on whether the rest of downtown is visible and easily accessible to the superstore's customers, he said.
Suburban officials also say they are trying to persuade independent merchants to compete more effectively by staying open later to accommodate commuters or by improving their displays.
In Hempstead, where two-thirds of the population is black or Hispanic, it was considered a coup when the village was able to attract Home Depot to the middle of town, said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. But the Home Depot, the anchor for a shopping center that will also contain an Old Navy clothing store and a supermarket, is behind a parking lot with spaces for 1,300 cars. Customers never have to set foot downtown.
Mayor James A. Garner, however, said the stores near the new shopping center were benefiting from the increased traffic. "It's brought a lot of business in," he said.
In Port Chester, plans for a development along the Byram River drew vehement protests and charges of racism because about 170 homes and businesses, many of them belonging to Hispanics, were relocated to make way for the project, which will include a Costco warehouse store and a Super Stop and Shop .
Officials say the shopping center will be an integral part of the business district, with the stores designed to resemble boutiques. "It will be a mall turned inside out," Mayor Christine Korff said. "The store entrances will face the sidewalks." The project was also supposed to include a Loews Cineplex, but the company recently shelved plans to come to Port Chester.
Port Chester's major asset is its numerous ethnic restaurants, which attract patrons from other parts of Westchester County and southern Connecticut. Joyce M. Lannert, the commissioner of planning for Westchester County, said she expected restaurants to benefit from the project. "Once people go shopping and have a parking space, they might as well try one of the fun restaurants," she said.
But some critics of the plan question whether people shopping at Costco for perishable goods will spend any of their time on downtown streets. Jennifer Kohn, an owner of Kneaded Bread, a two-year-old bakery on Main Street, said she welcomed the increased traffic but wondered whether the new stores would fit in with the restaurants. "Maybe if they put in an artsy theater, it would really go with the mood of the town," she said. "If you want to elevate the town, I don't think this is the way to do it."
Most experts in the so-called new urbanism say reviving a downtown is a painstaking process. "The successful examples," said Mr. Yaro of the Regional Plan Association, "are the ones that developed in a more organic way, that were built around the historic fabric of the town. These things don't happen right away. It takes a vision that is broadly shared and implemented over a decade or more."

HEADLINE: An Open Border With Mexico?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Visas for Mexican Workers" (editorial, Aug. 24), you qualify the ideas of Vicente Fox, Mexico's president-elect, regarding free labor movement across the open border as "not practical anytime soon."
Such skepticism might derive from a resistance to recognize the contribution of Mexican immigrants to the United States economy. As a 1994 Department of Labor report concludes: 
 "In effect, migrant workers, so necessary for the success of the labor-intensive U.S. agricultural system, subsidize that very system with their own and their families' indigence. The system functions to transfer costs to workers who are left with income so marginal that, for the most part, only newcomers and those with no other options are willing to work on our nation's farms."
If you were to give credence to these findings, Mr. Fox's ideas would not be as premature as you suggest.
JORGE A. BUSTAMANTE
Notre Dame, Ind., Aug. 24, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of sociology at the University of Notre Dame.

HEADLINE: Minor League Ball in Queens: So Far, Everything but Crowds

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

 BODY:
Just before 7 p.m. Friday, George Perez, right-handed pitcher for the Queens Kings, a minor-league baseball team playing in what was, until recently, an exclusively major-league town, strolled into the team's ballpark looking a little forlorn.
He was itching to play, but by now he had to wonder: how many fans would be watching? 
 "The attendance has been kind of poor," Mr. Perez said before heading for the dugout. "But we're new and we didn't know what to expect. We came ready to play, and whatever happens, happens."
As it turned out, Friday night's game, a 9-4 win over the Pittsfield Mets, drew a spirited crowd of 1,390, a respectable turnout for a first-year team with a record of 38-26 that has struggled to attract fans.
Spectators were clustered in groups across the team's temporary 3,500-seat stadium, on the campus of St. John's University in a residential section of Jamaica, Queens. Still, there were rows of empty stands, and the parking lot was less than half full.
"You wish there was a better environment fan-wise," said Frank Insalco, a city police officer who lives in Queens and attended his first minor-league game Friday with his son and daughter. "But I make my own fun, and at this level, it's pure baseball. You don't need that Shea Stadium, Yankee Stadium spectacle. You're here to watch baseball."
Attendance, as low as 600 fans on some nights, has hovered at an average of 930, ranking the team last in attendance among the 14 Class A clubs in the New York-Penn League, according to the latest figures from the Minor League Baseball Association.
(The Staten Island Yankees, a club in the same league as the Kings that started its first season last year, has drawn more fans; crowds have averaged 2,800 so far this season.)
The sparse attendance in Queens came on the same week that the city broke ground on a 6,500-seat ballpark in Coney Island for a minor-league Mets franchise that next season will replace the Queens Kings, now an affiliate of the Toronto Blue Jays. The Pittsfield Mets franchise will move to Brooklyn, and the Queens Kings will no longer exist.
The Coney Island stadium is expected to cost the city $39 million and is fiercely opposed by the Brooklyn borough president, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has defended it and a $71 million minor-league ballpark under construction on Staten Island, saying they will help the economy of the two boroughs.
City officials and members of the Queens Kings insist that the low turnout at St. John's is not an indication of the city's appetite for minor-league baseball. At the Coney Island groundbreaking, Mr. Giuliani said that once the Mets farm team had a home in the city, rivalry between it and the Staten Island Yankees would "fuel attendance."
"The possibility of watching future Mets stars will appeal to the people of the city of New York," said Steve Cohen, general manager of the Kings.
The Kings' season began with a series of problems, the biggest of them involving finding a field. At first, the city planned to build a temporary ballpark in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, but a lawsuit and political opposition thwarted that idea. The city then turned to St. John's, but residents and civic groups in the neighborhood also sued to block the stadium.
The Queens lawsuit is still pending, but the case is probably moot with plans for the Coney Island stadium well under way. And with attendance lower than expected, residents' worst fears -- traffic and noise overrunning the quiet nearby neighborhood of Jamaica Estates -- were not realized. The lights and loudspeaker from the stadium have annoyed residents, but life around the stadium on game nights has been a lot quieter than people expected, several residents said.
"Thankfully, for whatever reason, the team hasn't drawn well," said Barry Weinberg, a dentist who lives near the stadium and is chairman of the Jamaica Estates Association.
He added, "What could have happened could have been a complete disaster."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 2, 2000, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about low attendance at minor league baseball games in Queens and an article on Aug. 23 about opposition to a Coney Island ballpark referred imprecisely to the cost of a minor league stadium under construction on Staten Island. According to the city's budget for the project, the construction of the stadium, the land purchase and the architectural, engineering and management fees are expected to add up to $53.2 million. Other features, including an esplanade and other site enhancements, put the combined cost for the project above $71 million; that is not the cost for the stadium itself.

HEADLINE: As Mideast Talks of Peace, Soft Voice Urges War

BYLINE: By John F. Burns

DATELINE: GAZA, Aug. 24

 BODY:
As Israel and the Palestinians circle each other in a wary and increasingly fractious quest for a final peace agreement, the spotlight only rarely settles these days on a small, wizened, straggly bearded man in a wheelchair whose antagonism to Israel could one day unsettle or even destroy any deal that establishes a Palestinian state pledged to coexistence with Israel.
 At first glance, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of the Islamic Resistance Movement, or Hamas, seems an improbable enemy for a peace that would aim at resolving one of the world's most protracted and bitter conflicts. Until he speaks, sketching a future of unremitting warfare until Israel is wiped from the map, there is little about him to suggest that he leads an organization that the United States lists as one of the world's most dangerous, if currently quiescent, terror groups. 
 At 64, Sheik Yassin -- the title is one given in Islam to a man revered for his piety -- is emaciated by the paralysis he suffered in a teenage accident on a Gaza beach. His hearing is deeply impaired by infections he blames on the 10 years he spent in Israeli prisons before his release in October 1997. He dresses in the all-white of an Islamic holy man, and speaks in such a tiny voice that even aides have to lean close to understand what he is saying.
 But what he says, and his ability to turn words into action, could hardly be more important to the long-term prospects for Middle East peace. Even if Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, overcome deep differences over Jerusalem and other issues that confounded attempts to reach a peace pact at last month's Camp David summit meeting, Sheik Yassin and the Islamic resistance could remain the wild card of regional politics, their unreconciled hatred for Israel a threat to destabilize peace. The words have hardly changed, not since Sheik Yassin, responding to the new mood of defiance represented by the street uprising among Palestinians known as the intifada, emerged from decades of Islamic devotions to found Hamas in 1987. "I believe completely that Israel will vanish, and that we Palestinians will recover the lands and homes that were stolen from us in 1948," he said. Extrapolating from predictions of disaster for the Jews he says he has drawn from inferences in the Koran, he added: "I've said it before, I'll say it again, the year 2027 will see the end of the state of Israel."
But whether this is the vow of a zealot whose time has passed, of an embittered man who lost his family's lands in a village, Al-Jura, that was on the Mediterranean coast near what is now the Israeli town of Ashkelon in 1948, or the resolve of a charismatic leader with a charter that will one day plunge the region into a renewed round of bombings and assassinations, may depend on how the eddying forces of Palestinian politics resolve.
 As part of the 1993 Oslo accords that began the peace effort, Mr. Arafat pledged to help uproot Palestinian terrorism, but his record has been mixed. No outsider can really know whether Mr. Arafat and Sheik Yassin are irreconcilable adversaries, the good-cop-bad-cop act of Palestinian politics, or as Israeli intelligence officials believe, a complex and shifting amalgam of both.
 In an extended interview at his office on the Gaza beachfront, ended only by the muezzin's call to prayfrom a local mosque, the signals were conflicting.
 On one hand, Sheik Yassin complained vigorously that Mr. Arafat was holding about 300 activists from Hamas and an associated group, Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, in jail, in addition to 1,500 others who are prisoners of the Israelis. He also spoke of the 10 weeks he spent under house arrest in Gaza in 1998, under Mr. Arafat's orders, after an abortive Hamas attempt to blow up a school bus near the Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom in Gaza.
 Sheik Yassin said Mr. Arafat's intelligence apparatus had voided 175 separate attacks against Israeli targets that had been planned by Hamas's military wing, the Ezzadin al-Qassem Brigade, in recent years. This, he implied, explained why there had been few attacks in Israel and around the Jewish settlements in Gaza and the West Bank since the chaotic years from 1994 to 1996, when a spate of suicide bombings and kidnappings by Hamas and Islamic Jihad killed scores of Israelis. At that time, Mr. Arafat was just beginning to assert his authority in the first blocks of territory ceded to the Palestinians under the Oslo accords.
 Against this, there was much to suggest that Sheik Yassin and Mr. Arafat recognize that they need each other. Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority recently permitted Hamas to set up its Gaza headquarters only a few hundred yards down Gaza's beachfront road from Mr. Arafat's "presidential" offices. And much about the new Hamas offices suggests that it has no need to pretend it lives in the shadows.
 The simple offices are sandwiched between the Dolphin bar and the Al-Jojo fishing tackle shop. The prayer room used by Sheik Yassin has an open portal looking out over the pounding Mediterranean surf, and there are no armed guards outside. When Sheik Yassin leaves, he travels in an expensive Range Rover, adapted to take the Islamic leader's wheelchair, which the sheik's aides said was given to him by Mr. Arafat.
 When Sheik Yassin was asked when he last met Mr. Arafat, he said he had invited him to dinner at his Gaza home three months ago. "Of course, we talked politics," he said. "Politics is our bread and water."
 Personally, he said he considered Mr. Arafat brave, if misguided. "He has tried to restore our rights, but if he can't, he should step aside and allow others to try," Sheik Yassin said. "If he recognizes the state of Israel, he will have given away our rights to our 1948 lands, and he will have gone from leading our resistance to defending our enemy."
 At this point, Sheik Yassin's words turned menacing, at least for Mr. Arafat, suggesting another reason why Mr. Arafat has chosen, until now, not to have any final showdown with Hamas. At the Camp David talks, the sheik said, Mr. Arafat appeared to have toed the ultimate "red line" in Palestinian politics -- finalizing a deal that, in return for mutual recognition by Israel and a Palestinian state, would have given Israel the prize sought since 1948, acceptance of its right to live on lands taken from Palestinians in Israel's independence war.
 "Arafat is in a very critical situation -- he can't move forward, and he can't move back," he said. "He's reached the logical conclusion of his policy of negotiating with the Israelis, and he's reached a dead end, unless he makes concessions that would be fatal for him. I only hope, for his sake, that he can get himself out of this situation, without giving up any Palestinian rights, without sacrificing our future for the sake of the Zionist entity."
 On a blindingly hot summer's day that had many of the 1.1 million Palestinians of Gaza sheltering in the shadows, there was much else to suggest that Hamas and its rejectionist politics are far from having exhausted their future, especially among the young. Conversations with several people produced only a minority -- many with links to Mr. Arafat's apparatus -- who said they would accept, as part of a final peace settlement with Israel, a renunciation of the "1948 lands" -- a phrase used in Gaza and the West Bank.
 A merchant selling gold trinkets from a hand cart in the bazaar, a well-known editor, a schoolteacher, an 18-year-old youth kicking a football along the beach, a cashier selling stationery, a food shop owner -- all dismissed the notion that Palestinians would settle permanently for a state in Gaza and the West Bank, and a foothold in Jerusalem, except as a way station to a fuller reckoning with Israel later.
 The strongest support for Hamas, now as before, comes from those living in refugee camps, perhaps as many as two-thirds of the Gaza population. These are people who live in Gaza City, Rafah and other towns, in squalid neighborhoods with unpaved roads, inadequate electricity, water and sanitation, and chronic unemployment that have condemned three generations in the same families to poverty. The camps are divided into neighborhoods, named for the towns and villages in pre-1948 Palestine.
 In Rafah, at the southern end of the Gaza Strip, when a visitor asked Ahmed Da'abes, age 16, where he was from, he answered without a pause, "Yibna" -- a predominantly Palestinian town before 1948, now the Israeli town of Yavne, 10 miles south of Tel Aviv. And what did Ahmed think of Mr. Arafat? "Well, you know very well the kind of leaders we have now," he said. "If our leaders were from the Islamic movement, we would be sure that we would one day have Yibna back."
 The message is one that needs no underscoring in Israel. Organizations like Shin Bet, the internal security agency, have never relented in their hunt for Islamic militants, and have scored some chilling successes. In January 1996, a cell phone doctored by Shin Bet exploded in the hands of Yehiya Ayash, the leader of the al-Qassem brigade, killing him. His successor, Mohammed Dief, was arrested in Gaza in May this year, and is being held in an Israeli jail.
 This week, Shin Bet announced that a joint operation between its agents and Mr. Arafat's in Israel, Gaza and the West Bank had resulted in the roundup of 23 Islamic activists involved in planning terror bombings and other attacks, including one Gaza man, Nabil Okal, 27, said to have been sent by Hamas for training in a camp in Pakistan run by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born terrorist leader.
 Last month, another Shin Bet operation resulted in the seizure of an alleged Hamas armory in the West Bank town of Nablus, where agents were said to have found one of the largest stores of weapons and bomb-making equipment seized in years. The two swoops appeared to have been behind a new State Department advisory issued 10 days ago warning Americans of an increased risk of terrorist attacks in Israel, and might have prompted a similar warning given this week by Mr. Barak.
 Three years ago, Sheik Yassin said his organization would consider a "truce" with Israel if it abandoned all claims to Gaza, the West Bank and Jerusalem, and released all Palestinian prisoners. But in the interview in Gaza City, he said that the offer was now void, as Israel had rejected it. Asked whether this would not condemn young Palestinians to an endless, bloody fight against a nation that is heavily armed and trained, he smiled, as if he had heard such foolishness a thousand times.
 "I have the strength of a man who is ready to fight and die for the liberation of his land, who doesn't need aircraft and tanks and atomic bombs," he said. "How can Israel resist people who are prepared to die as martyrs?"

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Global Calm Prevails, But Is It Deceptive?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
WHEN central bankers and economists from around the world gathered here two years ago for the annual conference sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, the worldwide economic outlook was bleak.
 
 Russia's finances were melting down. Asia was in a tailspin. Latin America's stability was at risk. Though no one had yet noticed, one of the world's biggest hedge funds was imploding. Even the ever-resilient American economy was under threat.
 In many ways, the atmosphere here over the last several days at this year's Fed conference on global economic integration could not have been more different. The global financial crisis of a few years ago has given way to general stability and renewed growth. With the partial exception of Japan, the big industrial nations are prosperous. Most of the developing world is rebounding. Financial markets, while still bearing the scars of 1998, are healthy if not robust.
 Yet there was an undercurrent of nervousness in much of the discussion here, and not because of the forest fires burning just a few miles away from this scenic resort. It seemed driven by a sense that while the last crisis had passed without much permanent harm, another might well be on the way, and that there was still no clear prescription for dealing with it.
 Paul Krugman of Princeton University presented a paper to the conference saying that economists were suffering from "persistent if low-grade anxiety" about the world economy, and said that one of the by-products of increased economic integration among countries would be more frequent financial crises.
 Michael Mussa, director of research at the International Monetary Fund, felt compelled to ask whether the world was about to lapse back into isolationism and nationalism. And although his answer was no, the very fact that he raised the question suggested that policy makers had been shaken by the widespread protests in the last year over free trade and the threat it posed to labor and environmental standards.
 EVEN Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, bemoaned the lack of progress in breaking down the remaining trade barriers among nations, and warned that support for globalization could erode the next time the economy hits a rough patch.
 It was certainly not news to anyone here, including Mr. Greenspan, that globalization carries risks and costs as well as undeniable advantages. The issue is what we have learned from the experience of recent years about how to minimize the chances of a problem erupting or to deal with it effectively once it has.
 Mr. Krugman, who also writes an Op-Ed Page column for The New York Times, told the meeting that economists have not even come to any consensus about what caused the troubles that began in Asia in 1997, much less worked out a new global financial architecture or crisis-response playbook.
 Most economists and policy makers here agree that high levels of short-term borrowings in foreign currencies by companies contributed greatly to the travails in Asian nations like Thailand. When local currencies collapsed, the repayment terms of these loans rapidly became prohibitive. Companies went bankrupt and economics spiraled downward in defiance of the beneficial effects that a cheaper currency is usually expected to have on exports. With the economy deteriorating, capital took flight, particularly as foreign lenders refused to roll over loans and took their money home.
 Why not try to block this kind of death spiral in the future by restricting capital flight? The policy makers and economists gathered here, by and large a avidly free-market bunch, could not quite swallow their distaste for limiting the mobility of money across borders, although Charles Goodhart of the London School of Economics suggested that there might be an ideologically acceptable compromise in using bank regulation, rather than outright capital controls, as a brake on the rapid withdrawal of funds from an economy.
 IN any case, the last crisis may not hold any lessons for the next crisis, whatever it might be.
 A paper by Maurice Obstfeld of the University of California at Berkeley and Kenneth Rogoff of Harvard suggested that the next big international economic problem could arise close to home.
 They studied the large and rising current account deficit in the United States - 4.3 percent of gross domestic product this year, up from an average of 1.7 percent from 1992 to 1998.
 They concluded that a reversal of the current account position, a development they said was inevitable within the next 5 to 10 years, would entail a drastic change in the relative value of the dollar, forcing a depreciation of as much as 45 percent if the turn-about was abrupt or 12 percent if the turn-about proved more orderly.
 But the somewhat disconcerting sense among the economic elite gathered here was that they are even less able to foresee the future than to understand and draw lessons from the past. As Mr. Greenspan put it, "our past endeavors at long-term forecasting afford us little confidence in being able to anticipate seminal changes in global economics and finance."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Again Debate Their Dueling Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR

DATELINE: NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 26

 BODY:
The debate over the tax cut plans of Representative Rick A Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton continued today, with Mrs. Clinton calling Mr. Lazio's proposal "fiscally irresponsible" and saying that it was likely to increase the national debt.
 
 Mr. Lazio, meanwhile, said Mrs. Clinton's plan was not in the best interest of New Yorkers.
 Speaking before a group of Democratic women at the Nyack Center, a community center, Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic candidate for Senate from New York, portrayed herself as a key member of the Clinton administration team that reduced the national debt. She tried to tie Mr. Lazio to conservative Republicans in Congress who had proposed large tax cuts.
 Today was the first day that Mrs. Clinton herself directly criticized Mr. Lazio's tax plan. In the last few days, Mrs. Clinton's aides have criticized Mr. Lazio's proposal to use a projected $4.4 trillion, 10-year federal budget surplus to cut taxes.
 The centerpiece of the plan, which Mr. Lazio outlined Thursday in a speech in Amherst, would allow tax-payers to deduct from their federal income taxes the payroll tax, which finances Social Security.
 After a speech here today, Mrs. Clinton said she believed that the Lazio plan would waste the surplus and stifle the economic boom.
 "Mr. Lazio has a tax plan that is fiscally irresponsible and the numbers don't add up," she said. "It's not going to give one penny to prescription drug benefits, Medicare or putting down the debt, things I've supported."
 Mrs. Clinton said Mr. Lazio's proposal mirrored many of those advocated by House Republicans when Newt Gingrich was the House speaker.
 "This is right out of the Newt Gingrich, George W. Bush Republican playbook," Mrs. Clinton said.
 But the Lazio campaign defended its plan today, saying that it would actually bring prosperity to blighted areas of the state. "Mrs. Clinton doesn't trust New Yorkers and believes only Washington bureaucrats know how to spend our hard-earned money," Mr. Lazio said in a statement.
 Mrs. Clinton's plan would trim taxes by $496 billion over 10 years, and include a cut in the so-called marriage penalty, but not eliminate it.
 On Thursday, Mr. Lazio, who has been a congressman from Suffolk County for eights years, said his proposal would include a menu of tax cuts long advocated by Congressional Republicans, among them the elimination of the inheritance tax and the marriage penalty. Mr. Lazio's speech came in a week that George W. Bush, the Republican presidential nominee, was forced to defend his $1.3 trillion federal tax cut proposal.
 Mr. Lazio said his plan would result in $776 billion in tax cuts over 10 years. It was meant to distance himself from the Bush plan, while still advocating more reductions than Mrs. Clinton did. But Clinton campaign aides said that because of an error in calculations, Mr. Lazio's plan would actually produce $1.24 trillion in cuts, rather than the $776 billion he cited.
 Organizers of Mrs. Clinton's appearance here said the event was hastily put together over the last five days to help shore up support among female voters.
 Recent polls have shown that Mrs. Clinton is not doing well among white women, though her support among black women reamins strong. Only local women were invited to today's event, organizers said.

HEADLINE: The Poor Among Us

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bob Herbert did not have to travel to Los Angeles to find a working poor family in the grip of stifling poverty (column, Aug. 21). Walk into any homeless shelter here in New York City, and you'll find men and women working at low-wage jobs, unable to afford rents in this booming economy. Walk into a city hospital's emergency room, and you'll see working families without health insurance relying on the hospital for their primary care. 
 A minimum-wage increase is only one part of the equation. We also need welfare reform that doesn't rely on make-work programs but instead offers people an opportunity for real skill-building and jobs that provide a ladder up. Universal health care is essential, as is a commitment to the construction of affordable housing.
 
ARNOLD S. COHEN
Pres., Partnership for the Homeless
New York, Aug. 21, 2000

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
A San Francisco Company Learns What a Mayor Can Do for Business

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
More than 750 local governments now use the Web site operated by NetClerk to put the construction-permit process online. But so far, only the mayor of San Francisco, Willie L. Brown, has become part of NetClerk's advertising campaign.
Last week, NetClerk put a picture of Mr. Brown and the city's seal on www.netclerk.com, the company's Web site, along with a letter the mayor had written praising the company for, among other things, helping reduce lines at city hall. 
 So far, NetClerk's PermitCentral service has been used to issue more than 1,000 building permits in San Francisco.
"Although we enjoy interacting with each and every person who comes to city hall, waiting in line may not be the best use of a contractor's time," the mayor wrote.
The letter may have been less than a spontaneous testimonial. Jon Fisher, founder of NetClerk, said the company began discussing a "public relations partnership" with the San Francisco's mayor's office about a month ago.
So how does a letterhead partnership play out?
"The city of San Francisco is well known for its forward thinking, technological savvy," the mayor wrote. "NetClerk offers a perfect example of how technology can improve a current system to the satisfaction of all parties involved."
For Mayor Brown, of course, the satisfaction comes from bolstering his image as a technology supporter and promoter of the Bay Area's high-technology economy.
As it happens, NetClerk, based in South San Francisco, is part of that economy. LAURIE J. FLYNN

HEADLINE: New Economy;
The German auction of wireless networks uncovered deep fissures in the European telecommunications landscape.

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
IT was a free-market contest of the purest sort, an airwave auction of the kind pioneered in the United States and taken to dizzying new heights in Europe.
Yet ever since the bidding ended 11 days ago in Germany's auction of wireless licenses for so-called third-generation mobile networks, even devoted market enthusiasts have started to wonder if this is really the most rational way to go. 
 After two weeks and 173 rounds of bidding, six companies had bid a total $46 billion for the rights to one license apiece. And that total did not include an additional $4 billion or so that each company would have to spend to build the new networks and drum up customers.
Investors have been reeling, dumping the stocks of all the winners: Deutsche Telekom, Vodafone AirTouch of Britain, British Telecommunications, France Telecom, Telefonica of Spain and Sonera of Finland.
Standard & Poor's, the credit-rating agency, warned that it would probably lower most of the companies' credit ratings and might even drop some to the triple-B level, not much better than junk-bond status. Bond investors are bracing for a flood of gigantic telephone bond offerings, but the uncertainties were high enough that British Telecommunications postponed an offering last week until its rating was clarified.
Certainly, wireless opportunities are immense. Europe is well ahead of the United States in rolling out digital wireless telephones, and the new licenses will be used to offer high-speed data communications that are eventually expected to galvanize mobile electronic commerce.
As envisioned, the new third-generation mobile networks will enable people to surf the Internet from a sidewalk, download video clips onto their hand-held phones or simply locate a nearby restaurant and book a table.
But no one knows what consumers will really want or how much they will be ready to pay. And because the new systems will increase competition in ordinary mobile phone service, analysts predict that prices and profitability in voice service will decline sharply.
Most economists argue that risks are simply part of the game. If companies overbid, they may have to fold tent and sell their licenses to someone else at a loss. The world will go on.
But the German auctions also uncovered deep fissures in the European telecommunications landscape that make the entire playing field uneven.
Britain, Germany and the Netherlands have all held auctions, won by a variety of European players. But Spain and Finland, using a so-called beauty contest approach, simply awarded licenses to companies deemed most worthy. The licenses, granted primarily to domestic applicants, came at a fraction of the price they might have fetched at auction. France will hold a beauty contest, too, but will charge a flat fee of about $4 billion a license.
Some executives complain that companies from countries with very low license costs can save billions at home and then plow the money into auctions elsewhere.
"We don't have a level playing field in Europe," said Hans Ehnert, a spokesman for Deutsche Telekom. "We had to compete in the bidding against companies like Telefonica from Spain, but we were excluded from the Spanish market."
The idea of auctioning off the airwaves was pioneered in the early 1990's in the United States, where economists and government officials alike viewed them as the fairest and most efficient way of allocating the public airwaves.
The auction approach developed after governments handed out the first cellular licenses in the 1980's, when companies paid nothing to receive what soon became hugely profitable franchises that grew at explosive rates. By forcing companies to pay the government top dollar, governments and taxpayers would be able to reap at least some of the bonanza.
Indeed, the German government's auction windfall is so big that the largess has ignited a major political battle over what to do with the money.
Advocates of auctions also argue that they are the most effective way to put licenses in the hands of those most likely to use them profitably. Compared with beauty contests, auctions give the participants no opportunity to exploit political connections or bedazzle government bureaucrats with lofty promises that can later be broken.
"In a beauty contest, there is no way to ensure that a decision is based on objective facts," said Torsten Gerpott, a professor of economics at the University of Duisberg in Germany, who has closely studied the issue. "Look at France," he said. "I would bet that at least three of the licenses are awarded to local players."
By any measure, both the British and German auctions were open. But one of the surprise winners in the German auction -- a bidder that Deutsche Telekom and Vodafone both tried and failed to eliminate -- was a group controlled by Telefonica of Spain and Sonera of Finland.
The Spanish and Finnish companies had received new wireless licenses at negligible costs from their own governments.
Deutsche Telekom bid for a license earlier this year in Spain, where the license fees were relative peanuts: about $130 million and 0.15 percent of future revenues. Deutsche Telekom teamed up in the beauty contest with Jazztel, a fast-growing Spanish competitor to Telefonica, but the team lost to three Spanish operators and a fourth group led by Vivendi of France.
As for Finland, Pirjo Kekalainen-Torvinen, Sonera's senior vice president for international business development, said her company had not unfairly benefited by getting a Finnish license almost free. "We paid as much for our license in Germany as anybody else," she said.
She noted that Finland had strong policy reasons for awarding wireless licenses as cheaply as possible. Finland, which is home to the world's biggest producer of wireless phones, Nokia, considers wireless technology its biggest national industry. By giving out next-generation wireless licenses as quickly and cheaply as possible, government officials hope to promote and indirectly subsidize innovative new technology and services.
Many industry executives blame Deutsche Telekom itself for the high prices of the German licenses. Gerhard Schmid, chief executive of Mobilcom, a German company that teamed up with France Telecom and did win a license, angrily complained that the six final bidders could have ended up with the same licenses and saved billions of dollars if they had simply stopped bidding four days earlier.
Mr. Schmid blamed Deutsche Telekom for a misguided attempt to outbid the Spanish-Finnish group for an extra license, a move that would have reduced the number of rivals from six to five.
But Telefonica and Sonera refused to give up, and Deutsche Telekom exececutives capitulated after the total bidding had climbed from 30 billion euros ($27.1 billion) to 50.5 billion euros. The result was higher license prices and more licensees than most investors had been expecting.
To be sure, investors pummeled shares of Sonera and Telefonica even more than they did those of Deutsche Telekom. Yet when Italy begins auctions later this year, Deutsche Telekom plans to stay out, saying it has no interest in Italy. But Telefonica and Sonera, exuberant after their German adventure, plan to team up again.

HEADLINE: Report Questions a Number in Microsoft Trial

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27

 BODY:
How many applications dance on the head of a hard drive?
In his antitrust ruling against Microsoft, federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson argued that a crucial barrier confronting the company's potential competitors are the 70,000 programs written to run solely on the Windows operating system. 
 The judge made his ruling, in April, based on trial testimony about the number of Windows programs -- testimony that was not disputed by Microsoft. The judge concluded that the vast library of Windows-based programs discourage competitors and make the possibility of competing against Microsoft impractical. At issue are so-called application programs -- word processors, spreadsheets, personal-finance software and the like -- that run on top of the Windows operating system.
But an economist who has surveyed the personal computer software market contends that the 70,000 figure is grossly overstated. There are probably fewer than 10,000 Windows programs in use today and most users probably have no more than a handful on their computers, according to the economist, Richard B. McKenzie, a conservative scholar at the University of California at Irvine.
The lower figure indicates that Microsoft is not the impregnable fortress depicted in the antitrust trial, Mr. McKenzie writes in a paper that presents the results of his survey.
The paper is to be published this week by the Cato Institute, a libertarian research group based in Washington. Mr. McKenzie also recently published "Trust on Trial: How the Microsoft Case Is Reframing the Rules of Competition," a book that attacks the Justice Department's antitrust case.
In his paper, Mr. McKenzie contends that Microsoft may have contributed to the misconception when it claimed in marketing and advertising materials in 1997 that as many as 100,000 programs existed for the Windows operating system.
 "It seems that their marketing behavior has come back to bite them," Mr. McKenzie said in an interview.
He said he had embarked on his research after failing to find any documentation to support a contention made during the trial by John Rose, a Compaq Computer executive and Microsoft witness, that the 70,000 applications were the reason that Compaq shipped Windows with its computers.
"I was shocked," by the claim, Mr. McKenzie recalled. After failing to find documentation for the claim and conducting a survey, he said he asked the company why it had not challenged the figure.
 He said Microsoft executives told him that they did not wish to undermine the credibility of their witness. "They were between a rock and a hard place," he said.
The 70,000 figure might actually represent the number of applications that have been written during the entire history of the personal computer industry, he said. Or it may be an exaggeration based on the fact that many software programs go through multiple versions during their life spans.
 "Amazon lists only 8,301 'software programs' under its productivity software categories," Mr. McKenzie writes in his paper, titled "Microsoft's Applications Barrier to Entry: The Missing 70,000 Programs."
"That is a large number," the paper continues, "but it counts programs written for all available operating systems, including Red Hat Linux, IBM OS/2, and Apple Mac, as well as Microsoft Windows. Many of the software programs are also listed several times in the various subcategories."
A Microsoft spokesman said that, despite Mr. McKenzie's analysis, the company believed that the larger number cited by the Compaq witness and by the judge were accurate.
Mr. McKenzie draws a different lesson. Because there are actually only a few crucial programs used by most PC users -- like Microsoft Office -- the company's applications business, he said, should be vulnerable to a program like StarOffice, which is being distributed free by Sun Microsystems.

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report;
Internet companies learn how to personalize service.

BYLINE: By Susan Stellin 

 BODY:
ASK a handful of Internet executives to define the term "personalization," and invariably the conversation turns to the analogy of a shopkeeper who knows not only his customers' names, but how much they can afford to spend and what size shirt they wear.
Never mind that most Americans shop at retail chains where, if they happen to be greeted by a clerk, they are more likely than not to respond, "Thanks, I'm just looking." This old-fashioned ideal of personalized service -- albeit, updated with new economy motives -- is the next hurdle for Internet companies trying to achieve profitability in an increasingly competitive environment. 
 What this means in practice is that rather than displaying the same set of pages to every visitor, a Web site would present different information to each customer based on the person's data profile. A person who has shown online interest in classical music might be presented with a special price on Bach compact discs, whereas someone who has bought a Britney Spears CD might be offered a discount on N'Sync.
This type of personalized experience, alternatively described as "one to one marketing" or "targeted merchandising," has long been touted as one of the key benefits of the Web. But so far, very few Internet companies have been able to take advantage of this potential, mainly because the technologies for delivering it are still in the early stages of development.
That said, the industry is gradually catching up to the hype surrounding personalization, as a growing number of companies have installed tools enabling them to present customized Web pages -- if not to a single individual, then at least to groups that have been identified as having a similar profile. This trend is going to raise the ante for companies doing business online, both in terms of investors' and customers' expectations. It is also going to raise new privacy issues concerning what type of information is collected about consumers and how that data is used -- worries that could overshadow any benefits that customers stand to derive from these services.
To be sure, some degree of personalization has existed for years online, most notably through sites like Yahoo or Excite, which allow members to create a page that displays information based on preferences they have entered, like stock symbols or categories of news. In the ever-changing industry vernacular, however, that type of service is now referred to as "customization," whereas the techniques known as "personalization" are based on information companies have more discreetly gathered about consumers, like their purchase history or the Web pages they have viewed.
Cormac Foster, an analyst at the research firm Jupiter Communications, said the difference involves explicit versus implicit data. "Customization is giving users what they've told you they want," he said, "and personalization is anticipating what they want."
The ability to deliver personalized services involves a complex process, generally requiring an investment in hardware and software that can cost from several hundred thousand to several million dollars.
First, a company must integrate disparate sources of data, like its product list, its customer database and a record of the pages on its Web site those customers have viewed. Once that data is integrated, analysis tools from companies like E.Piphany and Broadbase Software can be used to look for patterns of behavior. Using those patterns, marketers set rules telling the system to give a certain treatment to a particular category of customers. Those rules, in turn, are processed by so-called content delivery systems offered by companies like the ATG Group and BroadVision that are responsible for putting the selected information on the screens of the right customers.
One of the challenges for companies setting up personalization systems, Mr. Foster said, is that they generally have to work with a number of different vendors. And in some cases, companies that have experimented with early technologies have already had to replace those systems. "Part of the problem," he said, "is all the technologies are fairly immature."
Not surprisingly, one of the leaders in the personalization arena is Amazon.com, which began its efforts in 1997 with a "book matcher" feature. To use that feature, customers had to fill out a form indicating their interests, and the system would match them with books tailored to their entries. The problem with that feature, according to Josh Petersen, Amazon's director of personalization, was that it required too much work on the user's part.
"You wouldn't have had to walk into a store of old and fill out a questionnaire," Mr. Petersen said.
As a result, Amazon focused its efforts on building a system based on implicit data, like a customer's past purchases, which now feeds into the site's "New for You" and "Recommendations" features. Using technology primarily developed by Amazon, these services recommend products to customers based on algorithms that take into account factors like the ratings a customer has assigned various products on the site and the purchasing patterns of customers with similar profiles.
To reduce the impact of errant data, Amazon allows users to exclude certain purchases from their profile; that way, a Pokemon game purchased for a niece will not skew a pattern of buying mystery novels and Woody Allen videos. The system also makes some automatic assumptions, like excluding gift-wrapped items.
Despite the advances the company has made, Mr. Petersen said Amazon still had a long way to go before meeting the company's goal of creating a unique store for every customer who visits the site. "It's one of the hardest engineering tasks that we work on," he said.
John Samuel, vice president of interactive marketing for AMR's American Airlines, would be the first to agree that current implementations of personalization technologies are still in their infancy. American overhauled its AA.com Web site in 1998, with a new version that allows the site to present pages that have been tailored for each individual.
Mr. Samuel said the company had a head start in its personalization efforts because of its AAdvantage frequent-flier program, which has gathered information about 40 million members. American uses that information, as well as data collected from customers who fill out a profile online, to tailor the offers that customers see when they visit the company's Web site.
"For us, that translates to knowing someone is in college versus knowing someone is retired or often flies business class," Mr. Samuel said. "The communication to those customers should be very different."
The business customer, for example, might be presented with information about upgrades or American's Admirals Club, whereas the college student would be shown special offers for travel during school vacations. In addition, American targets information based on a customer's home airport and preferred destinations.
In this respect, Mr. Samuel said, American has been careful to err on the side of being explicit about collecting data, which is why the company asks customers to fill out a profile, even if that information is easy to deduce from an individual's travel history.
"It would not be hard for us to infer a customer's home airport," he said. "But we still ask on the Web site."
The challenge for American Airlines and other companies experimenting with this level of personalization will be negotiating a delicate balance between providing consumers with services and offers they want, and appearing to know too much and risk scaring those customers away.
"We know a lot, and our customers know we know a lot," Mr. Samuels said. The question is, "What permission do we have from the customer to use that knowledge?"

HEADLINE: DaimlerChrysler to Expand Its Production in Alabama

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 27

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler plans to announce on Monday that it will nearly double production in Alabama, adding another assembly line close to the site where it already builds M-Class sport utility vehicles, auto industry officials and consultants said over the weekend.
The Mercedes-Benz unit of DaimlerChrysler said on Friday that it would hold a news conference on Monday in Tuscaloosa, Ala., the nearest large city to its sport utility vehicle factory in Vance. The planned construction project is the latest sign that Alabama's auto industry is growing. Honda has just begun building a minivan factory near Vance, too. 
 DaimlerChrysler declined to comment on what the factory would produce. But auto industry consultants working for automakers and auto parts suppliers said that the company would make a so-called crossover vehicle that would combine the features of a minivan and the M-Class sport utility vehicle.
Whether the planned Mercedes project represents a new assembly plant or an expansion of the existing one will likely be the subject of some debate. State officials in Alabama began praising the project on Friday as a new plant. But there is no consensus among automakers over whether adding a second assembly line represents a second plant or an expansion of an existing one.
Because the second assembly line will produce a vehicle similar to the M-Class, it is likely to work closely with the existing assembly plant and receive shipments of many of the same parts. "I'd put it more in terms of expansion" of the existing factory, rather than a second, independent assembly plant, said an auto industry manager who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The Birmingham News reported that Mercedes would receive $150 million in state incentives for the new operation and that it would create 1,750 jobs. Mercedes received $235 million in incentives for the existing factory.
It will be to DaimlerChrysler's advantage to portray the new operation as an entire assembly plant to people in Alabama, where the company has been seeking tax breaks and other assistance, while portraying it in Michigan as an expansion of the existing operation. The United Automobile Workers union, which represents workers of the former Chrysler Corporation, has been unable to organize workers at the factory in Vance, and there is considerable nervousness among workers and state officials in Michigan about the pace of automakers' expansion in the South.
The U.A.W. declined today to comment on DaimlerChrysler's plans. Although DaimlerChrysler has publicly declared its neutrality on the question of whether the current assembly plant should be organized, union officials have complained over the last year that the company has remained hostile. Local businesses in the Vance area have tried to rally factory workers against the U.A.W., fearing that if the union is successful, that might discourage further investment in the area. The U.A.W. has not insisted on an actual vote at the factory on whether to unionize, fearing that it might lose.
Michael E. Robinet, the director of forecast services at CSM Worldwide, a big auto production consulting firm based in Northville, Mich., said over the weekend that Mercedes would change the M-Class sport utility vehicle considerably several years from now and then use the underbody from the new model to build a similar vehicle at an adjacent site.
The current M-Class uses a stiff, heavy underbody like that of a pickup truck, which made it cheap to develop but also gives a bumpy ride. Mr. Robinet said that Mercedes would switch to a lighter, car-like underbody for the next generation of M-Class vehicles.
Automakers are increasingly combining the features of sport utility vehicles with those of cars and minivans, using car-like underbodies for better handling, fuel economy and safety. Examples include the Lexus RX-300 sport utility vehicle and the new Pontiac Aztek and Ford Escape. Because these vehicles still look mostly like sport utilities on the outside, automakers have been successful, with few exceptions, in persuading regulators that these crossover vehicles are still eligible for the more lenient safety, air pollution and fuel economy standards that apply to light trucks, instead of the more stringent standards applied to cars.

HEADLINE: Lynden Pindling, 70, Who Led the Bahamas to Independence

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Sir Lynden O. Pindling, the prime minister of the Bahamas for 25 years whose reputation and relationship with the United States were marred by unresolved accusations of protecting drug traffickers, died on Saturday at his home in Nassau. He was 70.
The cause was prostate cancer, aides said in a statement. 
 Sir Lynden was the prime minister from 1967 to 1992, leading the Bahamas through tremendous change, including the transition from a British colony to independence in 1973. He was defeated in the 1992 election by the current prime minister, Hubert Ingraham. At the time of his defeat, Sir Lynden had been in office longer than any leader in the Western Hemisphere except Fidel Castro of Cuba.
On Saturday, as radio and television stations in the Bahamas broadcast tributes to Sir Lynden, Mr. Ingraham called him "a giant of our times," according to The Associated Press.
Left unmentioned, however, were allegations involving Sir Lynden in the 1980's that political observers in the Bahamas say contributed to his defeat. He was accused of covering up for drug traffickers and of taking bribes as the chairman of the nation's Hotel Commission. A Bahamian government commission was unable to substantiate any of the claims, but the allegations had pronounced political ramifications.
Sir Lynden remained a member of the House of Assembly until 1997, when he resigned after 41 years in that legislative body. At the time, he said he was "less than perfect," but added that "when all I did for good is put in the balance against all I did for ill or failed to do at all, I hope that future generations will not find me sorely wanting."
In 1953, he helped found the Progressive Liberal Party, a political organization dedicated to overthrowing the mostly white colonial-run United Bahamian Party. Some supporters called him the "black Moses."
When he was first elected prime minister in 1967, he ended a tradition of white minority rule that had been in place for centuries. He devoted his first term in office to securing independence from Britain and used that prestige to win five more elections.
Sir Lynden spent much of his time working to improve the reputation of his country, but became vulnerable to charges of corruption in 1984, when an official commission set up to investigate drug trafficking in the Bahamas found wide evidence of official corruption in his cabinet and the Bahamian police. The commission eventually cleared Sir Lynden of any wrongdoing, but said that he and his wife had at least $3.5 million in bank deposits that could not be accounted for.
At the 1987 trial of Carlos Lehder, a founder of the Medellin cocaine cartel in Colombia, prosecutors charged that Mr. Lehder and other drug traffickers had paid at least $5 million to Sir Lynden for permission to use the Bahamas as a shipment point for cocaine and marijuana bound for the United States.
Several drug smugglers testified that they had made such payments directly to him. The prime minister denied the accusations. After Mr. Lehder's conviction, the United States sought to confiscate his holdings in the Bahamas, but was rebuffed by Sir Lynden. He continued to quarrel with the United States until his 1992 defeat.
By that year, though, a decline in the economy in the late 1980's and early 1990's had become the decisive factor for many voters. Tourism was by far the largest source of employment and revenue in the nation of more than 700 islands, and the Bahamas was finding it difficult to compete with other vacation destinations.
To many young voters, Sir Lynden was seen not as a father of their country, but as an international pariah and leader who could not get them jobs.
He is survived by his wife, Lady Marguerite; two sons, Obafemi, 40, and Leslie, 39; two daughters, Michelle Sands, 38, and Monique Johnson, 34; and five grandchildren.
