HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES NIGERIA TO FIGHT TYRANNY OF AIDS

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: ABUJA, Nigeria, Aug. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton urged Nigerians today to eliminate the taboos associated with AIDS in Africa, and to confront what he called the "tyranny" of the disease with the same resolve they showed in enduring decades of dictatorship.
"Is it harder to talk about these things than to watch a child die of AIDS who could have lived if the rest of us had done our part?" the president asked at a women's conference here. "Is it harder to talk about than to comfort a child whose mother has died? We have to break the silence about how this disease spreads and how to prevent it. And we need to fight AIDS, not people with AIDS." 
 Mr. Clinton's remarks presented a bold challenge, not only to Nigerians but to all in Africa, where health experts have lamented the fact that the stigma surrounding the disease and inadequate public education about its dangers have contributed to the spread of AIDS. An estimated 23 million Africans carry H.I.V., the virus that causes the disease.
But while the president offered American support for Nigerian efforts to confront AIDS, he offered no new assistance. Africans reacted coolly to the United States' offer last month of $1 billion in annual loans to finance the purchase of anti-AIDS drugs in sub-Saharan Africa, suggesting that the approach would merely add to the already heavy debt burden of African nations.
Mr. Clinton spent the day addressing some of the most pressing problems in Africa: AIDS, poverty, joblessness and soaring national debt. He ventured from the Nigerian capital to a rural village to get a glimpse of how a vast majority of Nigerians live and, winding up a two-day visit to Africa's newest democracy, he encouraged Nigerian businessmen to work to expand the economy beyond its heavy reliance on oil.
Under a morning rain, the village chief, Muhammadu Baba, led Mr. Clinton through the muddy walkways traversing the village of Ushafa, where tin-roof huts house several thousand residents, as well as houses of worship, a pharmacy and health clinic.
The president, accompanied by his daughter, Chelsea, received a rousing welcome as schoolchildren bearing tiny American flags sang greetings and native dancers spun around him in the center square. Mr. Clinton, to the delight of onlookers, slipped into a traditional Nigerian robe and held aloft a handmade hoe, both official gifts of the village.
Later, at a hotel conference room in Abuja, Mr. Clinton told business executives that Nigeria would be added to the list of developing countries that receive duty-free status for their exports, and he vowed to increase ties between Nigeria and the United States, its largest export market. The elimination of tariffs could increase demand for Nigerian exports including cocoa, cotton, hand-made traditional textiles, minerals and forest products.
But it was at a midday appearance before a crowded women's conference that Mr. Clinton addressed the health plight that if left unchecked, he said, would stymie the country even if political and economic reforms took root.
Standing beside a man infected with the virus that has become the continent's leading killer, Mr. Clinton applauded Nigeria's efforts to control the spread of AIDS. But he offered a blunt reminder to Africans that the disease is preventable -- if people would only speak frankly about how it is spread, and take common-sense action.
"AIDS is 100 percent preventable -- if we are willing to deal with it openly and honestly," he said. "In every country, in any culture, it is difficult, painful, at the very least, embarrassing to talk about the issues involved with AIDS."
The president announced no new funds for Nigeria's AIDS fight but he detailed the $20 million the United States will spend this year to control the spread of AIDS, malaria and polio in Nigeria. He reported that AIDS education would be included as part of the military training that United States troops are giving to Nigerian peacekeepers headed to nearby Sierra Leone, which has been ravaged by civil war.
He told the audience of young people, religious leaders and women at the conference in Abuja that Nigerians, despite the introduction of civilian rule last year, would never be free until they bring infectious diseases under control. An estimated 5.4 percent of Nigeria's 114 million people are infected with the AIDS virus, according to the White House, giving it one of the highest infection rates on the continent.
"I am amazed at the courage of the people of Nigeria in struggling against the oppression that you endured for too long until you got your democracy," Mr. Clinton said. "I urge you now to show that same kind of courage to beat the tyranny of this disease so you can keep your democracy alive for all the children of Nigeria and their future."
United States officials, frustrated by the lack of action by some African governments, have praised President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria for making the fight against AIDS a priority. But Mr. Obasanjo stressed today that Nigeria would need help from the rest of the world to win its struggle against the disease.
"It is not a disease you can say if you eradicate it in Nigeria, it is eradicated for good," Mr. Obasanjo said. "Those from Nigeria who go outside and have sexual relations with those who have H.I.V.-AIDS or have blood transfusions with them will bring it back. We don't see it as a Nigerian disease. We see it as a world disease that is ravaging Africa most."
Throughout Mr. Clinton's two-day visit here, Mr. Obasanjo has repeatedly raised the issue of debt relief, encouraging the wealthy nations of the world to forgive the large sums amassed by previous African rulers.
Mr. Obasanjo, elected 15 months ago as part of Nigeria's tenuous transition to democracy, did not directly address the United States AIDS plan today. But in toasting Mr. Clinton at a state dinner on Saturday night, he made a plea for financial relief from the United States and other wealthy nations.
"We know that we cannot achieve our desire for economic development if we continue to bleed from the gushing wounds of an ever-penetrating debt-repayment lance," he said.
Mr. Clinton, in addressing business leaders today, said past leaders of Nigeria -- a country that has suffered under corrupt dictators for most of its modern history -- had squandered its riches and must be careful to focus any debt relief on improving the lives of its people.
In the village of Ushafa, Mr. Clinton saw how far Nigeria must still progress. The village lacks telephone service and running water and received electricity only several months ago. Mr. Clinton entered a small medical clinic that had been stocked with supplies by the State Department just the day before.
One worker told the president that the clinic had treated 234 cases of malaria this year. There are no H.I.V. cases, villagers said, although nearby villages have cases and urban areas are heavily affected.
The United States assistance to Nigeria includes $2 million in the current budget to produce insecticide-treated bed nets to keep malaria-infected mosquitoes at bay, as well as $9 million to battle polio and $10 million to assist the anti-AIDS fight. The White House has requested a $100 million increase, to $342 million, in international AIDS funds in the 2001 fiscal year budget.
"This is not just Nigeria's fight, or Africa's fight," Mr. Clinton said. "It is America's fight and the world's fight too."
The president's remarks heartened John Ibekwe, who heads an organization in Nigeria for people living with AIDS. "With you as an advocate on our side, governments in Africa will do more than they are doing," Mr. Ibekwe said in introducing the president.
Mr. Clinton, who restricted his travel in Nigeria partly for security reasons, leaves for Tanzania early Monday for an update from former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa on the Burundi peace talks. He began his day at a Baptist church in Abuja, where he heard the Rev. Israel Akanji preach on the parable of the Good Samaritan.
"Robbers have come; bandits have come," Mr. Akanji said of his country's struggles against its own leaders. "We have been left wounded, bleeding and dying. Is there a Good Samaritan passing by?"

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1721 words

HEADLINE: A Republican Blazes a Trail In the Campaign For Lazio's Seat

SERIES: NEW YORK PRIMARY -- Second Congressional District

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: BAY SHORE, N.Y.

 BODY:
It was, she says, divine inspiration that cast her into a race that could make her the first black Republican woman ever to serve in Congress.
"I really think I am on a path that someone higher than me is preparing me for," says Joan B. Johnson, 66, the elected town clerk of Islip, who has mounted a campaign to win the Suffolk County seat that Representative Rick A. Lazio is giving up for his Senate candidacy. 
 There was, of course, some earthly machination as well. Two of Suffolk County's most powerful Republicans, the party leaders of the county organization and the town of Islip, the largest community, threw their support behind Mrs. Johnson, a blunt-spoken former social worker. She may lack the polish of a political pro, party leaders reasoned, but she is a proven vote getter whose moderate stances to the left of Mr. Lazio -- and perhaps her race and sex -- will attract Democrats' votes in the Second Congressional District, where Republicans hold only a slight edge in voter registration.
And now Mrs. Johnson, one of a few black Republican women running in the country but the one political analysts say has the best shot, finds herself in the semi-comfortable position of blazing a trail, maybe two, lined with obstacles. She must win a primary on Sept. 12, and confront the possibility that, as she and her supporters concede, some people may not vote for her, simply because of her race and sex.
"A lot of people really thought they were going to get this nod, mainly because here on Long Island you tend to have a cookie-cutter type profile of what a congressperson should look like," Mrs. Johnson said, alluding to the Island's penchant for sending young, white male lawyers to Washington. "And it didn't look like me. It's never female. And in that respect, that's the historic piece of this. I would be the first Republican woman in either Nassau or Suffolk Counties to ever run for Congress."
Mrs. Johnson, who grew up in Florida when segregation was legal and has lived in Islip for 38 years, said the racial aspect of her potential achievement never occurred to her until a reporter for a political journal raised the issue, shortly after she entered the campaign in June.
"I said, 'Oh, my God.' First time I heard it. Never even thought about it," she said.
Mrs. Johnson, who teaches Bible study on Saturdays and dispenses marriage licenses and other bureaucratic documents during the week, now weathers the gale of a high-stakes Congressional race, one symbolically and tactically important for Republicans. Their five-seat hold on the House is on the line, and they are loath to surrender any seat, much less that of Mr. Lazio.
And so Mrs. Johnson, town clerk since 1991, is surrounded by a staff she hardly knows, with a state party operative as her campaign manager and a Washington consultant, Tony Marsh, as campaign strategist. Her eyes bulge at her fund-raising goal, $1.5 million, 88 times the most she ever raised for a town clerk campaign and a far cry from what she has now, about $130,000.
The open seat has brought out a bevy of contenders to a contest that Congressional Quarterly, a leading political journal, rates a tossup between the eventual Democratic and Republican nominees.
Mrs. Johnson has received the endorsement of the Republican and the Conservative Party organizations, but faces a primary on both lines. Her Republican challenger is Robert T. Walsh, a retired banker from Deer Park who represents a Russian humanitarian organization at the United Nations. Mr. Walsh also plans to run on the Right to Life line, as he did in 1994 when he ran for governor. (Mrs. Johnson favors abortion rights with no restrictions, unlike Mr. Lazio, who opposes both public financing for abortions and late-term procedures.) Richard N. Thompson of West Islip is challenging her on the Conservative line.
Mr. Walsh, calling Mrs. Johnson's positions on abortion and gun control out of step with the district's electorate, said, "I think she is an extraordinarily weak candidate and has little chance to beat the Democrats running." He said his years as a banking executive and as a goodwill ambassador at the United Nations stood above her qualifications "or lack thereof" as town clerk.
Mr. Thompson, a lawyer from West Islip who was a pitcher for the Cleveland Indians and Montreal Expos in the 1980's, said he viewed Mrs. Johnson as too far to the left on a number of issues. "I don't think she was the best candidate chosen by the Republicans," he said. "I didn't think she was a voice for conservative values, so I felt compelled to run."
The opponent the primary winners will face is still undetermined. Democrats are headed for a three-way primary, with the victor almost guaranteed strong backing by the national party in an effort both to embarrass Mr. Lazio by grabbing his seat and to help win back the House. They are seeking to reclaim a seat held by a Democrat, Thomas Downey, for 20 years before Mr. Lazio defeated him in 1992.
But among the biggest question marks looming is how voters will take to Mrs. Johnson's race and sex, in a district that has never sent a woman to Congress and whose population of 580,000 is about 79 percent white, 9 percent black, 9 percent Hispanic and 2 percent Asian.
Republicans have portrayed her candidacy as groundbreaking and emblematic of the diversity and inclusiveness they seek. National party officials gave her a brief but valuable daytime speaking role at the Republican National Convention this month. The National Republican Congressional Committee, which conducted a poll in early June that placed Mrs. Johnson near the top of the potential candidates in name recognition, is expected to send a hefty sum to her campaign this fall.
That said, even some of Mrs. Johnson's supporters openly wonder whether people will choose not to vote for her principally because of her race. "I'd like to say that won't happen, but realistically it might," said State Senator Carl L. Marcellino of Syosset, who said he was hopeful that "people in the district will look beyond that."
Some Republicans privately worry about Mrs. Johnson's age and lack of political or legislative experience and rue the decision of Peter McGowan, the powerful Islip town supervisor, to skip the race even though he topped the list of six or seven contenders for the party's backing. Mrs. Johnson, who was not on the initial list, is most often described as kindly, but lacking the fierce ambition that could make waves in a local party striving for stability after scandals and a succession of leaders.
She scoffs at those who question her experience, saying the administrative tasks of the town clerk's office and service on numerous community organization boards adequately prepare anyone for Congress. She cites the case of Representative Carolyn McCarthy, a Long Island Democrat, who won office in 1996 with no political experience by running on a gun control platform rooted in the death of her husband in the Long Island Rail Road shooting in 1993.
As for strategy, Mrs. Johnson hammers an antitax message but also has firmly hitched her fortune to Mr. Lazio, a popular figure in the district. In remarks at a recent "meet the candidates" picnic, Mrs. Johnson scarcely mentioned herself for all her praise of Mr. Lazio.
Black Republicans have always tilted at political windmills, said David Bositis, senior political analyst for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington-based organization that studies African-American affairs. There is only one black Republican now in Congress, J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, and there have been only five this century, Mr. Bositis said.
"Face it, there is a lot of history between African-Americans and the G.O.P.," said Mr. Bositis, citing as an example the party's advocacy during the 1960's and 70's of "states' rights' and other positions that blacks have seen as racially tinged appeals to white Southerners. "At least in the recent past, most of it is negative. No amount of image making in the short term is going to change that around."
Mrs. Johnson grows impatient with talk about one party being for one race or another, a form of "racial profiling," she says with a laugh. If Democrats are perceived as more likely champions of racial advancement, people need to go further back in history, she says with mounting bitterness, rattling off names of Southern Democrats with reputations for intolerance. "I'll tell you who the people were in power when my people were hanging from ropes in trees. They were Democrats."
Her views are generally liberal. She is for not only abortion rights, but also affirmative action, and -- as the godmother of a 17-year-old murder victim -- gun control, including registration. She supports the death penalty, for the most heinous crimes like serial killings, but she says her positions are not rigid and shifted uncomfortably as she discussed the topic. "These issues don't come easy to me," she says. "All life is precious."
But Mrs. Johnson says she feels philosophically closer to Republicans because of her goals to lower taxes and shrink government.
More than anything, however, Mrs. Johnson senses victory in her web of community connections, from her work at Head Start to children's clubs to the town clerk's office.
"See that robe?" she says, motioning to a black gown hanging in the campaign office here on East Main Street that once was where she got her nails done. "I've married 2,500 couples. That's 5,000 people who personally know me because I've put them together." She added: "I go to the Eagle Scout awards, and I was a member of the Boy Scouts Council, and I was a vice president of the Girl Scouts Council, so I do a lot of things locally. My weekends are always filled with community things, the Fire Department, the whatever, the church events."
Theresa Sanders, president of the Urban League of Long Island, a nonpartisan group, said: "She always has been an unsung hero in our community. What Joan Johnson does represent is we've always had progressive, articulate, dedicated African-Americans in our community, and Joan Johnson is no stranger to us."

HEADLINE: Researchers Raise Fresh Issues in Breast-Feeding Debate

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 28

 BODY:
A recent study in India suggests that breast-feeding alone may not provide enough sustenance to babies in the developing nations when their mothers are severely malnourished.
The report adds fuel to a debate about a decade-old campaign by the World Health Organization and other United Nations agencies that advocate an exclusive reliance on breast milk for the first six months of life. 
 The study -- an Indian National Family Health Survey report titled "Are W.H.O. Guidelines on Breast-Feeding Appropriate for India?" -- concludes that babies can and should be given supplementary liquids or soft foods as young as 2 or 3 months to overcome the deficiencies in the milk of a malnourished mother.
The new survey drew immediate criticism from officials from the World Health Organization and Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund. Both groups say that breast-feeding provides the safest, most health-giving nourishment, providing antibodies against diarrheal disease and eliminating risks posed by contaminants often introduced into baby formula or other supplements through the use of dirty water.
Questions about breast-feeding in the developing world have arisen because of AIDS, with studies still assessing the possible transmission from mother to baby of the virus that causes AIDS.
The World Health Organization's guidelines say that breast-feeding should begin immediately after birth and that infants should receive no other food until they are 4 to 6 months old, when supplements may be added to provide additional nutrients. Breast-feeding, in combination with other foods, is recommended until a child is at least 2 years old.
In India, with a population of 1 billion, decades of maternal health programs have failed to dent significantly the high incidence of malnourishment among children, according to the World Bank, which says that more than half the children under 4 in India are severely malnourished and 60 percent of mothers are anemic. Put another way, 40 percent of all the world's malnourished children are Indian. Infant mortality in India is still high, at 79 for every 1,000 births.
In May, the new survey on the role of breast-feeding in nutrition and mortality was published jointly by a state demographer from South India and a specialist in population and health studies from the East-West Center in Honolulu.
The report looked at breast-feeding practices measured against not only infant mortality statistics but also social and economic factors in the lives of the mothers in three groups of high-mortality, medium-mortality and low-mortality Indian states. Breast-feeding is the norm everywhere in India and usually continues beyond infancy, providing a common backdrop for the survey.
While the authors -- Ravilla Anandaiah, demographer for the Tamil Nadu directorate of family welfare, and Minja Kim Choe, a senior fellow at the East-West Center -- did not dispute the value of breast-feeding, they wrote that the purpose of their survey was "to shed light on how infant survival in India can be improved by modifying infant-feeding practices and to evaluate the appropriateness of the W.H.O. guidelines for breast-feeding -- especially the guideline recommending exclusive breast-feeding up to 4 to 6 months."
The authors surveyed mothers of children born in the previous four years, asking them at how many months a baby was regularly given plain water, other milk, other liquids or solids or mushy food.
They found that almost everywhere, babies were being given supplementary liquids or solids at an age lower than international health officials had recommended, and that the food was apparently safe because the presence of supplementary food was not related to higher death rates. Advocates of only breast-feeding say that the risk of contamination, particularly by dirty water, rises when other foods are introduced.
The new survey found that in all mortality groups, both exclusive and nonexclusive breast-feeding seemed to lower mortality rates in the early months. But the benefits of exclusive breast-feeding dropped for older infants, the authors concluded, because "children's nutritional needs are not met completely by mother's milk after the first few months of infancy."
By 3 to 6 months in states with high mortality rates, the survey says, "mortality is higher among those who are breast-fed exclusively." In these high-risk states -- Assam, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Orissa and Uttar Pradesh -- "breast-feeding with supplements has the most beneficial effect on child survival." Mothers who breast-fed exclusively were the poorest, most illiterate and likely to be the most malnourished.

HEADLINE: CABARET REVIEW;
A Woman of Many Faces, Not to Mention Outfits and Wigs

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
When she was a child growing up in South Carolina, Queen Esther recalls in her autobiographical cabaret show, "Queen Esther: Unemployed Superstar," she dreamed of becoming a slinky Las Vegas entertainer like Lola Falana and being a guest star on "The Mike Douglas Show." 
 Evoking that era, she dons a copper-colored wig and an evening gown to croon the bland 1970 ballad "It's Impossible," while parodying the vacant poses struck by lounge singers back then.
Since those days this singer and actress who appeared in the national tour of "Rent" has come far. "Unemployed Superstar" is the tale of her growing up, trying on and discarding pop-culture images from revolutionary black militant to tortured jazz singer and eventually deciding to be herself. Her story is strikingly similar to the one related by Kristen Childs in her recent Off Broadway show, "The Bubbly Black Girl Sheds Her Chameleon Skin."
Through it all Queen Esther exudes an impish charm that recalls the sorely missed comedian and performance artist Danitra Vance. But by the end of the show her musical identity remains undefined. Her nondescript versions of "The Lady Is a Tramp" and "Lush Life" fail to illuminate either the material or her ideas. And when she caps her show with two more vintage lounge songs, "I've Gotta Be Me" and "The Good Life," it isn't clear whether she's making fun of them or embracing them.
The best moments of "Unemployed Superstar," returning on Friday and Sept. 8 and 11 at Joe's Pub at 425 Lafayette Street in the East Village, are its nonmusical monologues in which Queen Esther impersonates embittered neighbors she met when she moved to Harlem. Characters like these could form the basis of an unsettling evening of serious political comedy.

LENGTH: 977 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Questions Raised by a Political Period Piece

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Marc Blitzstein's musical position paper in defense of labor unions, "The Cradle Will Rock," is a period piece that begs an understanding of its period: the later years of the Depression when unions were exercising fresh muscles and being ferociously opposed by industrialists.
That a class war was imminent and apt to be kindled by Blitzstein's proud agitprop was the evident fear of the federal government, which had financed the show under the auspices of a New Deal agency, the Federal Theater Project, but withdrew its support at the last moment, shuttering the theater on opening night, June 16, 1937. 
 Thus was engendered one of theater history's most legendary show-must-go-on stories: the audience and the cast, led by the director, Orson Welles, and the producer, John Houseman, walked to another theater and performed the show anyway, with Blitzstein at the piano and the actors, forbidden by their unions to appear onstage, defiantly singing and reciting their lines from their seats in the auditorium.
This is all so melodramatic that it would seem to be unfathomable by today's theatergoers -- well, at least until a mayor threatens to shut down an art museum. But that aside, the times, the economy and the workplace obviously look different; our hot buttons are not the same. Art frightens some people now for other reasons; communism looms to almost no one as either threat or panacea. And no matter what you think of Nafta or how outraged by American companies exploiting foreign workers, the issue of labor versus management has evolved to be considerably cloudier than Blitzstein's good-versus-evil presentation.
In "Cradle" you're either fer us or agin us. And at a time when Al Gore is casting himself as a populist, the paradigms have obviously taken on some ambiguity.
Nonetheless, the new Off Broadway production of "Cradle" by the Jean Cocteau Repertory Company at the Bouwerie Lane Theater is steadfast in its championing of the original. The director, David Fuller, has imbued the show with an earnest nostalgia, even recalling the famous opening night with several scenes staged in the aisles of the tiny house, and having actors, on occasion, make their entrances through a side door from the street.
It all results in a production that is high-minded, energetic and amusingly quaint. Blitzstein's play is a story set in Steeltown, U.S.A., that pits a noble union organizer, Larry Foreman, against the powerful Mr. Mister, who owns the steel mill and holds the town's religious and civic leaders in his thrall. It consists of a series of scenes in which everyone who does not adamantly oppose Mr. Mister as corrupt -- the press, the clergy, the artists who fawn on his wife, Mrs. Mister, for her patronage -- are prostitutes, in the show's leading metaphor, except the woman who actually does sell her body because her virtue is sacrificed to need. She does it for food.
This is unsubtle stuff; its power comes from its righteous gall but the best this production musters is a sincere mimicking of a passion that was heartily felt long ago. Part of this has to do, perhaps, with the small theater; Blitzstein's grandiosity is necessarily writ small here. And perhaps it has to do with many in the cast (members of the Cocteau company, including a few interns), not being old enough to remember Ho Chi Minh, not to mention Mussolini.
The performers here understand well enough that Blitzstein intended acrid satire. But with a couple of exceptions (notably two longstanding company members, Elise Stone as Moll, the prostitute, whose performance has a lovely, plaintive quality, and Craig Smith as Mr. Mister, whose potency has just the slightest suggestion of puncturablility), the performances come across as glib. Their largely conventional sense of hyperbole feels on the one hand like guesswork at issue-driven passions that no longer make headlines. On the other hand they're not hyperbolic enough as if a post-modern irony has made the actors fearful of the show's bald display. Most notably, as Foreman, Jason Crowl sings well, but there's more contrived bluster than stage-holding heart about him.
Blitzstein's score, with its echoes of Weill and dissonant variations on popular forms, had a novel punch in its day, something that the Tim Robbins film of last year, "Cradle Will Rock," for all its show-biz romanticizing of the events leading up to the show's famous opening, satisfyingly preserved. Here, played behind the show's thin convictions by an onstage pianist, Charles Berigan, it has been robbed of its acerbic bite -- it doesn't help that not all the singers land consistently on Blitzstein's melodic astringencies -- leaving it feeling rather humorlessly fervent.
The humor, instead, is of another sort; in some furiously rendered interludes, Mr. Berigan takes on the aspect of a player behind a screened silent film, cranking up the tension when little Nell is tied to the railroad track.
In the end, it all feels terribly ardent, even entertainingly so, but with a whimsy that's probably unintended. It leaves the audience chuckling with the memory of how serious everything used to be.
 
THE CRADLE WILL ROCK
 
Book, music and lyrics by Marc Blitzstein; directed by David Fuller; musical direction by Charles Berigan; choreography by Barbara Brandt; sets by Mark Fitzgibbons; lighting by Izzy Einsidler; costumes by Irene V. SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 1969 words

HEADLINE: That Sinking Feeling, Again

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

DATELINE: VENICE

 BODY:
Science often rests on chance discoveries. So it is that an American archaeologist studying the origins of Venice has stumbled on clues suggesting that a multibillion-dollar plan to build floodgates to save the city from rising waters is doomed.
"Be careful," Dr. Albert J. Ammerman warned as he pulled a tarp from an archaeological dig, freeing swarms of mud wasps. 
 The pit, 10 feet deep and more than 30 feet wide, had been dug next to an ancient basilica. The hole was below sea level, with a pump keeping it from filling with water. At its bottom lay one of the oldest known signs of human habitation in the Venetian archipelago -- a stone walkway dated to around the second century.
This and kindred discoveries show that, over the ages, people living here have had to haul in countless tons of dirt, silt, wood and stone to fortify their swampy isles and keep their homes and cities from disappearing into the sea. And the findings suggest that the floodgates plan -- one of the biggest public works projects of all time -- could produce as many problems as it solves, causing wide ecologic damage.
"You have to see this to understand how the ground builds up," said Dr. Ammerman, a Colgate University archaeologist who has studied the origins of Venice for more than a decade. That the city rests on millions of wooden stilts pounded into marshy ground is well known. But the surprising age and abundance of other kinds of supporting materials is only now coming to light, with large implications for public policy.
The lost world of artifacts and structures is letting Dr. Ammerman and his colleagues in Italy and the United States estimate both past and future rates of subsidence. The news is bad for a city whose famous piazzas and streets already flood with alarming regularity.
For complex reasons, the scientists say, Venice is sinking faster than ever and in the coming century the encroaching waters of the Adriatic Sea could devastate this celebrated city of art and architecture. The situation will only get worse if global warming causes seas to rise.
In fact, they say, surging waters will overwhelm the main way Italy is planning to fight the danger -- 79 mobile floodgates meant to cut off the Venetian lagoon and its islands from the highest of the high tides. The plan, drawn up decades ago and debated since then, is on the verge of approval by the Italian government. It is estimated to cost $2 billion to $4 billion, and has won backing from Italian companies eager for the work.
Dr. Ammerman, 58, an expert about things Venetian, has decided to air his findings widely in hopes of thwarting the project and spurring research on alternative ways of saving Venice, a cultural icon that 10 million people visit each year. It is also his home when he is not at Colgate, in Hamilton, N.Y.
His finds "are raising basic questions about the feasibility" of the mobile floodgates, he wrote last week in the journal Science. Saving the city will take fresh thinking, he added, perhaps through an international competition for new ideas.
"It's a test case for the future," said Charles E. McClennen, a Colgate geologist who aids Dr. Ammerman's inquiries here and who collaborated on the Science article. "We got into this research by accident. But now we see its general importance for cities in many coastal regions."
Dr. Ammerman's work is financed by Colgate, the Delmas Foundation, the Kress Foundation and the National Geographic Society.
That Venetians live a few precarious inches above sea level is evident to any visitor to this city of 117 islands. Its canals teem not only with gondolas and motorboats but fish large and small, as well as algae and seaweed. On hot summer days, the canals at low tide give off a pungent odor said to be based partly on decomposing sea life and partly on the outflows of ancient plumbing.
Every day, the tides here go up and down about three feet. Tides that are more extreme, known as "acqua alta," or high water, tend to occur between October and April and periodically inundate Venice, most alarmingly in 1966 when flooding caused wide damage and economic losses. The tidal surges are driven by heavy rains, winter weather patterns and southerly winds that blow Adriatic waters northward.
On many old buildings, the red bricks of the ground floors are coated by a patina of white -- corrosive sea salt soaked up by the absorbent bricks, which weakens them and causes them crumble.
Low wooden doors are often stained or rotted away at the bottom because of past flooding, and commercial shop doors often have metal guides that allow the quick installation of waterproof gates. Raised walkways are set up in in winter floods. And some tour books recommend high boots.
It was sheer accident that Dr. Ammerman came to delve into the origins of Venice, and that his work opened a new window on the dimensions of the flooding menace.
An environmental archaeologist trained at the University of London, he worked in Italy in the 1970's and 1980's studying sites around Parma, Calabria and Rome, including the Forum.
A specialty of his was extracting core samples and dating materials to better understand the original context of ancient objects and monuments.
In 1989, Dr. Ammerman was living in Venice, happy to have a break from Rome's gritty bustle, when Dr. Maurizia de Min, a senior archaeologist at Venice's Superintendency of Monuments, asked him for assistance. She was helping restore a church, San Lorenzo, and wanted him to probe beneath it.
"We hit stuff three feet down," he recalled. "We hit archaeological things. We moved lower. It was always the same -- layers of living and building materials."
"That was the turning point," Dr. Ammerman said. "We started to realize that there was a whole world down there that no one had ever imagined."
Historians have long known that Venice rose to power in the ninth century, its swampy isolation a bulwark against invaders, its location on the Adriatic a boon for trade. But the scientists managed to illuminate its lost infancy, going back more than 500 years further.
Through the 1990's, working closely with Dr. de Min and the Superintendency of Monuments, Dr. Ammerman investigated six sites in Venice and its lagoon. Each proved a revelation about past habitation and building practices, the evidence always surprisingly deep and speaking volumes about subsidence rates over the ages.
The most extensive dig was on Torcello, an island in the lagoon about a half hour's boat ride from Venice. Some of the first Venetians landed there while fleeing the barbarians.
During a recent visit to Torcello, Dr. Ammerman stepped carefully into the deep pit where the scientists had uncovered the low stone walkway dated to the second century. Pointing to an area higher up, and thus younger, he noted a stone hearth, dated to the sixth century, and, higher still, a road surface made of aligned stones, dated to about the seventh.
Given the ground's softness, he said, "people had to keep building up" or face destruction from encroaching tides and waves.
A major breakthrough in his work was understanding that the depth of such artifacts could yield a way to gauge old sea levels, and thus the rate of ground subsidence over the centuries.
For instance, Dr. Ammerman found that the second-century walkway, probably of Roman origin, had been erected near the edge of the island about 20 inches above what was then the sea level.
Back at his apartment in Venice, he displayed a long, clear plastic tube filled with a deep core sample recently taken from below the walkway area, its streaks of brown and yellow telling of its composition.
Scores of such samples and depth calculations have revealed the arc of accelerating subsidence since the Venetian lagoon formed 6,000 years ago. Dr. Ammerman calculates that, per century, human artifacts sank at a rate of about three inches, then five, then 10, with the fastest decline in the 20th century.
The causes of the speedup are complex, he said. Factors include local industry's pumping of water from beneath the Venice region (which has been stopped), the oxidation of peat that forms as part of the substrate, the compaction of spongy sediments under the growing weight of buildings and slow changes in plate tectonics and the region's geology.
In June 1999, Dr. Ammerman, Dr. McClennen, Dr. de Min and Dr. Rupert Housley of the University of Glasgow published an overview of their speedup findings in Antiquity, a top archaeology journal.
It was this research that led Dr. Ammerman to conclude that Italy's main solution to the flooding problem would not work because it was based on flawed estimates of the subsidence rate.
The floodgates, he reasoned, would have to close 94 to 150 times each year during high tides, destroying the lagoon's delicate ecological balance, basically cutting it off from the sea and its cleansing flows.
The floodgates would be built in lines at the entrances to the Venetian lagoon. Lying flat in housings on the seabed, they would in theory have no effect on shipping or regular tides. When storm surges were forecast, compressed air would be pumped into their hollow inner cavities, forcing out water and causing the hinged gates to tilt upward and rise to the surface to block incoming swells.
Since the worst tides come mostly in winter, Dr. Ammerman and Dr. McClennen wrote last week in Science, gate closure "will end up taking place repeatedly, day after day and week after week."
Defenders of the plan are unmoved, saying Dr. Ammerman is exaggerating the difficulties. Anyway, they say, if the water rises faster than expected, as Dr. Ammerman says it will, the barriers are all the more crucial.
"The gates become even more urgent if the worst scenarios are right," said Dr. Rafael L. Bras, an environmental engineer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who led an international assessment of the floodgate plan.
But in all likelihood, he said, the gates would have to close far less often than Dr. Ammerman foresees and would do little or no ecological harm.
The Consorzio Venezia Nuova, the bloc of Italian companies eager to build the floodgates, Friday denounced the Colgate researchers as "clearly less concerned with the validity of scientific data than they are with attempting to persuade the Italian government to withdraw the concession granted to Italian construction companies."
But Dr. Ahmet S. Cakmak, an emeritus professor of civil engineering at Princeton, who reviewed Dr. Ammerman's calculations on soil mechanics, strongly defended the archaeologist. "He has done a very careful study," Dr. Cakmak said yesterday in a telephone interview. "I support him completely."
John Keahey, a journalist writing a book about saving Venice, said Dr. Ammerman's arguments were "having a big impact" on Italian politicians. "They could use this as an excuse to delay a decision," Mr. Keahey said. "The government is in a struggle to survive, and they would probably rather use the money to give the citizens a tax break."
Dr. Ammerman said the Consorzio would rather attack him and spend money than face the facts.
"Everybody wants a silver bullet," he said. "But that doesn't exist," at least not yet.
Something may emerge in an international competition, he said. But in the meantime, Venice needs to continue what it has already started: raising sidewalks and canal walls, elevating power supplies and telephone lines and moving people out of the first floors of residences.
"People should do what people have always done here since the beginning, which is to build up the ground," Dr. Ammerman added, stressing the importance of old strategies. "This buys you time to work up a better solution that doesn't create equally bad problems."

HEADLINE: Aid to Colombia: Unlearned Lessons

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Neighbors Fear Fallout of Aid to Colombians" (front page, Aug. 25): 
 The United States has apparently learned nothing from the horrors of El Salvador and Nicaragua, where vast amounts of military aid only served to intensify conflicts that neither side was going to win. Now, Congress and President Clinton have confirmed that they will make the same error in Colombia by sending $1.3 billion, almost all in military aid.
Haven't the last 20 years shown us that as long as there is a market for drugs in the United States, somebody will find a way to get them there? Cutting down on the demand side in the United States would do much more to curtail drug production than a bloody military campaign. By providing military aid rather than substantial social and economic assistance, the United States is missing an opportunity to address the real roots of insurgency and drug production in Colombia.
 
OSCAR ARIAS
San Jose, Costa Rica, Aug. 25, 2000
 
The writer, the former president of Costa Rica, won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1987.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
30-Year Issue In Biggest Fall In Six Weeks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday in its biggest one-day drop in six weeks as stocks rose and as analysts said government debt prices had become expensive after a summer rally.
The bond's yield has dropped about half a percentage point, and 10-year note yields are down nearly a full percentage point since early May, helped lower by signs of slower economic growth. That has fed speculation that six interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve in the last 14 months had been enough to keep inflation from accelerating. 
 "Treasuries are at levels that look extreme," said Douglas Johnston, chief government bond strategist at Lehman Brothers Inc. "The good news has already been priced in, so there is only one way for Treasury prices to go and that is down."
The 30-year bond fell 27/32, to 107 17/32, as the three major stock measures rose, damping demand for Treasuries, said James Caron, a Merrill Lynch fixed-income strategist. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.72 percent from 5.66 percent on Friday.
The 10-year note fell 12/32, to 99 27/32. Its yield rose to 5.77 percent, up from 5.72 percent on Friday.
A 2.6 percent rise in the cost of crude oil also hurt Treasuries on concern that higher energy costs might yet filter through to other parts of the economy. At $32.87, oil has risen 28 percent this year, with almost 20 percent of the gain coming in the month of August alone.
Selling by dealers to hedge against possible losses on an expected heavy load of corporate bond sales next week was yet another drag on prices, traders said.

HEADLINE: Wachovia Bank Plans to Cut About 8% of Its Work Force

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 28

 BODY:
Wachovia, one of the nation's largest banks, plans to cut about 1,800 jobs -- or about 8 percent of its work force -- as part of a sweeping revamping intended to reduce expenses by $100 million a year.
The announcement today comes after similar cutbacks at North Carolina's two other largest banks, Bank of America and First Union, both based in Charlotte. All three companies have been looking for ways to improve efficiency. 
 "The resource realignment announced today is another step in a thoughtful process that will make Wachovia stronger and more competitive," said L. M. Baker Jr., the chairman and chief executive.
The job cuts will be spread throughout the company, which is based in Winston-Salem, and will include all levels of professional staff. To ease the effect on displaced employees, Wachovia will offer them severance packages, Mr. Baker said.
Wachovia, which has 21,300 employees, will take a pretax charge of $85 to $100 million, primarily to cover the severance costs. A substantial portion of the charge will be taken in the third quarter.
Shares of Wachovia were down 25 cents, to $56.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In June, First Union said that it would cut at least 3,500 jobs under a similar belt-tightening move that led it to close the Money Store, its home equity loan subsidiary.
Then in late July, Bank of America, said that it would cut as many as 10,000 jobs as it changed focus from growing through mergers to becoming more profitable through use of technology and operating efficiency.
Banks have faced an uphill climb in generating more revenue as interest rates have risen over the last year. The higher rates have made the cost banks pay for their money increase faster than banks have been able to increase their rates for loans or other assets, analysts say.
Wachovia has assets of $70.8 billion, ranking it among the top 20 banks in the United States.

HEADLINE: Get the Easy Greenhouse Gases First

BYLINE: By Gregg Easterbrook; Gregg Easterbrook, a senior editor at The New Republic, is the author, most recently, of Beside Still Waters."

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
That North Pole ice has turned liquid may be the least of our problems. New studies have found that all Northern Hemisphere sea ice is melting at a rate of about 15 percent per decade and that the oceans as a whole are warming. Moreover, researchers have just identified a rare manufacturing byproduct, SF5 CF3, that represents the most potent greenhouse gas ever detected. The signs of global warming keep accumulating.
It's all so depressing; we must be doomed. Except that in the flood of distressing developments comes a breakthrough. A study led by James Hansen, the director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies in New York, suggests that our basic understanding of greenhouse gases should be overturned -- and that reforms could be more practical and affordable than widely assumed. 
 Until recently, scientists studying global warming focused nearly all their attention on the deleterious effects of carbon dioxide, which is known to trap atmospheric heat. Every year, cars, trucks and power plants release billions of tons of carbon dioxide by burning fossil fuels. Some combination of advanced nuclear energy and clean renewable fuels may eventually change this; but for the next few decades, at least, continued buildup is inevitable. Even the ratification of the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, which would commit industrialized nations to cut greenhouse gas emissions, could not stop carbon dioxide buildup. If the treaty's rules went into effect (no major country has ratified it), rising carbon emissions from the developing world would outweigh any reductions in the West.
Enter Mr. Hansen's team to suggest that focusing on carbon dioxide is a fundamental error. Carbon dioxide is a concern, the study says, but other factors may be equally significant. Black soot from industrial smoke, for example, may turn out to be a leading warming force. (Basically it makes the atmosphere soak up more of the sun's heat, since black absorbs sunlight.) Compounds like SF5 CF3 , may be doing more damage than expected. And most of all, methane, which has far more heat-trapping power than carbon dioxide, may be a much greater greenhouse malefactor than today's scientific models assume.
Here is the beauty of Mr. Hansen's insight. While fossil fuels are an essential, much of the world's methane emissions have no economic utility; they are the unintended byproduct of natural-gas exploration, poor landfill management and gas-pipeline leaks. These sources could be eliminated with little sacrifice to our lifestyle or economic growth. Likewise, rare chemicals like SF5 CF3 , could be controlled without harm to industry.
Black soot emissions have already nearly disappeared from Western industry without any economic harm. Today such soot comes mainly from the developing world, where choking smoke rises from unregulated industry and from unelectrified homes that use fires for cooking and heating.
While regulating smokestack emissions and expanding access to electricity in developing nations would be an expensive undertaking, it would also be a huge boon. Public health as well as the environment would benefit. The World Health Organization says that more children in the developing world die each year from respiratory diseases caused by smoke and soot inhalation than all those who die each year in the United States and the European Union from all causes at all ages.
This breakthrough study of greenhouse gases comes from a guru of the environmental movement. In 1981, Mr. Hansen authored one of the first papers linking rising levels of carbon dioxide to rising global temperatures. Yet much of the environmental movement has greeted the new study with skepticism; many environmentalists worry that any lessening of fears regarding fossil fuels will hurt efforts to reduce global warming.
Rather than grousing about the Hansen study, however, environmentalists should be extolling it as the greatest news in years. First, it revives hope for the Kyoto agreement -- which, at the insistence of State Department negotiators and Vice President Al Gore, contains a little-noticed clause saying that reductions in other greenhouse gas can be substituted for cuts in carbon dioxide. A Kyoto treaty that is fixated on reducing fossil fuel use may never be ratified, but one that goes after methane and SF5 CF3 , seems eminently practical, politically.
Second, Mr. Hansen's study means that even if the Kyoto agreement is never ratified, affordable, realistic steps against global warming could start right away, without economic harm. A warming world need no longer be our destiny. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Personal Spending Rises As Savings Rate Hits a Low

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Personal spending rose in July at twice the pace of incomes as consumers borrowed to make purchases and the savings rate fell to a record low, government figures showed today.
Spending on goods and services rose 0.6 percent last month, the largest increase since a 1.2 percent surge in February, as car and other retail sales increased. In June, spending rose 0.4 percent, the Commerce Department said. Incomes increased 0.3 percent in July after a rise of 0.4 percent the month before. 
 With consumer spending accounting for roughly two-thirds of the nation's output, the increase suggests that consumers will keep the record economic expansion going, even as six interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve since June 1999 appear to be slowing overall growth and helping keep inflation in check.
With unemployment close to a 30-year low, "there is little reason to believe that household confidence won't remain high and that spending won't continue unabated," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
The statistics are the first glimpse of personal consumption for the third quarter. In the previous three months, spending grew at a 2.9 percent annual pace, the slowest in three years. That followed a first quarter in which spending rose at a 7.6 percent rate, the best in 17 years, the Commerce Department said last week.
The personal consumption expenditures price index, a measure of inflation watched closely by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, rose 0.2 percent in July compared with a 0.3 percent gain in June.
As spending exceeded income growth, the savings rate fell to minus 0.2 percent in July -- the lowest since the records started in 1959 -- from 0.1 percent in June.
That means consumers are financing more of their purchases with credit cards or home equity loans. Consumer borrowing rose $12 billion in June after a $14.2 billion May increase, the Fed recently reported. That suggests further slowing in the economy could cause spending to cool along with it.
The savings rate accounts for neither capital gains from investments nor improvement in home values, something which consumers may be counting on to pay for future expenses, like retirement.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1944 words

HEADLINE: Lingering Job Worries Amid a Sea of Plenty;
Trying to Cope With Changing Technology

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho

 BODY:
Gary Taylor was ready to be a free agent. Just as Internet job-search sites and articles in new-economy magazines encourage people to do, Mr. Taylor had decided to quit his job. In this high-desert city of low unemployment and fast growth, Mr. Taylor, a glass installer, thought he could find something much better.
Within six weeks of casting about, Mr. Taylor had an offer from a utility company to work on one of its growing number of temporary projects. And local technology companies had dozens of open jobs. But there seemed to be a problem with every prospect. Either it did not pay enough to support his wife and three children, he said, or it lacked the health-care benefits to cover them. 
 In the end, he stayed in his current line of work, though he found a higher paying job. His wife, meanwhile, went to work part-time as a secretary and insurance sales representative. "There are jobs out there," Mr. Taylor said, "but I found the wages were not high enough for me to switch industries and support a family. At 41 years of age, it's very difficult to step into a new field even in a booming economy."
Mr. Taylor represents the new face of the still-anxious American worker. Economists say few people fret over whether they can find jobs in the 10th year of the nation's longest stretch of uninterrupted economic growth. But many employees say they are concerned about whether they can keep up with technological change and take advantage of opportunities in the sort of new-economy companies that are transforming places like Boise. And many either fear what will happen to their current job or -- like Mr. Taylor -- have looked but did not find another employment opportunity good enough to persuade them to jump.
This new-style job anxiety does not cut as deeply as the pain felt all across what was called the Rust Belt in the 1980's, when waves of blue-collar workers lost jobs as one American industry after another retooled to face heightened foreign competition. And it does not carry the pathos of the early 1990's, when many white-collar employees faced downsizing during and after a recession that led to another round of efficiency-driven cutbacks.
Indeed, the constant turnover in today's job market is exciting for many young, well-educated workers.
But economists say that the lingering uncertainties within the nation's 140-million-strong work force help to explain why wage pressures, while on the upswing, remain more modest than they were in the milder and shorter economic booms of the recent past.
"The evident insecurity felt by workers," Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said recently, echoing similar comments he has made on several occasions, is probably a result of "a fear of job skill obsolescence."
This seems like a strange time for the issue to raise its head. The contradictions of the early years of the 1990's, when consumer spending, corporate profits and share prices all rose rapidly but the median wage was falling, have largely ended. A record percentage of Americans now say they think that jobs are plentiful, and the number of people with the confidence to quit voluntarily has steadily grown since 1996.
But if concerns over the availability of work have receded, worries over the quality of those jobs remain a signature part of the economy for many people. And while Americans acknowledge an abundance of jobs, a surprising number still report that they fear being laid off in the near future. Even in boomtowns like Boise -- with thriving high-technology companies and an unemployment rate of about 3.5 percent compared with the nationwide average of 4 percent -- corporate mergers and constant efforts to increase productivity have left many people uneasy.
All this stands in contrast to the previous record-long expansion in the 1960's. Back then, said Richard Curtin, the director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan, "the only issue with living standards was how fast they would improve."
The current tension between prosperity and insecurity is also playing a role in the presidential campaign, analysts said, as Vice President Al Gore has tried both to claim credit for the economy's strong performance and to soothe traditional Democratic Party constituencies who may not be keeping up with pledges to improve education and health care. George W. Bush, the Republican candidate, faces a similar tension in pushing a broad-based tax cut that is supposed to offer financial relief to the middle class, but that has been attacked as too generous to the wealthy and as an excessive drain on future budget surpluses.
"These times are generally very scary," said Marcia Craig, an executive assistant at Boise Cascade, who had to change jobs last year when her previous employer, Ore-Ida Foods, moved to Pittsburgh. "It seems that no matter what you've done, no matter how long you've done it, there are kids coming out of school that are going to knock your socks off," said Ms. Craig, who is raising two teenage boys.
In fact, a generation gap has emerged at work. Younger employees, particularly those with a strong educational background, often view today's job market as a giant bazaar where their skills are handsomely rewarded.
"My grandmother gets nervous every time I take a new job," said Jill Feeler, 30, who since 1996 has worked for a bank, a hospital and now for Hewlett-Packard, in the marketing department here. "She says, 'What about your pension?' I'm like, 'Pension, shmension. It's 401(k)'s, grandma.' "
Workers like Ms. Feeler, who has both a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A. from Boise State University, say it does not bother them that the bonds between companies and employees have loosened over the last decade. They have a hard time imaging spending 20 years with one employer anyway.
And they are grateful for all the pay raises and job offers many have received. Debra Bell, a recent engineering graduate of Brigham Young University, for instance, moved to Boise this summer with her sister and two friends. All quickly received full-time job offers, Ms. Bell, an engineer at Micron Technology, said, including the two who had not yet graduated from college and were coming to Idaho just for the summer.
For most older workers -- be they carpenters and government employees here who have received scant raises in recent years or bank managers watching their companies merge -- the changes are more unsettling. The message from companies, said Jerry Bresina, an employee of Idaho Power for the last 27 years, is: What you did yesterday is not good enough today.
"That's a tough pill to take," Mr. Bresina said, noting that Idaho Power has sent him to more classes in the last five years than in the previous 20 years altogether.
Mr. Taylor, the glazier, added, "I don't think we're humanly engineered for the stress level." With his wife planning to become a full-time worker this fall, their children can look forward to more "fish-stick and macaroni-and-cheese dinners," he said.
Aggravating the uncertainty, many workers say, are a number of trends that the low unemployment rate does not capture. People are working harder -- per family, three more hours a week than a decade ago, according to the Economic Policy Institute -- complicating other areas of life. And household debt is up while health insurance coverage is down, raising the stakes for people who do leave their jobs.
Boise, Idaho's capital, is a particularly poignant example of the contradictions. An old gold-mining town, Boise has evolved from a city filled with headquarters of manufacturing and food companies to one that boasts Micron, a semiconductor maker, as its largest employer and a Hewlett-Packard office of 4,000 workers.
The city "has transformed itself from a prototypical old-economy area to a new-economy area," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa., which tracks regional statistics.
Help-wanted signs are common, despite an influx of new workers. The local economy, covering a metropolitan area of about 450,000 people, is growing more quickly than the rest of the nation, according to Economy.com. And compared with the rest of Idaho, where agriculture and heavy industry dominate, the city is wealthy and becoming more so.
But there is also churn in Boise. The most telling example may be Ore-Ida, a company that sells potatoes, the region's signature product, to the world and even has Idaho as part of its corporate name. Travelers who step off planes into the small airport here are still greeted by an advertisement for the company. "Welcome to Boise," it says. "A city we've been proud to call home for over a quarter-century!"
In reality, all that is left of Ore-Ida in Idaho -- besides the ad -- are four employees closing up shop in an office just east of downtown. H. J. Heinz, which owns Ore-Ida, has moved it to Pittsburgh over the last two years to combine it with its Weight Watchers frozen-food line to save money. Boise lost some 300 jobs in the process.
It is hardly the only turmoil here. West One Bancorp was bought by U.S. Bancorp in 1995, and First Security is disappearing into Wells Fargo. Hewlett-Packard has shed many of its production jobs but is adding white-collar workers. Albertson's, a fast-growing supermarket company based in Boise, has been trying to integrate its operation with the American Stores Company, which it bought last year.
Across the country, mergers have more than quadrupled in the last decade to about 8,000 a year, according to Mergerstat, leaving jobs in jeopardy in nearly every instance. And corporate relocations have roughly doubled in the last four years, according to Site Selection Magazine in Atlanta.
But to judge from Ore-Ida, losing a job today does not mean what it did a few years ago. Nearly all of the company's former employees seem to have received job offers elsewhere. A surprising number are earning a salary close to their old one, say both the workers and Bae Emilson, a consultant with the outplacement firm Drake Beam Morin that Heinz is paying to help the employees with their job search.
While they say they miss their old colleagues, some even consider Ore-Ida's departure to be a good development. "Almost every single person I know says this is the best thing that has happened to them," Ms. Craig said. Her salary at Boise Cascade is slightly lower than what Ore-Ida was paying her, and her new job as an executive assistant is a notch lower. But she finds the work more creative -- a discovery she suspects she never would have made had she not been laid off.
At the same time, the Ore-Ida alumni agree that few of them will ever feel as secure in their jobs as they once did. That view is common in Boise, not just among those who have had to change jobs but also with those who have only heard about dislocation through friends or the local newspaper.
Ms. Craig said she now keeps her resume updated, especially after Boise Cascade considered eliminating her department only weeks after she arrived. "I have a different attitude," she said.
Miren Lolley, who ran Ore-Ida's information technology department, has decided to use her severance pay to take about a year off after working for the company for 21 years. Then she hopes to become a consultant so she can control her own schedule, leaving time to eat lunch and dinner with her friends and two sons, as she has been able to do since Ore-Ida left.
In the future, Ms. Lolley said, she wants to avoid working long hours for a company without knowing whether her job is secure. "Nobody," she said, "trained us for that."

HEADLINE: Labor Group Plans Housing For Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. will undertake an ambitious effort to create thousands of housing units for middle- and low-income workers, its president announced yesterday.
Denis M. Hughes, the labor federation's president, said many union members were having a hard time finding housing they could afford, notwithstanding a decade-long economic boom. He said the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents more than two million union members, plans to work with nonprofit developers and community and political leaders to create an independent agency that would build housing. 
 "The time has come to gain affordable, safe housing for our members and their families," Mr. Hughes said.
Mr. Hughes said he hoped to name a group of experts to set up and run the agency. He also suggested that money from union pension funds might be used to finance construction of housing units around the state.
Mr. Hughes announced the housing plan during the federation's convention at the Sheraton New York Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, where he was re-elected as the federation's president.
Mr. Hughes also announced an initiative to pressure the State Legislature for a law requiring all employers to give workers at least one day off every week. Many farm workers in upstate New York complain that they often toil up to four weeks in a row without a day off.
Last year, the state labor federation failed to win passage of such a law.
Yesterday, convention delegates also heard from Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic nominee for the Senate.
Mrs. Clinton said that if the union leaders in the audience worked hard to elect her in November, she would work hard to represent the interests of union members.
Mrs. Clinton tailored her speech to the union audience, which responded enthusiastically. She said she wanted tougher job safety laws, more money for the National Labor Relations Board and laws to make it easier to organize more workers.
Mr. Hughes pledged the labor movement's support to Mrs. Clinton.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Chief of MP3.com Testifies in Music Copyright Hearing

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
With his Internet music start-up facing potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in damages for copyright violations, the head of MP3.com told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that he believed he was acting legally when he created an online database of thousands of copyrighted record albums.
The testimony from Michael Robertson, MP3.com's chief executive, came at the first day of hearings in a trial pitting his company, a San Diego-based start-up, against the Seagram Company's Universal Music Group, the world's largest record company. The trial began after negotiations over the weekend failed to produce a settlement. 
 The judge in the case has already ruled that MP3.com infringed upon Universal's copyrights, but the size of the damages in the case will depend on whether the court determines the action was "willful."
Universal and four other major record company sued MP3.com in January, but the other companies have since settled. In the original suit, filed in January, the companies asserted that MP3.com violated their copyrights with the creation of the service called My.MP3.com.
The service created an "online locker," permitting users to store their music albums centrally on MP3.com's computers, then get access to them through various digital devices, like computers or portable music players.
To make the service easy to use, MP3.com did not require users to load their own music into the virtual lockers. Rather, a user had merely to insert a copy of the music into the CD-ROM drive of a computer, at which point, MP3.com would verify that the person had possession of a CD, then the company would automatically put a copy of the music into the person's virtual locker.
MP3.com amassed 65,000 albums to create the database from which it drew its music. However, the record companies, in their lawsuit, asserted that the company had violated their copyrights by creating the digital database of albums to which they held the copyrights. In April, Federal District Judge Jed S. Rakoff found in favor of the record companies, ruling that MP3.com had infringed upon the companies' copyrights.
In the ensuing months, MP3.com reached settlements with four of the major record companies, including Sony Music, Time Warner, the EMI Group and Bertelsmann A.G. Details of the settlements were not made public, but analysts estimated that MP3.com paid $20 million to each company. Eric Scheier, an industry analyst with Forrester Research, speculated that Universal had not yet settled for one or both of two reasons: because as the biggest record company it wants a larger settlement; or because it has intentions to start a competing service with My.MP3.com and does not want to license its content to MP3.com, a provision that has been a component of the settlements with the other record companies.
Universal may not want to license music to "MP3.com or more generally to anybody they don't feel they can control or express a lot of authority over about what kind of business models are going to be used," Mr. Scheier said. A spokesman for Universal Music Group declined to comment. Universal is an investor in MusicBank, a company that has said it plans to start a virtual locker business sometime in the fall.
At yesterday's hearing, Mr. Robertson told the court that he believed the My.MP3.com service was respectful of the record companies' copyrights. "Nothing I had looked at suggested this was illegal use or a copyright violation," he said, according to a report by the Dow Jones news service.
The hearing, which is scheduled to continue through Thursday, will provide the basis for Judge Rakoff to assess damages against MP3.com. People close to the trial said that if the judge decided the action was willful, MP3.com could face damage payments of $750 to $150,000 for each album infringement. If the judge finds the conduct not willful, the damages could range from $750 to $30,000. People familiar with the case said that MP3.com's database included roughly 10,000 albums that are the copyrighted works of Universal.
MP3.com in May suspended the My.MP3.com service, which it said had roughly 500,000 participants.
The hearing comes as the music industry continues to fight on other legal fronts, notably in its battle against Napster, a popular service that permits individual users to exchange music files online. It is a practice the music industry asserts amounts to theft. The industry's case against Napster is being handled in federal court in San Francisco.
