HEADLINE: Cashing In on a New Era of Opulence;
School Seeks Home Buyers Who Want to Live Like Vanderbilts

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Lycee Francais de New York, the prestigious school that attracts Europeans and American Francophiles, is selling all six of its buildings on the Upper East Side.
The school expects to sell the buildings to wealthy people who want to restore them to single-family homes. And the school hopes to make big profit, more than $100 million, on the sale, enough to create an endowment and build a new school. 
 Once considered too costly for private use, town houses are making a comeback as private residences in a new era of opulence that has left investment bankers, Internet entrepreneurs and investors flush with cash from the longest economic boom in history.
Many people are finding it increasingly difficult to afford Manhattan's skyrocketing housing prices, but it appears that there is no limit to what some well-heeled buyers will pay to restore the wood-paneled libraries, grand staircases, marble fireplaces and bedrooms of the fancy old houses, which had been carved into apartments, retail stores, museums and school buildings during the last 70 years. And with names like Vanderbilt, Gould, Pulitzer and McKim, Mead & White embedded in the schools buildings, brokers expect a rash of bidders.
"Many of these properties are going to be bought by private individuals, Wall Street money," said Jed Garfield, a broker at Leslie J. Garfield & Company, which specializes in town house sales. "There's no question that the dollars in private purchasers' pockets today are deeper than those of the institutions. It's an end of an era for some of these institutional buildings."
In the first six months of this year, the average price for a town house on the West Side climbed 34 percent to $2.9 million. During the same period, houses on the Upper East Side sold for $4.4 million, or $814 a square foot, up 19 percent from a year ago, according to the Corcoran Group. In contrast, the average price of a condominium on the Upper East Side is $673 a square foot.
Although it is rare that six houses would come on the market at once, real estate brokers said that the school's portfolio was not expected to dampen prices, because there are so few buildings available.
In June, an investment banker who took early retirement from Goldman Sachs paid $5 million for the town house at 25 East 92nd Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. The house had been divided into five condominiums. The buyer plans to knock down the walls and make a home for his family.
Last month, Benny Shabtai, president of Raymond Weil-Seville Watch Corporation, paid $8.2 million for the town house at 870 Park Avenue, between 77th and 78th Streets. The house has a three-story atrium, fireplaces, a library and a spiral staircase leading to five bedrooms.
This year, the architect Emilio Ambasz put a $23 million price tag on his five-story Beaux-Arts house at 8 East 62nd Street, near Fifth Avenue. He bought it eight years ago for $3.2 million.
Elsa Berry, who heads the board at Lycee Francais, said it was hard to part with the school's six illustrious old buildings, which sit in two clusters on the Upper East Side and serve 1,000 students.
But, she said, the buoyant real estate market provided the school with an opportunity to create an endowment and to build a new and more efficient, if less historic, school building at a single location. The school is negotiating to buy a site on either the Upper East Side or the Upper West Side for a 115,000-square-foot school building, nearly double the current space. According to one broker, the school is close to a deal for a site in the East 80's.
"We're trying to improve our operations from a technological standpoint and add new facilities for sports, student lounges and a cafeteria," said Ms. Berry, who attended the Lycee Francais as a girl and now runs the corporate finance department for BNP Paribas, a French investment bank. "The board is working aggressively on a long-term strategic plan."
Many small institutions and private schools like the Lycee Francais in Manhattan are land rich but cash poor. The school's plan allows it to tap into its biggest asset. Richard Speciale, a managing partner at Aequitas, a real estate investment firm, is advising the school on its financial plan. He said that after selling the buildings, the school would make the annual payments on a tax-exempt bond for a new school from tuition payments and interest from the endowment fund.
Lycee Francais was founded in 1935 by Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, the French consul general at the time; Forsythe Wicks, a businessman who was president of the Alliance Francaise; and Paul Windels Sr., the city's corporation counsel. The school's alumni include Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Michel David-Weil, managing partner of Lazard Freres & Company, and Danielle Steel, the novelist.
Designed to be similar to a French lycee, the school emphasizes a classical education, including Latin and Greek. Instruction is primarily in French, although the school does provide an understanding of American language and culture. Ms. Berry said that 40 percent of the school's students are the children of French diplomats or business executives, and 40 percent are American, with 48 other nationalities accounting for the rest.
Paul J. Massey Jr., a partner at Massey Knakal Realty Services, who is handling the sale of the Lycee Francais buildings, said that he expected at least half of them to be sold to house buyers. "People are astounded that this many buildings would come on the market at once," he said. "There's a pattern that's been building for 10 years of people reclaiming these buildings."
The most valuable building owned by the lycee is the Henry T. Sloane residence at 9 East 72nd Street, which is regarded by architects as one of the finest Beaux-Arts town houses in the city. The landmark five-story structure, which has an intricately carved limestone facade, Ionic columns and French windows, was built in 1896 by Sloane, son of the founder of the W.& J. Sloane furniture store. But he lived there only briefly before a scandalous divorce in 1898.
Joseph Pulitzer, the newspaper publisher, lived there before it was bought in 1901 by James Stillman, president of the National City Bank, then one of the most important commercial banks in the world. Mr. Stillman worked closely with William Rockefeller, a founder of Standard Oil, and Jacob H. Schiff and Edward H. Harriman in reorganizing American railroads.
But starting in the late 1920's, most tycoons abandoned such luxurious town houses for more fashionable estates in the Long Island and Westchester countryside or for duplexes on Park and Fifth Avenues. Too costly to maintain, the buildings were demolished or converted into apartments, stores or museums. In the course of the conversions, many of the original details and fixtures were lost to history, although the lycee's buildings remain in relatively good shape.
"It doesn't matter," Mr. Garfield said. "Most people are gut-renovating everything anyway."
The lycee is also selling the Oliver Gould Jennings mansion, a Beaux-Arts house next door at 7 East 72nd Street, named after the man who built it in 1899 who was a director of Bethlehem Steel and the National Fuel Gas Company.
The third property, at 60 East 93rd Street, was built in 1931 for Virginia Graham Fair Vanderbilt, a racehorse breeder and former wife of William Vanderbilt, the railroad tycoon. Her father was Senator James Fair of Nevada, who made a fortune from the Comstock Lode and the Big Bonanza mine. The limestone building resembles a French hotel during the reign of Louis XV and once housed the Romanian Mission to the United Nations. Each of the voussoirs, or wedge-shaped stones in the arches, has the face of a different woman carved into it.
The fourth site is a neo-Classical-style limestone building with a mansard roof at 3 East 95th Street. It resembles a Parisian town house and was commissioned by Marion B. Carhart, after the death of her husband, Amory S. Carhart, a banking and railroad executive. She died shortly after its completion, in 1917. The school is also selling the adjoining three-story building at 5 East 95th Street and a limestone building at 12 East 73rd Street that was built in 1920 by Henry Allan Jacobs.
"These are beautiful buildings," Ms. Berry said, "but the huge hallways and grand staircases are not suited for a modern school."
In the end, one former student and some brokers lamented, the school may well lose some of the cachet of old New York as it moves to a modern home.
"You get a sense of history going to school in mansions," Mr. Garfield said. "But I'm sure the new building will be more efficient."

HEADLINE: REPUBLICAN LEADER MAKES CONCESSION ON MINIMUM WAGE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT with LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert today offered significant concessions to Democrats on a plan to raise the federal minimum wage, moving to end months of stalemate on a popular bill that Republicans feared could damage them at the polls.
The House and Senate earlier this year approved an increase in the minimum wage by $1 to $6.15 an hour, with the increase coming in 50-cent increments over two years in the House version and smaller annual amounts over three years in the Senate bill. The conflicting bills then stalled in the conference committee that was supposed to reconcile them, raising fears among some Republicans that they they were handing Democrats a potent campaign issue. 
 In a letter to President Clinton today, Mr. Hastert sought to take that threat off the table. He agreed to the Democrats' demands to spread the $1 increase over two years, but insisted on $76 billion in tax cuts for small business over 10 years to help these companies pay "the costs of this wage increase."
In another concession, Mr. Hastert proposed dropping pension provisions and a repeal of the estate tax that were attached to the minimum wage bill by House Republicans and that Democrats had criticized as a giveaway to wealthy Americans. Both of these provisions, however, have moved through the Congress on separate tracks and now must be dealt with on their own.
"It is very clear that a vast majority of congressional Democrats and Republicans would like to see a balanced approach before we adjourn," Mr. Hastert said.
Mr. Hastert's proposal makes the minimum wage, in effect, the opening issue among Democrats and Republicans in Congress when they return next week from their late-summer recess.
White House officials and Democratic leaders in Congress expressed cautious optimism that both parties would agree in the next month to raise the minimum wage for the first time since 1996. Officials signaled that a compromise could be reached on the Republican insistence on the small-business tax cuts.
"If at long last the Republicans are serious about dropping many of their roadblocks to a $1 increase over two years, then that's good news," Gene Sperling, head of the White House's National Economic Council, said in an interview. "There still remain some obstacles, but the president stands ready to work in good faith with Congress to get a bill he can sign."
Mr. Hastert's letter reflects his desire to turn a political liability into a virtue in time for the fall elections.
The initiative for the minimum wage offer came from Mr. Hastert and reflects how House Republicans feel more politically vulnerable on the issue than their Senate counterparts. Mr. Hastert said that Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, shared his views, but only the speaker signed the letter.
A spokesman for Senator Lott, John Czwartacki, said he had not seen Mr. Hastert's letter but added, "Senator Lott supports moving the minimum wage increase as long as it's tied to small-business tax relief."
In another sign that Mr. Hastert is seeking to secure his legislative gains for the bruising fall elections, the speaker is also paring back on the tax-cut proposals that he will press for, cuts for married couples and retirement savings.
Mr. Hastert's offer comes just days after Governor George W. Bush found himself defending his proposed tax cut, and admitting that he needed to do a better job of promoting it.
Scott McClellan, a spokesman for the Bush campaign, said the Texas governor supported a $1-an-hour increase in the minimum wage although he did not know if Mr. Bush supported the specific details in the compromises being discussed by Mr. Hastert and the Democrats.
Congressional Democrats greeted Mr. Hastert's offer cautiously, and seemed tempted to milk even more political mileage out of his political predicament.
"The proposal that the speaker made was in the right direction," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the second-ranking House Democrat and a sponsor with Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts of the Democrats' original $1-over-two-years bill.
The Republicans "are high on the tax relief side and low on the benefit to minimum-wage workers," Mr. Bonior added, "but it is my view that we can work this out and we can get a bill by sometime next month."
Mr. Bonior noted that the current minimum wage, $5.15 an hour, has lost purchasing power in the more than two years since since he and Mr. Kennedy first asked Congress for the additional $1 increase.
The $5.15 would have to rise by 24 cents to restore its 1998 purchasing power, according to an estimate furnished by Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute. The minimum wage reached its greatest purchasing power in 1968 when it was worth the equivalent of $7.49 in 1999 dollars.
Before Mr. Hastert beat them to the punch, going public with the Republican proposal, the Democrats had been discussing a revision of their original bill, one that would increase the minimum wage by more than $1. The aim was partly to restore the lost purchasing power and partly to answer the Republican insistence on raising the wage over three years instead of over two.
Mr. Hastert's proposal of a $76 billion tax cut for small business drew criticism from Mr. Bonior, who said that it was almost four times greater than the $20 billion in tax relief that the Republicans had sought in 1996, the last time Congress approved a minimum wage increase.
The Republican proposal would also remove from minimum wage coverage some workers now covered by the law.
"After three years of foot-dragging, Republicans appear ready to sign on to a wage increase for the lowest paid workers," Senator Kennedy said. "But their proposal is loaded with poison pills and oversized tax breaks for the wealthy."
Some House Republicans, however, criticized Mr. Hastert for compromising at all. "I've never been in favor of bargaining on the minimum wage," said Representative John Shadegg, an Arizona Republican who voted against the wage increase in March. "The package does not give businesses anywhere near the relief they're going to need."
In his weekly radio address on July 29, just before the Republican National Convention, Mr. Clinton appealed to Republicans to break the wage impasse.
"If Republican leaders really want to make their compassion count, they ought to join me in getting back to business and raising the minimum wage," Mr. Clinton said.
An increase in the minimum wage, to $6.15 an hour, would affect 10.1 million workers who now earn between $5.15 an hour and $6.14, and millions more who earn up to $6.70 an hour and would enjoy raises to maintain their margin over the new minimum wage, economists say.
Two-thirds of the 10.1 million directly affected workers are over age 20, often a family's principal earners, while one-third are teenagers. When Congress voted in 1996 to raise the minimum in two annual steps, to $5.15 an hour on Sept. 1, 1997, from $4.25, there was much concern that millions of low wage workers would lose their jobs because they lacked enough skills to justify higher pay.
But the 1996 increases came just as the economy began to boom, and the unemployment rate, instead of rising, fell steadily. Now, the concern over job loss is muted, the argument being that the strong economy is raising the pay of low-skilled workers anyway.
"The modest proposal people are talking about -- $1 over two years -- is pretty close to what would happen anyway in the marketplace," said Kevin Murphy, a labor economist at the University of Chicago, who had argued in 1996 that the proposed increase in the minimum wage, to $5.15 an hour, would cost jobs.

HEADLINE: Bridgestone Asks Venezuelan Dealers to Return Some Tires

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 28

 BODY:
Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. announced this evening that it had asked its dealers in Venezuela to return unsold 15- and 16-inch light truck tires made there, but the company rebuffed the Ford Motor Company's request for a recall of identical tires already in use in Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador.
In May, Ford recalled its Ford Explorer and F-series pickup trucks equipped with the tires in all three countries, and the automaker said today that it had urged Bridgestone to recall other manufacturers' sport utility vehicles that use the same tires. Ford also scheduled a news conference on Tuesday in Caracas, Venezuela, to explain why the automaker thought that tire-related crashes of Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles in Venezuela had solely been a result of defective tires and not because of any excessive tendency of Explorers to roll over. 
 Jon Harmon, a Ford spokesman, said that Ford had cut open Firestone tires returned during the recall in Venezuela and found that many lacked a protective layer of nylon or were unable to withstand high-speed driving.
Bridgestone said that problems with its tires were limited to a mislabeling of their sidewalls and insisted that the tires met Ford specifications. According to Ford, some of the mislabeled tires said that they had the nylon layer when they did not, while some tires were missing speed ratings entirely. None of the tires made in Venezuela were shipped to the United States, Ford and Bridgestone said.
The tire maker said that a broader recall was unnecessary and that it was a coincidence that the mislabeled 15-inch tires in Venezuela were the same size as the tires being recalled in the United States because the treads occasionally come off during high-speed driving.
Toyota, which used some of the tires on Toyota Land Cruisers sold in Venezuela, said that it had not received any reports of problems and did not think a broader recall was necessary.
Jorge Dominguez, a senior investigator at the Institute for Consumer Protection and Education in Venezuela, said that the agency was convinced that Ford was partly responsible for a problem that had caused more than 60 deaths in Venezuela. "We have documentary evidence," he said. "The responsibility is shared."
Among the agency's piles of evidence, he said, were communications between the two companies as well as stickers that Ford put on its vehicles showing a lower recommended tire pressure than Firestone favored.
"If the tire manufacturer said the tire should be inflated to 32 pounds pressure, they put on their stickers that it should be 26 to 28 pounds," Mr. Dominguez said. "We even have photos of the crashed vehicles showing these stickers in place."
Ford and Firestone have only recently differed in public in the United States over the recommended tire pressure. Ford has long favored 26 pounds a square inch. Firestone, after 10 years of acquiescing to this number, abruptly announced at the beginning of its recall in the United States on Aug. 9 that the pressure should be 30 pounds a square inch.
Tires inflated to a fairly low pressure can overheat and come apart at high speeds. Virtually all of the deaths in the United States have occurred when sport utility vehicles, mostly Explorers, have rolled over when their tires failed.
Tire makers tend to prefer higher pressures because it reduces the risk of failure for the tires, which are covered by the tire makers' warranties. But higher-pressure tires increase the risk that sport utility vehicles will roll over during other driving situations without tire failure.
A Ford memorandum distributed by plaintiffs' lawyers in the United States showed that Ford rejected higher-pressure tires on a prototype of the Explorer because they tended to cause rollovers. Ford ended up choosing a different, lower-pressure tire and a different suspension.
Ford says that rollovers are the main cause of crash deaths for occupants of all brands of midsize sport utility vehicles. Explorer occupants have a lower death rate in rollovers and over all than do occupants of other midsize sport utility models, according to Ford safety officials.
In TV commercials that began showing tonight, Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, emphasized that Ford had one of the best safety records, according to government data for the last 10 years.
George Pipas, a Ford market analyst, said today that Ford's sales in the United States in August would be roughly equal to last year's levels and only slightly below the company's early projections, a shortfall that he said might reflect response to the tire recall but also a somewhat slower economy and a highly competetive market.
Mr. Harmon said that Ford had not found protective nylon layers in 71 percent of the 15-inch tires from Venezuela that it cut open, nor in 55 percent of the 16-inch tires. Automakers commonly specify that tire makers include nylon for vehicles to be sold in South America because of the poor roads and because drivers frequently go extremely fast in the absence of enforced speed limits, Mr. Harmon said. The tires also failed before reaching 112 miles an hour on a dynanometer, a speed they were supposed to be able to withstand, particularly because the Explorer's engine has a computer that limits speed to 99 miles an hour, he added.
Ford has been criticized by plaintiffs' lawyers for not having Firestone include the nylon layers on Explorer tires for the United States market. Because of the good roads in the United States, manufacturers rarely use the layers except for very high-speed models like the Chevrolet Corvette sports car.
Bridgestone hinted in a letter today to the Venezuelan consumer agency that Ford might not have asked for nylon layers until recently. The letter said that Ford had specified in 1999 that the nylon be included and that nylon had been included since then. The tires in question have been produced since 1996, and the Bridgestone letter did not say whether the earlier tires had the nylon, nor were officials willing to elaborate.
Mr. Harmon said that Ford had always asked for the nylon. "Firestone specified a nylon ply to meet Ford's performance specifications from the beginning of Ford's Explorer sales in Venezuela," he said.
The Firestone tires in Venezuela, as in the United States, bear no external signs that the entire tread may come off an inner layer of rubber. Yet Ford engineers who cut apart the tires from Venezuela found that they were 100 to 1,000 times as likely to show early signs of tread separation as even the recalled Firestone tires in the United States, said a person who had seen the results.
Four investigators for the House Commerce Committee visited Bridgestone's United States headquarters in Nashville today seeking evidence on what the company knew about its American tires and when.

HEADLINE: Arts Center, Aided by Albany, Is to Rise on Woodstock Festival Site

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the state would help finance plans for a new performing arts and music center on the site of the original Woodstock festival in Bethel, N.Y.
Mr. Pataki was to appear today with the developer, Alan Gerry, at the festival site to unveil a proposal for the $40 million center, to which the state would contribute $15 million. It would be the first permanent structure built on the gently sloping hillside that once served as Max Yasgur's alfalfa field and, more famously, as the amphitheater for the August 1969 festival, a defining moment for many Americans. 
 Mr. Gerry, 71, who built his television antenna business into one of the largest cable television operations in the country, bought the original concert site's 37 acres on the Yasgur farm in 1997, and has since spoken of creating a tourist attraction and shrine to the Sixties counterculture there.
He said the arts center would stage a variety of theater, dance and music performances, from classical to rock, in a 4,000-seat indoor theater that could be partly opened to accommodate an additional 15,000 spectators sitting on the back lawn. He said that ground would be broken next spring and that the center would open in the summer of 2003.
"We feel it's one of the few things that Sullivan County has to offer that has brand recognition and is known worldwide," said Mr. Gerry, a lifelong resident of the county who has created a multimillion-dollar foundation to promote economic and cultural development there. "It's a natural franchise and no one can take it away from us."
The new arts center, which has not yet been named, is intended to attract thousands of tourists and help revive the Catskills, a struggling area whose fortunes have declined along with its grand resort hotels. In recent years, county officials and residents have tried to draw weekend visitors and other tourists by supporting proposals for at least two Indian-run casinos and building a $4 million corporate office park for high-tech and start-up companies.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Pataki said he hoped the Woodstock center would evolve into a cultural institution like the Saratoga Performing Arts Center or Tanglewood in the Berkshire Mountains of Massachusetts. The $15 million in state money, which will come from discretionary funds controlled by Mr. Pataki and the Legislature, will be used for the construction of the theater and for road and land improvements. The state will not have any ownership of the new project, but invested the money to spur the sagging economy of the area, the governor said.
"I think it will be a great facility for the Catskills," Mr. Pataki said. "They have always been one of the tourism centers for New York and they have lost that over the years."
Mr. Pataki said that as a 23-year-old law student, he had to stay home to tend his parents' farm while his friends went to the original Woodstock festival. Since then, he said, he has wanted to attend a concert there.
"This kind of makes up for that," he said. "I wasn't at Woodstock but I loved the music and it's going to be great to go up there. I love the Stones, but the fact is, the Band is my all-time favorite."
The Band, which gained fame as a backup band for Bob Dylan, was one of the many groups that played at the Woodstock festival. Levon Helm, the drummer and singer for the Band, who also lives nearby, will join Mr. Pataki at the site today for the announcement of the center.
Mr. Gerry bought the 37 acres for roughly $1 million in 1997, and later acquired more than 1,300 surrounding acres for an undisclosed price. Mr. Gerry, who did not attend the original Woodstock festival, said the idea of preserving the site came from his daughter, Robyn, who makes a pilgrimage there every summer.
Mr. Gerry staged two festivals at the site in 1998 and 1999 by building a temporary metal stage and importing lights and sewage lines. More than 60,000 people went to the first concert, which included performers like Joni Mitchell and Pete Townshend, and 35,000 more attended the following year to see Britney Spears and other stars. They paid $19 to $65 for tickets, but Mr. Gerry said the concerts lost money because of the expense involved for setup.
Many Sullivan county officials and residents praised the planned Woodstock center yesterday. Harvey Smith, the acting county manager, said it would bring a needed influx of customers for nearby hotels, restaurants, and stores, and also contribute to an active arts community that already stages classical music concerts, operas and plays for the county's 70,000 residents as well as summer visitors.
In addition, Mr. Smith said, the county is used to coping with large crowds because of its past as a resort area. "As someone said to me, "Happiness is a traffic jam," Mr. Smith said. "I think there's enough infrastructure here for what's planned and I'm sure there will be enhancements. We are absolutely looking forward to this kind of economic activity. It's clean, and very positive."
But beyond the hoped-for economic benefits, the Woodstock center seeks to transform what was once a makeshift concert ground into a place where people can bring their families, relive their memories, or simply find out what the fuss was all about. Even today, many people still walk through the meadows to a monument that commemorates the 1969 Woodstock festival.
"They come from all over the world," Mr. Gerry said. "This site is on so many people's calendars that it's become a historic site."

HEADLINE: Clinton, Visiting Tanzania, Calls for Peace in Burundi

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: ARUSHA, Tanzania, Aug. 28

 BODY:
President Clinton had hoped to witness the signing of a major peace deal and cease-fire among the warring factions in Burundi, but negotiations to end the country's seven-year civil war bogged down today when some Tutsi minority parties refused to sign an accord with the Hutu majority.
Former South African President Nelson Mandela, who is brokering the peace talks, delivered a blistering attack on the Tutsi parties for backing out of an agreement and turning their backs on "the slaughter of innocent people inside Burundi." Mr. Mandela had invited Mr. Clinton and leaders from about a dozen African nations to the resort town of Arusha for the signing by Hutu rebels and the Tutsi-dominated government. 
 But when it became clear that a major agreement would not be reached by today's deadline, Mr. Clinton instead used the occasion to plead for peace among the Tutsi and Hutu.
"If you don't do it, what is the price?" the president asked. "If you don't do it, what is the chance that the progress you have made will unravel? If you come back in 5 to 10 years, will the issues change? The gulf between you will not narrow, but the gulf between Burundi and the rest of the world will grow greater if you let this moment slip away."
Mr. Clinton winds up a four-day trip to Africa early Tuesday morning after a meeting in Cairo with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak. Mr. Clinton, eager for lasting foreign policy achievements in the final five months of his presidency, is struggling to build support among Arabs for a breakthrough deal between the Israelis and Palestinians.
The peace accord for Burundi that Mr. Mandela has been promoting during the last two years calls for an eventual return of power to the Hutu majority -- who make up nearly 85 percent of the population -- but with guaranteed protections for the Tutsi. Today's agreement, signed by only some of the parties, fell considerably short of even an end to hostilities.
Mr. Mandela criticized the Burundi president, Pierre Buyoya, in particular, for denying that he is holding political prisoners, who Mr. Mandela said are being "treated worse than animals" in Burundi jails.
Complicating the talks is the sheer number of parties involved -- 19 in all. They include 10 Tutsi political parties, 7 Hutu parties, the Tutsi-dominated army and the Burundi government. Two significant Hutu rebel groups are boycotting the talks.
"No one can force peace," Mr. Clinton told the Burundians."You must choose it."
The civil war in Burundi, which has claimed 200,000 lives and forced more than a million people from their homes, dates to 1993, when Tutsi paratroopers assassinated the first president from the Hutu majority, Melchior Ndadaye. Ethnic violence between the Tutsi and Hutu has flared in Burundi since it won independence from Belgium in 1962.
On the first trip by a United States president to Tanzania, Mr. Clinton told a welcoming party at the airport that "we still share your sorrow" over the 1998 terrorist bombing of the American Embassy in Dar es Salaam.
"I believe the terrorists went after Tanzania, Kenya and the United States precisely because we are dedicated to tolerance, understanding and cooperation across frontiers and lines of division," he said. "They took a lot of our loved ones, but they failed utterly to deter us from advancing our common principles."
Tens of thousands of people gathered along the highway waving green tree branches and flags at Mr. Clinton's passing motorcade.
Mr. Clinton signed an agreement with President Benjamin W. Mkapa of Tanzania that will give airlines in each country access to airports in the other, an "open skies agreement" that officials hope will increase passenger travel and commerce between the two nations.
In brief remarks, Mr. Clinton said that Tanzania should be thankful it has avoided many of the crises that have focused the world's attention on other parts of Africa.
"Because you have avoided headlines about repression, famine and war, and instead focused on the steady progress of democracy and development, being generous to your neighbors, and being a cause of peace and cooperation across the region, too many people in our country do not know enough about your country," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Finger Lakes Winery Gets Federal Grant

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
An organic winery on the east shore of Seneca Lake in upstate New York will look for nonchemical ways to control one of the most damaging pests in Finger Lakes vineyards.
Under a research grant from the United States Department of Agriculture, the Silver Thread Winery in Lodi, N.Y., will work against the grape leafhopper, which feeds on grape leaves and interferes with ripening and photosynthesis. 
 The owner of Silver Thread, Richard Figiel, said leafhoppers are typically controlled by chemical sprays. However, over time, the leafhopper can develop a resistance and actually increase in population. The chemical sprays also can kill off good bugs that could prey on the leafhoppers.
The project at Silver Thread will use a battery of organic techniques, including botanical sprays, agricultural soaps and releasing lacewings, beneficial insects that make meals of leafhoppers. By carefully timing use of these techniques to the leafhoppers' life cycle, Mr. Figiel hopes the pests can be controlled effectively and economically without using chemical sprays.
Silver Thread received one of 63 grants given throughout the Northeast. The department's Sustainable Agriculture Research and Education program was established in the 1980's to encourage farmers to experiment with agricultural practices that minimize the impact on the ecosystem.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Major Market Gauges Gain, Flirting With Record Highs

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Major stock market gauges crept close to record levels yesterday.
Led by American Express and General Motors, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 60.21 points, or 0.5 percent, to 11,252.84. The gain put the blue-chip index less than 30 points from its April 11 high of 11,287.08. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also neared record levels, climbing 7.64 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,514.09. Gains in EMC, General Electric and Oracle pulled the index higher. Its peak of 1,527.46 was set on March 24.
The Nasdaq composite index rose for the 10th time in the last 12 sessions, gaining 27.91 points, or 0.7 percent, to 4,070.59. The advance put the Nasdaq ahead for the year.
So far this year, the Nasdaq is up 0.03 percent; the S.& P. 500 is up 3.1 percent; and the Dow is down 2.1 percent.
With many traders on vacation, volume was light. On the New York Stock Exchange, some 733.6 million shares changed hands.
"You love to see an up market, but with the volume as poor as it is, it is difficult to tell what it means," said Ned Collins, head trader at Daiwa Securities America.
With activity at a fairly low ebb, Mr. Collins and other traders said there were no real problems with the introduction of decimalization on 13 listed stocks. But they said a bigger challenge could well come at the end of next month, when a much larger group of stocks is scheduled to be quoted in pennies instead of fractions.
"It's hard to draw any earth-shattering conclusions," said Michael Clark, head of global stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "There is a reason they decided to introduce this in late summer, when the volumes are low."
Among Dow stocks, American Express rose $3.38, to $59.94 a share. I.B.M. gained $1.63, to $130.63, after an analyst from Credit Suisse First Boston said the stock could reach $150 a share over the next 12 months. G.M. gained $3.06, to $74.50.
Intel, Microsoft and Cisco Systems, were the most actively traded issues yesterday.
Intel gained 94 cents, to $73.88; Microsoft rose 69 cents, to $71.31; and Cisco Systems closed at $66.06, up 56 cents.
Yahoo was a big decliner among technology stocks.
The stock plunged $12.19, to $122.06, after an analyst at Lehman Brothers said problems for Yahoo, the largest Internet search company, continued to worsen because of sluggish advertising revenue growth.
But it was a very good day for brokerage firms and financial services stocks.
Merrill Lynch rose $3.09, to $140.47; Lehman Brothers jumped $3.44, to $137.25; Goldman Sachs closed at $122, up $2.63; and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette gained $4.69, to $65.81.
"Leadership has clearly shifted to sectors that are interest rate sensitive," said Jim Paulson, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management. "I think we are going to new highs."

HEADLINE: An Escape to Eden On Vancouver Island

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SOOKE, British Columbia

 BODY:
SINCLAIR AND FREDERIQUE PHILIP make an unlikely pair. She comes from Cannes, on the lush Cote d'Azur; he grew up on the spare Canadian plains. He likes fish; she likes meat. He is reserved, ironic and intellectual, an international economist by trade; she has an earth-motherly warmth.
Yet, together they took a white clapboard house, built in 1928 on a lonely promontory on timber-clad Vancouver Island, facing the Strait of Juan de Fuca and the Olympic Mountains of Washington State beyond it, and in 21 years turned the place into an enticing and idiosyncratic retreat for epicures. 
 Today, Sooke Harbour House is one of Canada's half-dozen best restaurants, and it has a kitchen garden unlike any other in North America -- more than two acres of herbs, vegetables and edible flowers, many of them rarities, gradually devouring the lawns around the house, tumbling down to the sea, scaling hillsides in every direction, a living tapestry of leaf, shrub and color.
Tuberous begonias with blossoms the size of dinner plates fill baskets and window boxes, and a few petals are plucked each day to flavor the mignonette sauce served with freshly opened local oysters. A climbing fig twines around a dining alcove and provides fruit in the fall. Aromatic lemon verbena and jaunty nasturtiums grow in profusion close to the house, adding a sweet scent and flashes of bright color to the many pleasures of Sooke. Herbal teas are made from verbena, and nasturtium blossoms enliven salads.
Bergamot and borage flowers, two Philip favorites, will not soon supplant salt and pepper, but they and other products of the garden contribute not only subtle flavors but also an element of surprise to the menu, helping to accomplish the mission of serving only seasonal, organic food produced or harvested in British Columbia. People come here, Mr. Philip told me, "for the Canadian experience," whether they come from Canada, the American Northwest or farther afield.
So you will find no caviar and no mangoes at Sooke Harbour House, because none are produced in the province. But I'll wager you won't miss them -- not with line-caught sockeye salmon, trap-caught black cod and Dungeness crab fished out of the waters of Sooke Inlet; not with roast leg of suckling kid raised by a local farmer and lobster mushrooms and chanterelles foraged in the rain forest; not with West Coast mussels, plus marine exotica like gooseneck barnacles and limpets, all of them gathered by hand from rock-strewn beaches nearby.
"No matter where I go," said Edward Tuson, the 36-year-old head chef, "Nepal and India, Malaysia, Vancouver, I end up coming back here. I have total freedom, as long as I play by Sinclair's rules and keep it local. I invent something, fuss with it, change the menu every day. There's this fabulous garden, there's a network of farmers, and I have a fisherman who wakes me at 8, 8:30, every morning, calling to tell me what's best in the day's catch."
Close to 100 people eat here each night, in two big, alabaster-white dining rooms, one with a huge fireplace, both with big windows framing the vista of sea and sky. The rooms are decorated with the work of local artists, commissioned by Mrs. Philip (and with whimsical gifts from grateful diners: people send miniature hats -- straw for summer, wool for winter -- for the duck decoys on the mantlepiece).
Candles burn in the chandeliers. The window in one door is shaped like a crab. Like the whole place, the dining rooms are casual, unpretentious, very much in harmony with the rugged surroundings, but totally professional.
Self-taught the key players may be, but this is no amateur hour.
MR. AND MRS. PHILIP met in 1967 at a party in Nice given by a friend of hers. He had just arrived from Canada, to work on his French before heading to Africa. He never got there. They lived in Aix-en-Provence for a while, then at Grenoble, where he studied economics, and then in Toronto. On a business trip, he came upon Sooke Harbour House and decided to buy it.
For 16 years, the Philips lived in the basement with their children and worked upstairs. Making the place go took a kind of manic concentration and energy, and three years ago, just when they had almost paid off the mortgage, but not quite, they took out a new, bigger one to expand the inn to 28 bedrooms. He is now 53, she 52, and the staff, all recruited locally, has grown from three to 80.
"Sinclair," Mrs. Philip said, "does his research on anything the same way as he did the research for his Ph.D. at Grenoble, so when he decided to start the garden, he read everything in print on herbs and edible flowers."
Many of the choicest things Mr. Philip grows were brought here, in the form of seed or seedlings from commercial nurseries. That is the case with the tiny, seductively perfumed woodland strawberries the French call fraises des bois, as well as the Mabel Grey geraniums from South Africa, whose leaves have a lemon-lime scent -- a little like Sprite.
But he has learned a lot from the Northwest Indian tribes that have lived on Vancouver Island since time immemorial and from people who study them, like Nancy Turner, an ethnobotanist at the University of British Columbia. They taught him about cooking with the tender young needles of the fir tree and about many of the sea creatures that live on the beaches and in the tidal pools. One of the inn's most talented foragers is Carol Planes, an Indian, who regularly clambers down slippery rocks to gather shellfish.
"These people have been eating this stuff forever," Mr. Philip said. "You listen to them, and you learn."
Early clients blanched at things they were offered to eat. Mr. Philip remembers people asking, "How can you eat those bitter greens?" Mrs. Philip was often asked to taste a dish first, in a customer's presence, to demonstrate that it was actually edible.
You still see perplexed looks on people's faces when they sit down to their first meal and read a menu entry like this one: "Gooseneck barnacle terrine with grand fir and calendula petal emulsion, bull kelp pickle and sea cucumber." But they soon learn that weird as it may sound, it tastes like the very essence of the sea. It tastes like Japan. It tastes very good.
With it and the other inventive dishes on the menu come wines from a 91-page list -- wines from France and Australia and Italy, Germany and California and Oregon, including runs of older vintages of Stag's Leap Cask 23 and Silver Oak cabernet sauvignons; Grange shiraz from South Australia and choice, scarce Leonettis from Washington. On top of that, there are intriguing wines from Vancouver Island itself, as well as the Okanagan Valley, British Columbia's premier viticultural area.
But the magic of Sooke Harbour House lies in more than its table and its cellar. The setting is remarkable, with fog and mist swirling in from the sea, sometimes lying like a duvet on the harbor. Clearing and clouding over several times a day, the sky first reveals and then obscures the mountains, like some cosmic theatrical curtain rising and falling. And all the while, sea lions and orca whales frolic offshore while ospreys and loons circle overhead.
The rooms, each different, each decorated with Indian and other local art, are the spacious balcony seats for this spectacle. Most have fireplaces and refrigerators; each gets its ration of two big sugar cookies every day.
It is the kind of place that defies a person to get or stay uptight. I went planning to catch up on some reading and writing, but I failed.
One of the Philip daughters, Nishka, 19, gave me a running commentary one morning when I tagged along behind her as she gathered flower petals.
"This," she said, pointing to some chivelike stems topped with purple flowers, "is called 'society' garlic, because it's not supposed to get on your breath or anything. But I have my doubts, eh? These orange flowers you see everywhere are pot marigolds, or calendulas. They bloom all year, throughout the calendar, which is where they get their name. The breakfast people put them in cheese biscuits, to make the biscuits taste twice as cheesy. Long ago, they were used to color Cheddar."
Who would guess where flavors lurk in the garden? Day lily flowers go into sorbet, carnation petals are added to salads, and sweet woodruff, an herb with a perky white flower, long used by Central Europeans in wine punches, is used at Sooke in ice cream.
No culinary use has been found yet for the passionflower vine that grows along the eaves on one side of the house. It is a pet of Nishka's, not only because of its pretty, complex purple-blue flowers, but also because it spreads so exuberantly. "You can hear it growing," she assured me with a grin.
A little farther along, Nishka stopped at two groups of plants, side by side, which looked identical to me. To her, too, as it turned out. A book I found later in the house identified one as Korean mint (Agastache rugosa), which smells like root beer, and the other, a cousin, as anise hyssop (Agastache foeniculum), which has a slight licorice flavor. That night, my wife, Betsey, and I had a sauce subtly flavored with anise hyssop, among other things, on a piece of black cod. Another night, a small packet of black cod arrived in a crab and corn broth, flavored with shingeku, or chrysanthemum leaves.
In both dishes, it was the fresh, sweet taste and the firm, slightly springy texture of the fish that hit you at first bite. Only slowly did the herbal flavors assert themselves, adding an unanticipated contrast.
A gray, gawky cardoon plant grew into a tree near a cluster of borage plants -- "borage for the bees," Nishka said, "they love it." So do Englishmen, I told her; they put whole stalks of the stuff into the Pimms' Cup they like to drink at Wimbledon or after a cricket match. Across the way, she pointed to a hedge of hops, grown not for beer but for the delicate young spring shoots, which the Belgians (and also the Philips) cook like asparagus.
In a shady spot at the foot of the hedge some fernlike sweet cicely was doing nicely. Some of it was destined for a mild sabayon, also flavored with ginger and white peaches, which Mr. Tuson served us on superbly briny sea urchin roe he had taken from the shell a mere five minutes before we ate it.
Byron Cook, head gardener for 13 years, grows all sorts of salad crops, including shiso, the hauntingly flavored Japanese leaf, and arugula and red romaine and Red Sails lettuce. Most of them are planted in raised beds, so the soil can more easily be renewed with compost, as successive crops are harvested.
Mr. Cook's is more or less a year-round operation. It seldom snows at Sooke, which lies in hardiness Zone 8, the same as Charleston, S.C., a beneficiary of benign Pacific breezes and currents. A few of the tenderer plants, like verbena, are lifted from the soil and kept inside for the brief winter, and cuttings are taken of others to start fresh plants when spring arrives.
But all of the lettuces, the pansies, the English daisies and the hardier herbs (like an 11-foot rosemary bush outside one of the guest rooms) keep right on chugging, year-round.
Not everything flourishes at Sooke. It took Mr. Cook a half-dozen tries to establish Mexican marigolds, which have a flavor similar to tarragon, and even in this cosseted corner of the Pacific, dill gets scraggly and sun-hungry basil doesn't grow very tall. Reassuring, I guess, for us brown-thumbs.
 
SWEET LAVENDER, MAPLE SYRUP AND CARROT ICE MILK
Adapted from Sooke Harbour House
Time: 1 hour 40 minutes, plus freezing time
 
For the carrot puree:
2 pounds organic carrots, trimmed and peeled
1 tablespoon fresh organic rosemary or 2 tablespoons dried
1 cup unfiltered organic apple juice
2 tablespoons brown sugar
 
For the ice milk:
2 cups 2 percent milk
1 1/2 teaspoons fresh or dried organic lavender flowers or a 2-inch cinnamon stick
8 large egg yolks
 1/2 cup maple syrup
 1/4 cup granulated sugar
 1/4 cup brown sugar
1 ounce brandy, Cognac, rye or rum.
1. To prepare carrot puree, combine carrots, rosemary, apple juice and brown sugar in a medium nonreactive saucepan. Place over high heat until simmering, then cover, and reduce heat to medium-low. Cook until carrots are soft, 35 to 40 minutes. Remove from heat, and set aside to cool.
2. In a food processor, puree the carrots with any remaining juice. Process until the puree is very smooth, about 4 minutes.
3. To prepare ice milk, combine carrot puree, milk and lavender in a medium saucepan. Place mixture over medium heat until it just reaches a simmer. Remove from heat, and keep warm.
4. In a medium nonreactive bowl, combine egg yolks, maple syrup, granulated sugar and brown sugar. Heat mixture over a double boiler, whisking until it is thick and light in color, about 15 minutes. Remove from heat, and place a strainer over mixture. Pour in carrot puree, stirring and pressing with a rubber spatula until puree passes through into egg mixture.
5. Return double boiler to heat. Whisk until mixture is steaming and thick enough to coat the back of a spoon, about 15 minutes. Remove from heat, and whisk occasionally as it cools. (If mixture begins to curdle, pour into a blender and process until smooth.)
6. When mixture has cooled, stir in brandy. Freeze in an ice-cream maker, according to manufacturer's instructions.
Yield: 1 1/2 quarts (about 6 servings).

HEADLINE: Women Welcomed Back to Career Path

BYLINE: By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
When Gwen Hahn, a stay-at-home mother, decided this summer that it was time to re-enter the work force, she braced herself for rejection.
"I worried that employers might not take me seriously," said Ms. Hahn, who had quit her job as a catering manager for a Phoenix hotel six years ago to spend more time with her three children. 
 Instead, Ms. Hahn received a job offer even before she had a chance to send out her resume. Her boss-to-be, Nancy Nachman, president of a firm in Scottsdale, Ariz., that plans meetings for companies, was a guest at a party she held and was immediately taken with her people skills.
"As soon as I saw Gwen, I knew that she was a natural for the job," Ms. Nachman said. Not long after, she offered Ms. Hahn a position as a planner with the company, the Meetings Concierge, starting in early September, and Ms. Hahn accepted.
Not so long ago, housewives with resume gaps spanning several years faced tough slogging in the job market. No more. In today's full-employment economy, employers are actively wooing women who held jobs once upon a time and finding in them a rich new source of talent.
"There's no question that employers are taking a second look at women who are re-entering the work force." said Marcia Brumit Kropf, vice president for research and information services for Catalyst, a New York research group that studies women's issues. "Today's job market is so tight that employers are opening their mind to nontraditional candidates. If a woman has talent and a good track record, a gap in her resume is no longer as relevant."
And it does not seem to matter if the gap is more a chasm. Katherine Goldman quit her job as creative director for an advertising agency in Princeton, N.J., after her first child was born more than 14 years ago.
"I always kept my eyes and ears open," said Ms. Goldman, who spent the next 11 years doing freelance work for ad agencies while caring for her two children, who are now teenagers. When Ms. Goldman decided last year to go back to work full time, she called a contact at Jack Morton Worldwide, a branding communications firm.
"As a returning mother, I thought I might have to explain myself," she said. "Instead, after I told him that I'd like to work for him, he said, 'Wow, that's great, you're hired.' "
Cynthia Kuker, Ms. Goldman's boss, says the hot economy has forced her company's executives to soften their old hiring requirements. "We're a niche market without a large employee pool, so we're bringing in applicants who on paper might not look like the ideal candidate, but who might have just the skills we're looking for," she said.
And, as was the case with Ms. Hahn, those skills went beyond workplace credentials and centered on personality. The company was attracted by her maturity and confidence as well as her broad background in writing and advertising, Ms. Kuker said. "She was bringing something totally different to the table that somebody who had just gotten out of school, or maybe had one job, wouldn't have," she said.
So eager are some employers to tap into the stay-at-home-mom pool that many are courting them with flexible-work arrangements, day care and other perks.
"For the first time, I'm seeing a few law firms offer four-day workweeks to working mothers," said Jillian Winoker, director of associate placements for Corrao Miller Rush & Wiesenthal, a New York employment firm. "You would never have seen that in the legal profession five years ago."
It is not just law firms. In 1998, Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, created a host of flexible work arrangements, from compressed work schedules and telecommuting to job sharing. "Women returning to the work force are typically highly skilled, and we have to be creative in attracting them," said Deborah Holmes, national director of the firm's office of retention.
One woman who was attracted was Sharon Kurtz, now a manager of internal audit services for the firm. Ms. Kurtz had previously worked for Ernst & Young until her second child was born in 1995.
She decided to apply for a second job there in March 1999, after taking a break to spend time with her children.
"When I left, the climate for working mothers was totally different," said Ms. Kurtz, who now works a three-day week. "I would leave after a nine-hour day, and a co-worker would say, 'Oh, half-day today?' "
Now, Ms. Kurtz said, so many employees have flexible arrangements that nobody questions that she works three days a week.
Another reason women are finding it easier to re-enter the work force is that they are becoming more adept at keeping their foot in the door while they are gone. Although they are often busy raising children, some women make a point of updating their skills, taking classes and networking with peers.
Consider Cindy Bateman, a mother of two from Seattle. Soon after Ms. Bateman left her position as a vice president at the Pacific National Bank in Newport Beach, Calif., in December 1998, to spend more time with her children, she enrolled in an M.B.A. program at the University of Washington. She also accepted a position as a public affairs officer for an association for women who work in the financial industry. She plans to resume working in another year, when her younger child starts school and she has earned her master's degree.
Though by then she will have been out of the work force for about three years, she is confident she will find work as a senior bank manager. "I'm already getting calls from prospective employers," Ms. Bateman said. "I've gotten so much positive feedback that I hadn't really considered that there was any difference between me and a job candidate who hadn't taken time off."
The journey back to the office is not all smooth sailing, of course. Ms. Hahn, for example, worries about whether her computer skills are up to speed. "It's kind of intimidating," she said. "In my old job, I had a support staff to do this kind of stuff."
Then there is the inevitable culture shock. Ms. Goldman, who is in her early 40's, said reporting to people who are younger than she is could be tough.
But her biggest struggle, she said, has been making her family accustomed to the fact that she is working again and to share household chores like making dinner and doing the laundry. "We're having to renegotiate roles," she said. 'My working is something we're all still getting used to."

HEADLINE: Brazil Begins to Take Role on the World Stage

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
When Henry A. Kissinger visited here as secretary of state in the mid-1970's, his Brazilian counterpart, Antonio Azeredo da Silveira, made a point of escorting him on a tour of Itamaraty Palace, the ultramodern glass and marble headquarters of the Brazilian Foreign Ministry.
Afterward, Mr. Silveira asked his American guest for his impressions. 
 Grinning with amusement, Mr. Silveira later recalled in an interview Mr. Kissinger's reply: "It's a magnificent building, Antonio. Now all you need is a foreign policy to go with it."
Nearly a quarter of a century later, the joke may finally be on the United States. Today an increasingly confident and assertive Brazil is emerging as both an American partner and rival in Latin America, steering its own course on political and economic matters and, in the words of Anthony S. Harrington, the United States ambassador here, "stepping out onto the world stage in a way that it never has before."
At the World Trade Organization talks in Seattle last fall, for instance, it was Brazil that led the bloc of developing nations in criticizing Washington's position. And on Aug. 31 and Sept. 1, Brazil is sponsoring a first meeting of South American presidents here that is being seen as both a coming-out party and an effort to forge a unified regional front in negotiations with the United States about a hemispheric free-trade zone.
"It is clearly the judgment that the continent is now ready for Brazil to assume a broader, more dynamic leadership role in regional affairs," Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere Program at Johns Hopkins University, said in referring to Brazilian leaders in an essay published this month by the Web site InfoBrazil.com. "And it is now understood in South America that the regional card to play is one that is led from Brasilia."
As the largest country in Latin America but separated from its Spanish-speaking neighbors by its Portuguese language, Brazil has traditionally conducted a foreign policy that is pragmatic but that only recently began to emphasize relations within the region. By habit, said Helio Jaguaribe of the Institute for Political and Social Studies in Rio de Janeiro, "Brazil seeks cooperation," recognizing that "whether or not you like the United States, you have to live with it."
For that reason the United States has welcomed the summit meeting, even though one of its goals is to blunt Washington's strategy in trade talks of favoring bilateral agreements in which it has the upper hand.
"A South America assembled into a single bloc would add up to more than the sum of its parts and therefore be in a position to insist on more balanced negotiations with the North American trading bloc," said Gilberto Dupas of the Institute of Advanced Studies at the University of Sao Paulo.
If regional integration is to take place, the State Department would clearly prefer to see Brazil lead it rather than Venezuela's firebrand president, Hugo Chavez, whose calls for South American unity contain authoritarian and markedly anti-American elements. Indeed, given its sheer size and the relative maturity and health of its democracy compared with some of its more troubled neighbors, Brazil may be best positioned to lead such a effort.
"I think President Fernando Henrique Cardoso is looked upon as somewhat of an uncle by some of the other leaders in South America," Ambassador Harrington said in an interview. "His orientation and goal is to steer onto the path of democracy a few countries that may be a little more challenged there."
The United States has recognized the benefits of Brazil's playing such a role since the early 1980's, when Brazilian diplomacy guided a leftist government in Suriname away from a flirtation with Cuba. More recently, Brazil helped negotiate the end to a potentially explosive border dispute between Ecuador and Peru, and has used its influence to head off potential military coups in Paraguay.
President Clinton praised Brazil and Argentina during a visit to nuclear-armed India and Pakistan this spring as examples of nations that have successfully negotiated an end to dangerous nuclear programs and even become allies. Bitter military rivals for most of their history, Brazil and Argentina have in the last decade become partners in the Mercosul trade bloc and are now talking about adopting a common currency.
The United States and Brazil have disagreed recently, however, over the suspect presidential election in Peru that resulted in a third term for Alberto K. Fujimori. The United States was pushing behind the scenes for sanctions, and American officials have complained privately that Brazil was undermining their efforts to nudge the Organization of American States into a tough collective stance.
"Washington should have seen that one coming," said David Fleischer, a professor of political science at the National University of Brasilia. "If you want to bring the Andean nations into Mercosul, as Brazil apparently does, you are not going to want to slap them in the face."
But it is the crisis in Colombia, with which Brazil shares a 1,000-mile border, that seems to have the most potential to become a source of disagreement with Washington. The Clinton administration's plan to supply $1.3 billion in military and economic aid to President Andres Pastrana of Colombia has been widely criticized in the Brazilian press and Congress, and official support for the American-backed effort appears lukewarm, at best.
"Brazil certainly has concerns there could be a spillover onto our side, whether of coca cultivation and trafficking or of combat between the Colombian Army and guerrillas," Brazil's foreign minister, Luiz Felipe Lampreia, said in an interview here. The American aid plan to Colombia, he added, represents "a stepping up of the level of conflict" that "could generate this effect."
At a joint news conference with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright during her South American tour this month, Mr. Lampreia's remarks were even stronger. "We do not have the same degree of commitment," he said of the plan in Colombia, with Dr. Albright by his side. "We have no intention of participating in any common or concerted international action."
Another point of potential tension is the hemispheric free-trade talks, which are supposed to reach an agreement by 2005. Brazil and the United States are the co-chairmen, but after six years of negotiations, it is clear that the two nations have very different views, with some officials in Washington describing Brazil's position as "obstructionist."
Brazil, in turn, complains of protectionist barriers and subsidies in the United States that discriminate against Brazilian products ranging from steel and textiles to sugar and orange juice.
Speaking of access to the American market, Mr. Lampreia said, "What is essential for us is a free-trade agreement completely devoid of tariff and nontariff barriers so that we can have unobstructed access."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
From Industry to Pastry: A Business Park Evolves

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
The old Atlas Terminals industrial park, on Cooper Avenue in Queens, has long had a knack for reinventing itself. But the park's latest transformation efforts are unlike anything its late founder, Henry Hemmerdinger, might have imagined.
Atlas Terminals sprouted from a warehouse that Mr. Hemmerdinger bought in 1922. The 25-acre park reached its heyday in the early 1950's, when it was home to brand names like the General Electric Company and New York Telephone. 
 The 40- and 50-year tenants are long gone at Atlas, as are the railroad cars that once carried some 60 loads a day across eight miles of track. Manufacturing firms still take up about a third of the park's one million square feet of commercial space. But for years, Atlas, in the mostly residential Glendale area, has pursued a number of market niches that have given it a diverse, if mostly local, mix of tenants.
Those tenants, housed in 42 buildings, include warehouses for college textbooks, plastic bags, carpeting and lighting, as well as companies that make art frames, telephone calling cards, and even European pastries.
Atlas has had some notable victories lately. For one, the park is 92 percent occupied, up from just 75 percent during the recession of the early 1990's. Moreover, it has been able to replace the many knitting firms that left in recent years with medical firms like Mason Medical Products, a manufacturer of mattresses, slings and medical foam cushions. At 130,000 square feet, Mason is the industrial park's largest tenant.
Over the last 18 months, Atlas has also been able to woo roughly a half-dozen small businesses that used to be in Manhattan, says George Rozansky, the park's manager.
Yet despite such successes, Atlas Terminals's survival skills are still being tested.
For example, even with relatively modest rents that start at just $5.75 a square foot per year for industrial space, the turnover rate at Atlas remains "fairly high," said H. Dale Hemmerdinger, the grandson of Atlas's founder and the president of the Manhattan-based Atco Properties and Management. He said industrial tenants in New York are continuing to leave for areas where costs are lower, like New Jersey.
Mr. Rozansky said he is negotiating with several Long Island City companies about a possible move. However, one obstacle has been the lack of a nearby subway stop at Atlas; the closest station, at Metropolitan Avenue on the M line, is less than two miles away, or about a three-minute trip by bus.
Mr. Rozansky and the executives at Atco are trying to woo textile firms that are being squeezed out of Manhattan's garment district. So far, they have attracted two small shops. They also want to begin marketing their complex as a home for Internet companies and "telecommunications hotels," which house telecommunications and data equipment.
On this front, they hope to get sizable help from a broadband fiber-optic network being installed at the park by Verizon Communications. The electronics for the network are already in place in a building next to a 50,000-gallon water tower. The tower itself has been wired for cellular service and will soon be able to handle wireless Internet service.
Retailers represent another surprising change at Atlas these days. The park now has four such tenants, three of which came aboard during the last two years. This fall, the park's two newest retailers -- a coffee bar and an 8,200-square-foot Chinese restaurant -- are expected to open for business on Cooper Avenue, not far from another Atlas tenant, a thriving pet supply store. According to Mr. Rozansky, Atlas is signing up retail tenants at about $15 a square foot; he said retail space in Glendale commonly goes for $15 to $20 a square foot.
To accommodate the Chinese restaurant, Atlas Terminals embarked on its largest renovation project in a decade. It involved overhauling a century-old, drive-in trucking building that needed a new facade, openings for storefront windows and doors, and an 18-space parking lot. The structure also needed a new concrete floor, to replace sections that were still made of dirt.
Mr. Hemmerdinger said his firm remains a long-term investor at Atlas Terminals, a commitment that requires continual modernizations. Renovations have included replacing roughly a quarter of the park's crumbling brick facade, installing two new boiler systems, and replacing roughly 150 windows a year.
A relative newcomer to the park is Werner Rees, a tenant who runs a baking goods distributorship, as well as a wholesale and retail bakery called Bavarian Alps Konditorei Pastries.
In January 1999, Mr. Rees moved his business from a 5,000-square-foot site in Richmond Hill to a 10,000-foot space at Atlas. As part of the move, he invested $400,000 in an ultramodern bakery that now provides pastries to 14 airlines.
"I looked at other properties," Mr. Rees said, "but the rent here was reasonable, and I like the service. Also, it's centrally located. I'm only 10 minutes from the airport."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Are Mixed as Fears of Rate Increases Re-emerge

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday, with banks and airlines mainly lower while selected technology issues made modest gains, as unexpectedly strong housing sales renewed fears the Federal Reserve could raise interest rates again.
The latest government data showed sales of new homes hit the highest level in seven years in July. That helped to increase shares in home builders, like Kaufman & Broad, but fostered negative attitudes toward banks and some retailers amid concern that the central bank's campaign of interest rate increases may not be over. 
 "The fundamental picture today was a ripple from the home sales numbers," said Pierre Ellis, senior economist at Primark Decision Economics. He said the July home sales data looked extremely strong and "that might have started to raise suspicions that the Fed could be thinking of tightening if that kind of number is confirmed by other indicators going forward."
Higher interest rates tend to reduce growth in consumer spending and curb demand for bank loans.
Blue chips pulled back some of their earlier losses as shares of brokerage firms climbed in reaction to a surge in the stock of the Wall Street house Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which soared $16.44, to $82.25. There were reports that Credit Suisse First Boston, the investment banking arm of Switzerland's No. 2 bank, is negotiating to buy Donaldson.
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.74 points, or 0.3 percent, to 11,215.10. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 4.25 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,509.84. The technology-laced Nasdaq composite index finished up 11.58 points, or 0.28 percent, to 4,082.17.
On Monday, stocks roared ahead on what analysts said was hope that interest rates had peaked after six increases since June 1999.
Among the banks and financial services companies to slide were Chase Manhattan, which lost 81 cents, to $51.88, and American Express, off $1.44, to $58.44.
Among technology heavyweights to gain were I.B.M., up $2.25, to $132.88, and Cisco Systems, which added 50 cents, to $66.56.
Among the investment banks and brokerage firms to benefit from the rumors surrounding Donaldson, Lufkin was J. P. Morgan & Company, which rose $3.88, to $149, and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. up $3.34, to $140.59. Lehman has long been considered a prime takeover candidate as it remains independent.
The Dow was also pressured by Johnson & Johnson, off $1.75, to $93, on negative news about the anticlotting drug ReoPro, which it developed with its Centocor unit.
Shares of Eli Lilly & Company, which distributes ReoPro worldwide, except in Japan, were down 50 cents, to $74.
Transportation and airline stocks fell amid pressure from high crude oil prices, which represent additional costs for these companies. The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, slipped $1.56, to $49.94.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Drop
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury bond prices fell as investors said government debt ha become expensive and as more than $20 billion of planned corporate bond sales from British Telecommunications and others next month sapped demand.
"Prices are high," with 10-year notes returning 7 percent and 30-year bonds gaining almost 9 percent just since early May, said Peter Cordrey, who oversees $125 billion at Prudential Asset Management in Newark.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 8/32, to a price of 99 19/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.80 percent from 5.77 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32, to 107 4/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.74 percent from 5.72 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Pace of New-Home Sales Hit a 7-Year High in July

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Americans bought new homes in July at the fastest pace in seven years while consumer confidence remained near record highs, according to reports released yesterday.
Sales of new single-family homes surged 14.7 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 944,000, from 823,000 in June, the Commerce Department said. That was far above analysts' expectations for a rate of 833,000. 
 The consumer confidence index dipped slightly, to 141.1, in August from an upwardly revised 143.0 in July, but the level remained close to the record of 144.7, set in January and May, according to the Conference Board, a private business and economic research group.
Moreover, consumers' plans over the next six months to buy big-ticket items like homes, cars, vacations and refrigerators strengthened. This suggested no let-up ahead in robust demand, the Conference Board said.
With the consumer untrammeled by six interest rate increases since June 1999, analysts said the latest economic data suggested the Federal Reserve might need to push interest rates higher by early next year.
"Consumers are not about to close their wallets," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo & Company. "This implies that Fed chairman Alan Greenspan's job is not finished by any means."
One factor tempering the 14.7 percent jump in July home sales -- the biggest gain since a 16.4 percent surge in April 1993 -- was that June was even weaker than initially reported. June sales were revised down to a 7.1 percent drop from the previously reported 3.7 percent decline.
Averaging the two months showed the housing market has come off its peaks, analysts said. But they cautioned that a recent drop in 30-year mortgage rates below 8 percent might set off a fresh round of buying.
Skyrocketing demand pushed the supply of available single-family homes down to 3.8 months' worth at the current sales pace, down from 4.6 months' worth in June. The July figure was the lowest since December 1998.
The short supply appeared to be creating price pressures. Median prices of new single-family homes rose 3.8 percent in July, to $166,100, up from $157,900 a year ago.
Still, economists said they were not putting too much emphasis on economic reports that can be volatile. They still forecast growth slowing this summer from its heady 5.3 percent rate in the second quarter to 3.5 percent to 4 percent.
