HEADLINE: Scientists Report They Have Made Robot That Makes Its Own Robots

BYLINE: By KENNETH CHANG 

 BODY:
For the first time, computer scientists have created a robot that designs and builds other robots, almost entirely without human help.
In the short run, this advance could lead to a new industry of inexpensive robots customized for specific tasks. In the long run -- decades at least -- robots may one day be truly regarded as "artificial life," able to reproduce and evolve, building improved versions of themselves. 
 Such durable, adaptive robots, astronomers have suggested, could someday be sent into space to explore the galaxy or search for other life.
But the quest to create artificial life also revives concerns that computer scientists could eventually create a robotic species that would supplant biological life, including humans.
"Some things we probably can do we shouldn't do," said Bill Joy, chief scientist at Sun Microsystems, who wrote a recent article warning of the power of emerging technologies. "Just like we can kill things with DDT, but we shouldn't."
For now, the robotic manufacturing system -- a computer hooked up to a machine that builds plastic models -- in the laboratory of Dr. Jordan B. Pollack and Dr. Hod Lipson at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., cannot create anything nearly as complicated as itself. Instead, it produces eight-inch-long contraptions of plastic bars and ball joints.
When a motor and microchip are added, the automatons have one, and only one, ability: to crawl slowly. The fastest can scuttle along at a few inches a second.
"They look like toys," Dr. Pollack, a professor of computer science, said. But, he added, "They were not engineered by humans, and they were not manufactured by humans."
Dr. Pollack and Dr. Lipson, a research scientist, report their results in today's issue of the journal Nature.
"This is the first example of pretty much 100 percent automated evolution of a machine," said Dr. Philip Husbands, a professor of artificial intelligence at the University of Sussex in England. "It's a rather primitive example, but it's the first step to something that could be quite significant."
In the future, the technique could be used to design robots that assemble parts in factories, clean up chemical spills or vacuum a home.
Because computers cost much less than engineers, "It opens for the first time a more economical approach to robotics," Dr. Pollack said. "We can now essentially design for free and build for a few thousand dollars."
The cost of designing a robot today typically runs from hundreds of thousands of dollars to millions of dollars, Dr. Pollack said.
The computer in the Brandeis system had no idea what a successful design might look like. Instead, it was merely given a list of possible parts it could work with, the physical laws of gravity and friction, the goal of moving on a horizontal surface and a group of 200 randomly constructed, nonworking designs.
Mimicking biological evolution, the computer added, subtracted and changed pieces in the designs. At the same time, the computer similarly mutated the programming instructions for controlling the robot's movements. After each step, the computer ran simulations to test the designs, keeping the ones that moved well and discarding the failures.
After 300 to 600 generations of evolution and fine-tuning, the computer sent the design to a prototyping machine, used by manufacturers to build test models of product designs, to build the robot. Then, in the step that required human help, the researchers installed the robot's motor and microchip and downloaded the robot's programming instructions.
Changing the initial configuration of the robot parts produced a different design and a different approach to locomotion. One pushes itself along. "It's kind of like an accordion," Dr. Pollack said.
Another one "walks something like a crab," Dr. Lipson said. "It looks like it's crawling on the floor. It's quite surprising the diversity of solutions we get."
In earlier work, other researchers used similar evolution-inspired algorithms to evolve imaginary creatures that existed only in virtual computer worlds or to design the programming instructions.
The robots' evolution is currently a dead-end, as the designing computer never learns how well its designs work in the real world. The simple robots also have no ability to improve their performance. According to the researchers, the robots currently have the brainpower of bacteria. "We hope to get up to insect level within a couple of years," Dr. Pollack said. "There's no danger of Commander Data walking out of our fabricator anytime soon," he said, referring to the android character in "Star Trek."
In future research, the Brandeis researchers intend to add sensors to the robots and improve the design programs. Future robots may also be able to exchange information among one another and learn from each other's experiences.
As computer chips speed up and fabrication machines become more sophisticated, the robotic designers will produce robots that are more and more complex. Some have wondered what will happen when a robot can design and build something as complex as itself.
For example, Dr. Seth Shostak, an astronomer at the SETI Institute in Mountain View, Calif., has suggested that researchers listening for radio signals from alien civilizations are more likely to first come across intelligent machines created by aliens.
In an article in the April issue of Wired, Mr. Joy argued that scientists should perhaps deliberately steer themselves away from research that would create self-replicating, evolving, autonomous robots. With forethought, he said, computer scientists should be able to tap into most of the benefits of the emerging technology while avoiding the dangers.
"This doesn't have enough of the pieces to be by itself dangerous," Mr. Joy said about the Brandeis work.But, he added, "We're on the road to somewhere where there's big issues down the road."
Others working in the field are not as worried, even if technological advances make such devices possible. Dr. Ralph C. Merkle of the nanotechnology firm Zyvex and an adviser to the Foresight Institute, said that high costs would probably prevent the design of dangerous robots. Rather, robots would continue to be designed for specific tasks with little or no ability to evolve and adapt.
"It looks like having a device to work at all is hard," Dr. Merkle said. "There is no desire to add additional complexity. Those systems do not look like they would be dangerous."
The Brandeis researchers find the speculation premature. "Really, it's so far removed from anything dangerous," Dr. Lipson said about their work. "There are many other things to worry about before this."

HEADLINE: Off-Duty Police Driving Cabs? Taxi Panel Says Yes but Officers See an Insult

BYLINE: By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

 BODY:
In an effort to build up the ranks of taxi drivers, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission is considering a proposal to encourage police officers to moonlight behind the wheels of yellow cabs, but the plan is being greeted coldly by police officers.
Under the proposal, officers would be able to waive an 80-hour training course and a drug test that taxi drivers must take. Officials with the commission, which is scheduled to discuss the plan on Sept. 28, say the taxi industry proposed it as a way to deal with a driver shortage. They said police officers were an obvious choice, because they had completed driver training courses and were randomly tested for drug use. 
 But though many officers -- who say they are underpaid -- do hold down second jobs, many note that they already spend their days dealing with the public and patrolling the streets, not to mention fielding complaints from cabbies themselves.
"It just doesn't appeal to me," said Rick Lee, the community affairs officer of the First Precinct, in Lower Manhattan. "I think there should be other ways we should be compensated. We should maybe make a little better salary." He called the plan insulting.
"We're a pretty highly trained department," Officer Lee said. "It's kind of saying, 'Well, it might be all you're good for.' "
The taxi owners realize officers may not be interested, but they thought it was worth a try, said Diane McGrath-McKechnie, the chairwoman of the commission. "The economy is very, very strong right now, and they're having more difficulty than usual in recruiting drivers," she said.
She estimated that at any given time, 8 to 10 percent of the city's more than 12,000 medallions were unused, primarily because of the driver shortage.
The shortage is so acute, said the spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, Maureen Connelly, that some fleet operators are willing to lease taxis for shorter periods than the standard 12-hour shift.
"It's something that a police officer might want to do for four or six hours on a night or a day off, instead of working as a security guard," Ms. Connelly said.
The proposal, which was first reported yesterday in The New York Post, will be a hard sell. Some officers said that they were all too familiar with the woes and perils of cabby life. "People drunk, people not paying, people making a mess in the back of the cab," said Officer Thomas Reilly, 29, of the First Precinct. "I've seen a lot of cabdrivers. I see a lot of the problems they have."
Other officers said that after eight hours patrolling the streets and dealing with the public, the last thing they wanted was a part-time job that would put them back there.
"Guys here, if they work another job, they're going to go out and get another job that's not high stress, something that they like to do," said a longtime officer at the Fifth Precinct station house in Lower Manhattan.
An undercover officer called the proposal a "slap in the face," saying, "It's just an acknowledgment that we have to supplement the money we ain't making." He added, "Nobody's asking the bus drivers to take taxi jobs."
Taxi drivers' fraternal organizations blame the commission and what they describe as its unfair regulations for the driver shortage. The commission is "an agency that has completely lost touch with reality," said Biju Mathew, a member of the organizing committee of the New York Taxi Workers Alliance.
Mr. Mathew said that cabbies had been driven out of the profession in recent years, citing the system in which six points of traffic offenses during a 15-month period will cost a driver his license for a month, and the shortening of the grace period for license renewals.

HEADLINE: The Environment, and Our Votes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Protecting the Earth" (editorial, Aug. 28): The discussion about global warming highlights the opportunity to protect the environment while strengthening the economy.
Those who suggest that reducing fossil fuel emissions will cause economic deprivation have it exactly wrong. The most cost-effective way of reducing such emissions is to use energy more efficiently. Doing so reduces costs, enhancing productivity and competitiveness. Global-warming remediation policies therefore become a tool to achieve sustainable economic growth. 
 Al Gore's proposals to increase energy efficiency and to promote nonpolluting renewable energy sources are deserving of universal support.
 
JAMES J. FLORIO
Metuchen, N.J., Aug. 29, 2000
 
The writer is the former governor of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Bitter Primary Contest Hits Ethnic Nerve Among Blacks

SERIES: NEW YORK PRIMARY: 11th Congressional District

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
It is a primary race that has spawned a soap opera-like drama. The bitterness of a feud between two Democrats in the 11th Congressional District in Brooklyn has not only torn apart a longstanding friendship but has also delivered some of that anguish to the doorsteps of other politicians and voters in Brooklyn.
But it is also a contest that has brought to the surface simmering -- and often unspoken -- tension between black New Yorkers whose roots are in the United States and those with Caribbean heritage. In her campaign for Congress, Una Clarke, the Jamaican-born city councilwoman, has not only heralded her Caribbean roots in the campaign, but has also accused her old friend and mentor, United States Representative Major R. Owens, of being anti-immigrant. Mr. Owens, who was born in Memphis, has accused Ms. Clarke of trying to turn black Brooklynites against one another by using ethnic chauvinism to get votes. 
 As a result, theirs has not just been a political contest. It has represented a springboard for many to consider anew the relationship between two groups of black New Yorkers who often have their own share of prejudices against one another. At the same time, it has focused attention on the political impact of New York's growing Caribbean population.
"There has always been some degree of tension between African-Americans and Caribbean-Americans over the years," said Don Quinn Kelley, a professor of history at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn. "Color is the thing the two have in common. But there are misconceptions, and some degree of mistrust." And a campaign like the one between Mr. Owens and Ms. Clarke, he said, "causes people to focus on them again."
Some of that mistrust may come from a natural succession that has become part of the fabric of New York: the latest immigrant group encroaching on the territory of earlier groups. In this case, the wariness has been complicated by the fact that many American-born blacks in New York City have not had the same economic success that earlier groups of immigrants had.
"African-Americans have not translated their gains in the public sector in the way that the Jews or the Italians did," said Philip Kasinitz, a professor of sociology at the City University Graduate Center and author of the book "Caribbean New York." "So, when they face the same issues of ethnic succession, in this case by Caribbeans, it seems that there is more to lose. And that contributes to the tension."
For years, Mr. Owens and Ms. Clarke were the closest of friends. Mr. Owens, who was first elected to Congress 18 years ago, was a prominent benefactor to Ms. Clarke when she switched from a career as a child care administrator to elective politics a decade ago. They have worked on each other's campaigns. Their families socialized with each other over the years, and they attended family events and weddings together.
But with Ms. Clarke's decision to oppose her onetime mentor in the Democratic primary on Sept. 12, the relationship has dissolved into pure rancor. And while Mr. Owens has the advantage of incumbency and the support of most local officials, Ms. Clarke is well financed and could pose a tough challenge.
Today, they barely muster a nod when their paths cross on the campaign trail. "If we're both in the same place, I prefer to avoid her," Mr. Owens said in an interview last week. "If I can't avoid her, then I suppose I will at least say hello."
To Ms. Clarke, a 64-year-old legislator known for her sharp tongue and her championing of immigrant rights, Mr. Owens, also 64, is a tired congressman who has grown ineffective and disconnected. "It's not about friendship," she said. "Too much has been made of friendship. It's about leadership and effectiveness. I don't think he has kept up with the needs of the changing community."
Mr. Owens sees Ms. Clarke's challenge through a different lens. It is, he insists, spurred purely by her desire to cling to public office in the face of a term-limit law that prohibits her from running for re-election to the City Council.
"She has no reason to run against me," he said, "except for her interest in keeping a job. She has no platform. We agree on just about every issue."
In the midst of this clash are a number of Brooklyn Democrats with close ties to both officials who are uncomfortable about having to take sides and mournful that the congressman and the councilwoman are at war.
"This is a difficult thing to watch because many of us admire and respect both of them," said John L. Sampson, a state senator from the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, whose parents are African-American and Guyanese. "They used to work together on all kinds of things. But now, to see them attack each other, is like seeing a breach within a family. It's painful to see."
The campaign's tone has also been highly divisive, many Brooklyn politicians insist.
Mr. Owens says that by appealing to voters based on her Jamaican background, Ms. Clarke has crossed the line between ethnic pride and demagoguery. In a recent debate on New York 1, the cable news network, he likened those tactics to Hitler's.
Ms. Clarke said the congressman accused her of something she has never done. "I appeal to everyone in every community," she said. Ms. Clarke added that it was the congressman who was trying to place a wedge between citizens born here and those born overseas. The debate turned into a shouting match, with Ms. Clarke declaring repeatedly, "Major Owens, you're a liar."
The 11th Congressional District includes the neighborhoods of Flatbush and Brownsville and extends into Crown Heights, Prospect Heights and Park Slope. The population is about 55 percent black, with more than two-thirds of those being Caribbean blacks. The district is also about 25 percent white, which includes a significant population of Orthodox Jewish voters.
Most of the elected officials in central Brooklyn have endorsed Mr. Owens, saying that his seniority in Congress would place him in a position to be chairman of a committee or subcommittee, should the Democrats regain control of the House. Moreover, while many officials complain that the congressman's record has been unremarkable, they say he has nonetheless been effective and has roots deep in the community.
Mr. Owens was a commissioner of the city's antipoverty program when he entered elective politics, running for the State Senate in 1974. A reserved legislator, Mr. Owens often backed candidates who ran against officials supported by the traditional Democratic leadership in Brooklyn, making him a leader of a group of insurgents who, he said, needed a stronger voice in the politics of the borough.
And when Mr. Owens first ran for Congress in 1982 -- for the seat of the retiring incumbent, Shirley Chisholm, who was born in Brooklyn but got her early schooling in Barbados -- he won in a bitter and close contest with Vander L. Beatty, another state senator who was backed by the Democratic Party organization. He has not had a difficult race since.
He met Ms. Clarke in the 1980's, when she was a day care administrator who was becoming increasingly active in politics. When the City Council was being expanded, Mr. Owens pushed for the creation of a district that would include enough of the growing Caribbean community to make it possible for a West Indian Council member to be elected. He supported Ms. Clarke in her first, and ultimately successful, run for City Council, in 1991, over the candidate supported by the Democratic organization.
Mr. Owens is facing a formidable opponent in Ms. Clarke. She has been endorsed by Kenneth C. Fisher, a city councilman who is considered a leading candidate for Brooklyn borough president, and by Edward I. Koch, the former mayor. She has raised $188,000 for her campaign. And although Congressman Owens has raised $287,000, all her money has come from individuals, while more than half of Mr. Owens's contributions have come from political action committees.
(In her 1997 re-election campaign, Ms. Clarke was accused of campaign finance irregularities and is appealing a $48,000 fine.)
The congressman has taken great pains to portray Ms. Clarke as an ally of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, which is not considered a plus in this heavily Democratic district. He charges that Ms. Clarke has not been outspoken about incidents where police brutality was alleged, pointing out that he was arrested during civil disobedience activities while she had not been.
"I dare say that I will get far more Caribbean votes than she will," Mr. Owens said. "And I will get more Jewish votes, too. I haven't just started forging relationships in this community."
But Ms. Clarke suggests that she expects Caribbean and Jewish voters to respond favorably to her view on Mr. Owens's stewardship.
She denies his contention that she is motivated by term limits; rather, she calls it a sincere desire to improve the quality of representation in the district.
"When you ask people in the district to name a couple of things that the incumbent has done that demand his remaining, they are hard pressed," she said.
Furthermore, she said, she is saddened that so many people view the race in terms of the relationship she and Mr. Owens previously shared rather than the need for improved leadership.
"I wish people would not focus on that," she said of the erstwhile friendship. "After all, many people have been married 25 or 30 years and they go for a divorce and nobody says, shame on them." She added: "We had a political alliance. And the fact is, political alliances are just that and nothing more."

HEADLINE: Operator Sought for Rebuilt Brooklyn Rail Yard

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
After nearly two decades of planning, New York City and State have completed the $20 million modernization of an old freight yard in Brooklyn, and the city is seeking bidders to revive the cross-harbor rail freight traffic that had largely disappeared since its heyday a half century ago.
City officials hope that the return of a vibrant cross-harbor rail freight business will reduce the roadway congestion and pollution associated with heavy truck traffic, which now carries about 80 percent of the freight coming into the city. They also hope that the yard will foster the kind of growth in rail freight traffic that will help advance a proposed rail freight tunnel under New York Harbor that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has vigorously advocated. 
 With most of New York City cut off by water from the mainland United States, it has a paucity of direct rail freight links to the rest of the nation. Railroads now carry only 3 percent of the half-billion tons a year of freight that flows into the city, said Seth Kaye, executive vice president for transportation in the city's Economic Development Corporation.
"We view this as a catalyst toward rebuilding the market for rail freight in New York City," he said yesterday, adding that his agency anticipated that 10,000 or more rail cars a year could move through the rebuilt 65th Street Rail Yard in Bay Ridge.
Michael G. Carey, the agency's president, said putting a rail car float system into operation at the yard "could potentially divert approximately two million tons of freight a year from truck to rail and eliminate tons of air pollutants annually."
The only rail-freight float operation now operating in the city, that of the New York Cross Harbor Railroad, sent about 4,000 cars across the harbor last year, transporting them on rail barges between 51st Street in Sunset Park on the Brooklyn waterfront, and the Greenville yard in Jersey City. It is planning to float 6,000 cars this year, said Robert Bentley, president of New York Cross Harbor.
Mr. Bentley said that his rail line would bid to operate the 65th Street yard, and that his 16-year-old company was well suited to do so, given that it has experience in land-to-barge rail operations and has equipment for such an operation on the New Jersey side.
"We're obviously concerned," Mr. Bentley said of the possibility that other bidders might be selected to run the 65th Street Rail Yard. The 65th Street yard is not far from his yard, which is also on a city-owned site. Mr. Kaye said the 65th Street yard was much better, its modernization having recently been finished with the completion of two rail transfer bridges, gantry-like structures that move rail cars on and off barges.
Should New York Cross Harbor be selected to operate the 65th Street yard, it is not clear how many of the 10,000 or more cars the city hopes for at 65th Street would be above the number that New York Cross Harbor now handles. Mr. Bentley said New York Cross Harbor now transports cars by barge for the three major lines that carry rail freight into and out of the city: CSX, Norfolk Southern and Canadian Pacific.
In fact, those railroads would still be providing much, if not most, of the rail car traffic moving into and out of the city by barge, even if another operator were to be selected for the 65th Street yard. But Mr. Kaye said that the city viewed use of that yard as a catalyst to spur freight shippers and rail lines to increase rail car traffic across New York Harbor.
But whatever the growth of such traffic, it is not expected to come close to what it was in New York City's heyday of cross-harbor rail freight traffic. During World War II and into the 1960's, more than 100,000 rail cars a year were transported by barge into and out of the city.
"About half was through traffic," Mr. Bentley said, cars carrying freight destined not for New York City and its environs but for further land rail passage to areas like upstate New York and New England. A wave of railroad bankruptcies in the 1960's and 70's was among the reasons that the rail barge traffic in the harbor severely shrank.
The 65th Street yard has been unused since before the city bought it in 1982, with the intention of recapturing some of the lost traffic. But "the market wasn't ready for it," Mr. Kaye said, and city fiscal problems put off completion of the project. He also said the yard was a terminus of the Long Island Rail Road's Bay Ridge freight line, and the L.I.R.R. "didn't focus on rail freight."
For the last few years the New York & Atlantic Railway has been running freight service on the L.I.R.R.'s Bay Ridge tracks, and a year ago it became the first occupant of the 65th Street yard in many years under a short-term arrangement.
The city's effort to find a permanent yard operator began this week when it issued a request for proposals by potential operators. Operators also would be required to run nonbarge freight operations at the yard, including car rerouting and freight transfer between rail cars and trucks.

HEADLINE: AMERICAN LEAGUE: ROUNDUP;
One Night After Brawl, Devil Rays Win Quietly

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Tampa Bay Devil Rays did not need any inside pitches to down the Boston Red Sox.
 Albie Lopez allowed only four hits in eight innings as the Devil Rays beat the Red Sox, 3-1, last night in St. Petersburg, Fla. 
 The victory came one day after the two teams were involved a beanball-filled contest that featured two bench-clearing brawls.
 "For me, it's just good to get a win," Lopez said. "I really wasn't concerned about that. I couldn't allow it to get in my head. It hurts them a lot more if we get a win."
 One day after being one-hit by Pedro Martinez, the Devil Rays had 11 hits against five Boston pitchers. Bobby Smith snapped an 0-for-21 slump with a run-scoring single in the third inning. The Red Sox were held hitless after Nomar Garciaparra opened the fourth with a single. Boston's Jeff Fassero was dropped from the rotation after allowing three runs and eight hits over three and one-third innings. He will be replaced by Pete Schourek.
 
WHITE SOX 8, ATHLETICS 3: Mike Sirotka pitched seven strong innings and Jose Valentin put Chicago in front with a two-run single in the seventh as the White Sox won in Oakland.
 Sirotka limited Oakland to two runs and six hits, including a solo homer by Eric Chavez in the fourth inning. The White Sox scored four times in the ninth to break open a tight game.
 
INDIANS 5, RANGERS 3: Kenny Lofton made up for a two-base error with three hits and three runs batted in as the Cleveland Indians strengthened their position in the American League wild-card race with a victory over host Texas.
 Dave Burba pitched six strong innings and Roberto Alomar drove in the tie-breaking run with a seventh-inning double for the Indians, who won their third straight and improved to 18-8 since Aug. 2.
 Cleveland moved one and one-half games ahead of Boston in the wild-card race.
 
ORIOLES 5, TIGERS 1: Jose Mercedes pitched a two-hitter for his first complete game since 1997 as Baltimore sent Detroit back under .500.
 Mercedes allowed only three baserunners in improving to 5-1 over his last seven starts. The Tigers, who started the season 9-23, have reached .500 three times this month. But they have failed on each occasion to rise above the break-even point.
 
ROYALS 8, TWINS 7: Mike Sweeney hit a three-run double off Mark Redman to give him 121 R.B.I., second most in Royals history, and host Kansas City held on in 100-degree heat.
 
TESTIMONY ENDS IN UMPIRES' GRIEVANCE: Testimony in a grievance hearing on behalf of 22 unemployed umpires has ended in Philadelphia, but a decision in the case is probably at least three months off.
 The 22 umpires, who lost their jobs last year after taking part in a mass-resignation strategy, contend they were wrongly let go in an attempt by Major League Baseball to break their union. Baseball has argued that it merely accepted their resignations.
 The grievance hearing concluded with testimony by a former A.L. official, Derek Irwin, and the lawyers Richie Phillips and Pat Campbell, who led the umpires' old union, the Major League Umpires Association.
 Campbell said each side has 60 days to file briefs before the independent arbitrator Alan Symonette. That means the 22 umpires probably won't know until November at the earliest whether they will win back their jobs.
 Baseball's lawyers were not immediately available to comment.
 The Major League Umpires Association is handling the grievance even though it was voted out last year and replaced by a new union, the World Umpires Association, in February. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: The Mt. Everest Of Yard Sales

BYLINE: By FRANK DeCARO 

 BODY:
THE pin on Mimi Mannix's hat said it all. "Junk 'til you drop" it read, which is why Ms. Mannix -- "spelled like the detective," she said -- was outside the Strudel Haus in Covington, Ky., on a Thursday afternoon painting a giant pig. Like a multitude of less colorful people, Ms. Mannix, an Indiana collectibles dealer, and her capacious yellow porker, a mascot long ago rescued from the roof of a Piggly Wiggly grocery store, had come to this musty little town across the Ohio River from Cincinnati to shop.
"I'm selling, I'm buying, I'm doing my pig," Ms. Mannix said, dipping into a vat of pink enamel. "I'm having fun." Here at the northernmost tip of an annual event known as the 450-Mile Route 127 Corridor Sale, it was no wonder why. A banner spanning Main Street hailed, "Welcome to the start of the world's largest yard sale." On the reverse it said, "Welcome to the end of the world's largest yard sale." 
 Covington was the final destination if you started your journey at the other end, 450 miles away in Gadsden, Ala. Like everything about this multistate flea market, it was all in how you looked at it.
The Route 127 Corridor, as this scenically rich, economically underprivileged stretch is called, is not lined with Heywood Wakefield dining room sets and paved with lilac Fiesta Ware. But for a few very busy days every August, there is good junk as far as the eye can see. A 1966 Batman lunchbox for $50, a Shawnee Polynesian lady head vase for $40, a Continental Kilns Bali Hai vegetable bowl for $5, a set of Tiki spice shakers for $6, cartoon figurines from fast-food shops for a quarter. It is as if, for one long weekend a year, the 26th Street Flea Market extended from New York to Toronto.
For shoppers like my junking buddy, Chuck Hettinger, and me, longtime collectors who live by the words "Have Bubble Wrap, Will Travel," this was a four-day odyssey like no other. Although eBay and a plethora of guidebooks have inflated the prices of collectibles the world over, this rural flea market has not been completely spoiled by price-gouging dealers and pay-anything urban aficionados.
Trendy collectors -- the internationally known fashion designers, interior decorators and celebrities who frequent the flea markets of Manhattan or Pasadena, Calif. -- were not perusing Covington's card tables. Nor were they pawing the racks at Possum Trot Antiques in Pall Mall, Tenn., a day's drive away and one of the many antique stores dotting the route.
Instead, Possum Trot's Doris Doss was selling poodle-shaped liquor decanters and lunches of country ham, candied sweet potatoes with toasted marshmallows and slices of "Million Dollar Pie" to customers who came from as far away as Canada.
"What is 'Million Dollar Pie?' " I asked.
"It's delicious," Mrs. Doss said, her ad-libs as practiced as her baking.
Fueled by such artery-clogging foods -- not to mention Lee's Famous Fried Chicken, Dairy Queen Blizzard shakes and the home-cooked hamburgers and hot dogs sold from front-lawn barbecues -- we made our way along the mostly two-lane road that snaked through Kentucky and Tennessee. The slow-going drive continued into Georgia and Alabama. But after shopping for 12 hours a day for three days straight, we never made it past Chattanooga, Tenn. By then, we were just too junked out to go any farther than an antiques mall in East Ridge, Tenn.
Cruising past Baptist churches, double-wide trailers, bright green tobacco fields and solemn graveyards, we stopped our rented minivan every few minutes to browse through wares set out in the driveways of private homes, along sidewalks, in high school parking lots, in former chicken coops and on flatbed trailers parked in muddy fields. A pickup parked on the bank of the Ohio River near the Indiana border produced a 1950's tropical leaf-shaped dish from Hull pottery marked $35.
"Will you take $20?" I asked a man who had fashioned his T-shirt into a hat. "Make it $22, so my wife won't kill me," he replied.
Among the detritus of the 20th century -- from guns to gravy boats -- we perused pressed-glass pitchers, old Louis L'Amour paperbacks, Fire King mugs, Confederate flags, hubcaps and talking Pee-wee Herman dolls who uttered their last "I know you are, but what am I?" years ago. Empty Mrs. Butterworth's bottles shared tables with several decades' worth of Kentucky Derby glasses. Barbie dolls in hand-crocheted Southern belle dresses stood next to an unopened box of "Mork and Mindy" trading cards from the 1970's. Baby clothes cried out for a new generation of wearers.
There were some real finds on our trip -- a $10 box of Eva Zeisel Town and Country dishware that might fetch $500 on eBay, for instance. But a lot was the kind of stuff Housing Works would reject as too cruddy to sell in its New York City thrift shops. Still, the pleasure of the world's longest yard sale was in the hunt, the joy of uncovering that one coveted piece that made the trip spiritually, if not economically, worthwhile.
My accomplice in all this, Chuck, is a decorative painter whose collections include cookie jars, tin noisemakers and Lu-Ray Pastel dishes. For him, the holy grail was a three-foot-tall blown-glass bottle made by a company called Blenko in the early 1970's.
After looking through hundreds of thousands of items, we felt the junker's tingle in a scraggly crescent of grass and gravel with nothing else even remotely attractive for sale. There we found, lying on its side, the oversized decanter, a giant yellow vessel with its stopper still intact.
"How much is that big bottle?" I asked the man standing near it.
"Oh that's not for sale," he said. We hadn't come all this way to hear that.
"If it's not for sale, why is it here?" Chuck asked.
The man explained that he had bought the bottle that morning for $25, and didn't want to part with it. "I'll give you $50," Chuck said.
No thanks, the man replied. And on it went, $75, $100, finally $125.
That was the magic number. "I can't say no to making a hundred dollars," the man said. A few minutes later, I overheard one female shopper say to another, "That guy must know something if he's willing to spend that much for a bottle."
We both did. Chuck knew a similar Blenko bottle recently sold on eBay for close to $1,000. I knew I didn't want to be in that minivan if the guy had refused to sell it to Chuck.
Steals like that one, we've since been told, have gotten fewer and farther between as the sale has grown. "Four years ago, before eBay, there was a lot more collectible stuff for a quarter," said Ryan Lance, a proprietor of a store called Howdy Do on East Seventh Street in Manhattan, which sells campy pop culture items like "Cher's Dressing Room Play Set" and "H. R. Pufnstuf" coloring books.
Programs like "Antiques Roadshow" and published guides to all types of collectibles have helped to jack up prices, too, he said. "I saw a rusted-out, horrible old 'Charlie's Angels' lunchbox -- the handle was half melted -- and the lady had $95 on it," Mr. Lance said. "I asked her, 'Why is it this much?' and she said, 'That's what it books for.' "
His partner, Michael Torres, added, "People this year were much more aware of what they have in their homes and in their basements."
But at least one thing hasn't changed: The so-bad-it's-good aesthetic hasn't reached these parts yet. "The people down there don't appreciate black velvet paintings," Mr. Lance noted. "They're $3 apiece there and we can get $75 here. What's sad is that people probably took them down off their walls for the sale."
For those who live in these economically depressed environs -- particularly junk dealers, restaurant operators and motel owners -- the Route 127 sale is a significant source of income. "This is by far the biggest week of the year here," said Scott Sandman, executive director of the Jamestown, Tenn., Chamber of Commerce, which promotes the event. "There are sellers who make 8 or 10 thousand dollars in these four days," he said. The median household income in 1999 for Fentress County, Tenn., was $21,293.
As Mrs. Doss of Possum Trot Antiques said, "In four days, we do what we usually do in two months."
Debbie Barnett, who owns the County Line Antiques Mall in Lawrenceburg, Ky., said, "People buy for it all year long, box it up and store it until 127." She sees 50 to 100 customers on a typical day. During the sale, she estimated that 2,500 people a day browsed through her bric-a-brac. It is so busy, in fact, that she never leaves the store during the four-day yard sale, sleeping on a cot rather than going home to Lexington, which is a half-hour away.
"Last year we had people peeking in the door at 6:30 a.m.," she said. "And we stay open until they stop coming." That may be as late as midnight.
Started more than a dozen years ago, the giant yard sale has grown since the days when a former county executive named Mike Walker, a lawyer in Jamestown, came up with the idea of a crafts sale to lure tourists off the interstate. "The first year, we put out crafts and didn't sell anything," Mrs. Doss said. "But after that we put out junk and whatnot and it sold."
THE Route 127 Corridor Sale is no longer much of a secret. On June 14, HGTV, the home and garden cable channel, presented a one-hour documentary called "The Longest Yard Sale." "They aired that special on a Wednesday, and the next day, the phones wouldn't quit," Mr. Sandman said. "We had 400 calls."
One was from Allen Holladay, a machinist from Rock Island, Ill. He and his girlfriend, Lori Bitterman, a nursing instructor, had driven 750 miles from home when I caught up with them, near the Isaac Shelby Cemetery State Historic Site, seven miles northwest of Stanford, Ky. "We were sitting watching the Home and Garden network and heard about this," Mr. Holladay said. "We hadn't planned a vacation, so we decided to come here."
The couple were carting furniture home in a blue van with an open trailer attached. "It looks like the Beverly Hillbillies," he admitted.
For next summer, PBS plans to show "A Flea Market Documentary," another special featuring the Route 127 sale. At the Lake Cumberland Motel in Jamestown, Ky., Rick Sebak, a bearish television producer with a jovial demeanor, was conducting interviews for it. Mr. Sebak, who produced the critically lauded PBS specials "An Ice Cream Show" and "A Hot Dog Program," said that he and his crew "have been totally flabbergasted by it all."
"It's better than we expected," he said. "In rural Kentucky and Tennessee, there's still cool stuff left in people's houses."
Not for long, perhaps. But for now, the sale still has the feeling that around the next corner will be another Blenko bottle, another 60's lunchbox in fabulous condition and another woman painting a giant pig. When I think of Ms. Mannix back in Covington pointing to her hat, I laugh.
"See this button?" she asked. "It says, 'Don't pay department store prices.' I raised four kids on yard sales."
Then, as she had probably done at least a hundred times before, Ms. Mannix went into a story about the time she dressed the giant pig up as Zsa Zsa Gabor and took him to the Queen Kumquat Sashay in Orlando, Fla.
The story was free. No purchase required.
